DOC.HEAD: In Man Vs. Machine, Man Still Ahead in the Game of Chess
DOC.TEXT: Chess champion Antoly Karpov proved that man can still outwit machine when he beat supercomputer Deep Thought late Friday in a hard-fought match that went down to the wire. With only 90 seconds left to Deep Thought's 12 minutes, Karpov forced the computer to resign in the face of inevitable defeat. Karpov, the world's No. 2-ranked chess player, made a decisive penetration into Deep Thought's territory with his king after the computer, which can calculate 800,000 moves in a second, made a strategic error. The match, which lasted nearly two hours, was held in Harvard's Memorial Hall. One member of Deep Thought's crew, Sen-Hsiung Hsu, moved the pieces based on the computer's commands. Chris Chabris, alumni adviser to the Harvard Chess Club, said Karpov was ``was very relieved'' to have finished the game with his world-class reputation intact. ``He knew he was in a lot of trouble,'' Chabris said. Karpov left immediately after the match instead of speaking as scheduled. ``Everyone was very impressed with the way Deep Thought was performing today. We look forward to watching Deep Thought's progress in the future,'' said the Harvard Chess Club's president, Danny Edelman. Just before the match, Karpov was given the key to the city and warmly welcomed by Edelman, who said Deep Thought was ready for revenge after being beaten by World Chess Champion Gary Kasparov in October of 1989. However, by sacrificing a pawn, Karpov was able to isolate Deep Thought's pawns in a move Edelman termed ``brilliant.'' After the pawns were isolated, it was an easy win for Karpov, Chabris said.

DOC.HEAD: RHODE ISLAND
Mandela's Daughter Elated Over Release
With PM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: After more than 27 years, Makaziwe Mandela-Amuah is happy to be getting her father back. But the 35-year-old daughter of jailed African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela says the release doesn't mean the struggle has ended in South Africa. ``Apartheid is not over today,'' she said after South African President F.W. de Klerk announced Friday in a speech to Parliament that Mandela would be released unconditionally, although he set no date. The historic changes ``will be meaningless until apartheid is totally destroyed, until the conditions of the people in South Africa improve ... and all the illegal laws that have declared us inferior non-citizens in the land of our birth are totally dismantled,'' said Mandela, who is known as Maki. At a news conference at the University of Massachusetts, where she is a Fulbright Scholar studying anthropology, Maki Mandela said she got up at 3 a.m. to watch the broadcast live on cable television. ``Even if it didn't happen today, the thought that I will have a father back, that he will be a free man again, is very, very good news to me,'' she said. In his address to Parliament, de Klerk also legalized the ANC after 30 years of guerrilla war against white rule and said he would lift bans on more than 30 other opposition groups. The announcements appeared to clear the way for talks on a new constitution that would end the black majority's exclusion from national politics. Maki Mandela said the reforms announced were a landmark, but the news she found most exciting was the promise of her father's pending release. Mandela, 71, has been jailed since 1962 on charges he helped plan the start of the ANC's sabotage and bombing campaign. ``I think for many people in the international community my father is a symbol of the liberation struggle,'' she said. ``I think that he's a source of encouragement to many people in the world and they are amazed that a man who has been in prison for more than 27 years can still be so dedicated to fight and bring an evil system down to its knees.'' Maki Mandela, the youngest of three children from Mandela's first marriage, said she has no immediate plans to fly back to South Africa because she must finish her studies. She last saw her father during a visit over the summer.

DOC.HEAD: Couple Loses House, Car in Week Since Wedding
DOC.TEXT: Duff and Bernadette Jacobson have been married just over a week, and it's been anything but wedded bliss. Shortly after their Jan 26 wedding, the Palisades couple was involved in a traffic accident. Their only car was totaled; they escaped injury. On Thursday night, the couple's rented house caught on fire. The Jacobsons were not home at the time. Duff Jacobson, 25, said he was able to retrieve some of their clothes before flames destroyed the home. They now are living with Bernadette Jacobson's parents. Mrs. Jacobson, 19, said she has been shaken by the disasters, but the two agreed that their life together is bound to improve. ``It couldn't get any worse,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Selected for Hazelwood Trial
DOC.TEXT: A jury was selected in the trial of former Exxon Valdez captain Joseph Hazelwood, clearing the way for opening arguments next week. Twelve jurors were picked Friday after the screening of 52 candidates by attorneys and Anchorage Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone. Jurors who will hear the case stemming from the nation's worst oil spill are an air-traffic control trainee, an engineer, a real estate agent, the vice president of an insurance firm, a cook, a job seeker with a background in criminal justice, the chief operating officer of a corporation, a homemaker, the hardware manager of a tool-rental store, a grocer, a child-care worker and a mail carrier. Opening arguments may start as early as Monday in Hazelwood's trial on a felony charge of criminal mischief and on misdemeanor charges of operating a vessel while intoxicated, reckless endangerment and negligent discharge of oil. The maximum penalty for conviction on all counts is seven years, three months in prison and $61,000 in fines. The 987-foot Exxon Valdez that Hazelwood commanded spilled nearly 11 million gallons of Alaska crude oil after ramming a charted reef. Selection of the jury was completed after Johnstone granted each side in the case additional opportunities to rule out prospective jurors. He gave two more peremptory challenges to Hazelwood's attorneys and one to the state prosecutor. Peremptory challenges allow lawyers to remove a prospective juror without having to give a reason. Otherwise, they only can ask that a juror be removed for some cause, such as expressed bias. The trial for Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., is expected to last at least six weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Veterans' Groups Angered by Flag Ban at Funerals
DOC.TEXT: The Roman Catholic Church's decision to ban the traditional draping of an American flag on the coffins of war veterans or police officers has drawn fire from veterans' groups. ``There are a lot of people who feel strongly that either Dad or Uncle Charley or whoever received these war medals, and should have the right to a flag if they want it,'' said Hank Bradley, commander of the American Legion's Norfolk County district. A Vatican-approved revision of the funeral liturgy took effect Dec. 3. It specifically spelled out a ban on secular symbols, which had been stated less clearly in an earlier liturgy. ``We believe the Eucharist, or the Mass, is so central to faith, that only Christian symbols can be used,'' said Msgr. Dennis Sheehan, director of the Boston Archdiocesan Office for Family Worship. The casket may be draped with a flag during the wake, but it must be replaced with a white cloth before the funeral. The flag may be returned to the casket after the service. John Walsh, a spokesman for Cardinal Bernard Law, said some veterans' groups had already contacted the archdiocese to object. ``Some will apparently misunderstand this as a denigration of patriotism, he said. ``It is no such thing. I don't want to make light of what the veterans are feeling. But they should try to look at the intent of this particular norm.'' But veterans' groups disagree. ``It's terrible. If someone served in the war and they're a veteran like my husband, I think they should have the right to have the flag draped over them,'' said Anne Torrance, a member of the American Legion Auxiliary.

DOC.HEAD: Cholera Epidemic in Shaba Province
DOC.TEXT: A cholera epidemic has broken out in the mining province of Shaba, killing 21 people in the past month, medical authorities reported. The authorities said the two towns of Moba and Kalemie have been hardest hit. Zaire suffers from a shortage of medical supplies, making the struggle against the disease difficult.

DOC.HEAD: Costly Aircraft Bomb-Sniffing Devices Not Good Enough, Panelists Say
DOC.TEXT: Members of a presidential commission say a costly new device to detect explosives at airports is flawed and probably could not have found the terrorist bomb which destroyed Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland. Members of the Presidential Commission on Aviation Security and Terrorism complained Friday that the giant and heavy bomb detectors being deployed at major U.S. and foreign airports have not been adequately tested. Several members said at a hearing the devices should not be installed at hundreds of airports until their reliability can be guaranteed. But Monte Belger, associate administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration, said the sophisticated detection device is the best of its kind, has gone through enough tests and should be set up soon to make airports more secure. ``It is not perfect and we know it ...,'' Belger said. ``It would be a mistake not to continue to deploy it. It is wrong to wait for the perfect machine.'' At an all-day hearing, the commission also was told the device _ which uses a technique called thermal neutron analysis, or TNA _ will cost far more than original estimates of between $700,000 to $1 million each. Belger said the first five TNA machines actually will cost a total of $15 million, or about $3 million each, because of the rush order. A TNA system _ employing an 18-foot high, ten-ton detector _ is inspecting baggage at Kennedy International Airport in New York. A second system was installed at Miami International Airport last week and is being calibrated. A third TNA machine is to be installed at Gatwick Airport near London next month, and another is being planned for Washington Dulles International Airport. ``I think there is a lot of flim-flam going on,'' said Sen. Alphonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., a commission member, saying the TNA has ``incredible deficiencies.'' ``The TNA looks good but it does not do what it is supposed to do,'' D'Amato said. ``Congress has been sold a bill of goods. ... There is a reduced ability to detect plastic explosives at the levels believed to have been used at Lockerbie.'' Investigators believe the Lockerbie crash on Dec. 21, 1988, was caused by less than a pound of plastic explosives inside a portable tape player. The crash killed 259 people aboard the Boeing 747 aircraft and 11 people on the ground. Hadi Bozorgmanesh, vice president of Science Applications International Corp., defended the TNA device his company developed, saying the accusation that the machine cannot detect bombs as small as two pounds is ``absolutely false.'' He said the machine has a 94 percent reliability rate and ``we would like to get closer to 100 percent and to detect smaller amounts of explosives with better accuracy.'' ``I totally agree that the system is not perfect, but it's far better than anything else that can be demonstrated,'' he said. D'Amato said setting the device to detect a Lockerbie-sized bomb would set off so many false alarms ``you would have a system which is inoperative.'' Science magazine, which first reported in August that the TNA machines would not be able to detect a Lockerbie-sized bomb, said the devices are being set at a sensitivity to detect about 2{ pounds of explosives. The TNA machines probe luggage for the presence of nitrogen, a major component of explosives. A problem with the TNA system is that some types of fabric, leather and such things as plastic ski boots can have nitrogen densities as high as explosives.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Czar Declares `Scourge Is Beginning to Pass'
DOC.TEXT: The drug ``scourge is beginning to pass'' and the government is well on its way to winning the war against narcotics, national drug policy director William J. Bennett says. ``The war is by no means over, but it is clearly winnable and the momentum, I think, is shifting our way,'' Bennett told the Senate Judiciary Committee on Friday. He said there ``is still too much bad news'' but there are also ``scattered but clear signs that we are beginning to win, the scourge is beginning to pass. If we keep up our efforts, indeed, intensify our efforts, we are going to win.'' Bennett said when he became head of the effort a year ago, ``it was by no means certain that we would win it.'' But he said, ``My view has changed.'' His remarks did not stray beyond what the Bush administration unveiled last week in the second installment of its anti-drug strategy, calling for a $10.6 billion budget in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. Senators of both parties did not bicker over details of the administration's plan. But Chairman Joseph Biden, D-Del., did ask Bennett to comment on an alternative strategy Biden wrote. It calls for putting more stress on hard-core users, education, treatment and a one-time program to forgive international debt owed by Andean nations if farmers plant other crops in place of the coca they normally produce. Bennett agreed with most Biden proposals and said differences were largely a matter of emphasis. But he said that if forced to choose between education and enforcement, he would strengthen enforcement. The former secretary of education said his background is ``a helpful auxiliary.'' ``I know children,'' Bennett said. ``That may not be a very rosy view of children, but I do know children.'' ``It seems to me that it's more than a helpful auxiliary,'' Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., said. ``You talk to LeRoy Martin, the superintendent of police in Chicago, and he'll tell you that education should be the centerpiece.'' Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., pressed Bennett on why the administration did not bar the import of semiautomatic assault pistols which are often only slightly different from the semiautomatic assault rifles the government does not allow to be imported. The question sparked an exchange similar to fiery arguments over firearms that have arisen at past Judiciary Committee hearings between Bennett and Sens. Kennedy and Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio. ``Why are you silent? Why are you quiet?'' Kennedy demanded. ``Because I have given my advice to the president, Senator, and that is where it should lie,'' Bennett said. Kennedy pressed ahead, reminding Bennett at one point that police are in danger of being targets of assault pistols. Bennett said the issue was highly complex and criminals would always be able to get guns while other people had good reason to possess weapons. ``The world is awash in guns, Senator,'' Bennett said. ``This is a cheap, symbolic victory that you are interested in that has nothing to do with reality.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Lawmakers Welcome South Africa Words, Wait for Action
DOC.TEXT: President Bush says U.S. sanctions against South Africa should be reviewed in light of President F.W. de Klerk's reform announcements, but he wants to see more specifics before scaling back the sanctions. ``I'm sure that we'll have a lot of debate and discussion inside the administration as to what the next move by the United States ought to be,'' Bush told reporters. ``I am one who has not favored additional sanctions, so I'm perfectly willing to review things as new developments take place.'' Bush said he would look particularly for the freeing of imprisoned African nationalist leader Nelson Mandela. ``I think when people move in the right direction, it's certainly timely to review all policy. But we haven't gotten into any specifics on that at this point. We want to see the policy initiatives go forward and the release of Mandela,'' he said. De Klerk announced Friday that he would free Mandela, a political prisoner for 27 years, and lift the ban on Mandela's outlawed African National Congress and other political opposition organizations. De Klerk announced a series of other reform measures, but they stopped short of what the United States would require to lift the sanctions, said U.S. officials. Under U.S. law, the president can suspend or modify the sanctions if Mandela and other political prisoners are freed and other specific conditions are met. ``All are essential in ending apartheid and restoring justice,'' said Rep. William H. Gray III, D-Pa. Some members of Congress urged Bush to keep the sanctions in place, noting South Africa's system of racial apartheid is still intact. ``The sanctions should be maintained in full force. This is no time to relax them,'' said Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass. ``Apartheid is crumbling as the Berlin Wall crumbled only a few months ago,'' Kennedy said, adding the sanctions had helped pressure South Africa into changes. The economic sanctions include a ban on U.S. imports of textiles, coal, uranium, steel and agricultural products, and prohibition of new U.S. investment in South Africa, landing rights for South African airlines and new bank loans to the country. Pretoria in recent weeks has freed several political prisoners and prominent opposition leaders. Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., former chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said de Klerk had made a ``bold stroke for freedom,'' but that Bush has promised to consult with Congress before he takes any action. Lugar added, ``The trend in events is South Africa has been a strong one toward negotiation.'' In Washington, the Rev. Jesse Jackson said ``we must balance hope with caution. Caution because the structure of apartheid is still in place and Nelson Mandela is still in jail.'' Randall Robinson, executive director of TransAfrica, a Washington lobbying organization, said ``celebration would be premature. ... as long as the apartheid system remains in place, as it does, we must sustain in the United States the imposition of economic sanctions.'' As rumors of Mandela's imminent release circulated, White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater has said President Bush would invite him to the White House and invite de Klerk in a separate visit. There was talk last year of a visit by de Klerk to Washington, but it failed to materialize in the face of controversy over whether Bush should receive a leader whose government enforces official apartheid policies of racial separation. Bush reacted to the news from South Africa as he was leaving Friday for a trip to Raleigh, N.C., and Knoxville, Tenn., to spotlight his budget proposals on science and research and development. The president said the news from South Africa was ``quite positive.'' ``I'm very encouraged by some of the changes that have taken place and certainly by representations yesterday by Mr. de Klerk,'' he said. The Bush administration has made few public pronouncements on South Africa, maintaining opposition to the apartheid policies but not taking any new initiatives in the region.

DOC.HEAD: Sudan Chief Justice Tells Inmates Their Limbs Will be Spared
DOC.TEXT: Authorities have decided not to cut off the limbs of 12 prisoners condemned to that punishment under Islamic law, and similar cases are under review, the chief justice said. The Sudan News Agency said Friday that Chief Justice Kamil Ali Lutfi had also ordered retrials for some people sentenced to various punishments under Islamic law. The news agency gave no reason for Lutfi's actions. However, Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir's 7-month-old military government has come under strong criticism from the Amnesty International human rights group and other Western agencies and governments for alleged violations of human rights. In 1983, Sudan began a strict interpretation of Islamic law, which decrees that a thief's limbs must amputated, an adultress must be stoned to death and people who drink alcohol must be flogged. Murder was made punishable by death, unless the victim's kin accepts payment from the culprit. However, Lutfi has begun reviewing dozens of such sentences imposed under the tough Islamic penal code, which is called hudud, the news agency said. ``We will reconsider those sentences,'' he was quoted as saying. On Thursday, the first day of Lufti's review, he told 12 inmates each sentenced to having an arm and leg lopped off that he was changing their punishments to prison terms of five to 10 years. The change triggered speculation that the move was made under pressure from moderate military men inside and outside the ruling 15-member junta to get the government to improve its image. President Gaafar Nimeiri, deposed by the military in 1985 after a 16-year rule, imposed Islamic law in 1983. Several dozen people convicted of theft had limbs cut off in the 20 months before his overthrow. Nimeiri's action brought criticism from neighboring Egypt and Western countries, including the United States. It also has added fuel to a southern rebellion launched by the Sudan People's Liberation Army. After Nimeiri's fall, courts continued to hand down sentences in accordance with the hudud. But the sentences were not carried out and remained suspended until the chief justice's review began on Thursday. Police Brig. Gen. Al-Kamil M. Soleiman of the Prisons Administration said there were 40 convicts in jail who must pay money to the families of murder victims. Another 37 prisoners had been sentenced to limb amputations and were waiting for them to be carried out, he said. The news agency quoted Lutfi as saying he had ordered ordered retrials for some of those sentenced under hudud. He did not specify the number.

DOC.HEAD: Rights Report ``Doesn't Pull Any Punches'' on China
DOC.TEXT: The State Department's annual human rights report ``doesn't pull any punches'' in describing abuses by China in its crackdown on the pro-democracy movement, according to a congressional source familiar with the report. The frankness of the document surprised some congressional figures who expected the Bush administration to mute criticism of China as it presses for better relations with Beijing. `It describes every human rights crime you can think of,'' a source who had seen the unreleased report said Friday night. ``Murders, disappearances, executions, suppression of labor rights, religious persecution of Catholics and Buddhists, slave labor camps in western China _ you name it, it's in there,'' said the source, speaking on condition of anonymity. The administration has asserted it is important to maintain a dialogue with Chinese leaders to encourage liberalization. Bush successfully vetoed a bill protecting Chinese students against deportation, arguing he had accomplished the same objectives through administrative action, and has sent high-level emissaries to China twice since last summer's bloody suppression of demonstrators in Tiananmen Square. ``We expected, in light of those visits, that they might go somewhat easy on the Chinese, but they didn't,'' said a second congressional source who also has seen the report. ``The report doesn't pull any punches,'' said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The second source said the document avoided high-temperature rhetoric, confining itself to ``factual and accurate'' statements. NBC News reported first on the report Friday evening. The network quoted from the document: ``As of year's end, there were continuing reliable reports of beatings of political detainees in the Beijing area by security forces ... prisoners, both criminal and political, are subjected to severe psychological pressure to confess.'' Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger is scheduled to appear before the House Foreign Affairs Committee and the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on successive days next week. The two congressional sources said he was certain to be questioned about the document. The annual report is given to the House or Senate committees in alternate years, and was scheduled for release Feb. 21 by the House committee. Congressional Democrats and even many Republicans have attacked Bush for moving too rapidly to re-establish ties with China since the Tiananmen Square massacre and say Beijing has made only cosmetic changes since June. China was one of the major criticisms of House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., in responding to Bush's State of the Union address on Wednesday. Earlier this week, Secretary of State James A. Baker III, in testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, listed in his advance text Cuba and China as countries who ``try to shut out democratic values,'' but in actually speaking the words omitted the reference to China. Bush has said he was pleased by the Chinese government's recent lifting of martial law and release of some prisoners.

DOC.BYLINE: Bush Voids China's Purchase of Aircraft Parts Company ^By TOM RAUM
DOC.TEXT: President Bush says his decision to void China's purchase of a Seattle aircraft parts company was made on national security grounds and not to discourage Chinese investment in the United States. Bush on Friday ordered the divestiture of the Mamco Manufacturing Co. of Seattle by the China National Aero-Technology Import and Export Corp., which is owned by the Chinese government. Bush's action on Mamco, which manufactures metal parts for aircraft, upheld the recommendation of an interagency panel. In a report to Congress, Bush said his action was based on ``a particular transaction'' and does not reflect a policy shift. ``It does not change our open investment policy and is not a precedent for the future with regard to direct investment of the United States from the People's Republic of China or any other country,'' Bush said. Even so, his move was likely to help mute widespread criticism in Congress that Bush has been too conciliatory toward the Beijing government since its brutal crackdown on China's pro-democracy movement. Citing ``credible confidential information,'' Bush negated the December 1988 acquisition on national security grounds. The Chinese corporation was given three months to sell all its holdings in the company, with the possibility of a single three-month extension. Bush's order invoked for the first time a provision of a 1988 trade law that gives the president power to restrict foreign investment in the United States if the nation's security may be harmed. The president ordered the Chinese government to sell the company because ``continued control of Mamco might threaten to impair the national security,'' the White House said in a statement. It did not elaborate on what harm might result from the Chinese ownership. The action came a week after Bush's veto of a bill extending visas of Chinese students in the United States was narrowly sustained by the Senate. Bush called the legislation an infringement on his presidential foreign policy prerogatives. But some members of Congress argued Bush has acted too quickly to step up contacts with the Beijing government, which they said has done little to loosen its staunch control since the Tiananmen Square crackdown last June. Sanctions Bush imposed after the crackdown bar all military sales to China. However, Bush's order on Friday did not allege a violation of those sanctions in the relationship between Mamco and China. The interagency panel that reviewed Mamco found the Seattle company, which reported $20 million in sales in 1988, was involved with sensitive materials that could have military applications, said officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity. The Chinese corporation is part of the Chinese Ministry of Aerospace Industry. It has business dealings with various U.S. companies ``in several sectors, including commercial aircraft,'' the White House statement said. Bush acted under the so-called Exon-Florio provision of 1988 trade legislation that allows a president to intervene to bar foreign investment in the United States on national security grounds. The legislation is named after Sen. James Exon, D-Neb., and former Rep. James Florio, D-N.J., now the governor of New Jersey.

DOC.HEAD: Former Joint Chiefs See Less Need for U.S. Mobile Missiles
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration should kill plans to upgrade its land-based, nuclear missile force if a U.S.-Soviet pact is signed on strategic weapons and mobile missiles, say three former chairmen of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. ``I just don't see the great need for modernization of that element right now,'' retired Gen. David Jones, who served as joint chiefs chairman in the early 1980s, told the Senate Armed Services Committee on Friday. Asked whether one part of the strategic deterrent could be dropped, the former chairmen agreed on drastically scaling back plans to build more multiple-warhead, rail-based MX missiles and to deploy the new, single-warhead Midgetman. ``I would cancel the two land-based missiles,'' said retired Gen. John Vessey, who was joint chiefs chairman in the mid-1980s. ``I think the idea that someone's going to attack our silo-based missile forces, ... it's just not reasonable now.'' Retired Adm. William Crowe, who stepped down last October as chairman of the joint chiefs, agreed with Vessey, and noted the United States has ``a mobile missile in the field _ the seaborne mobile missile'' on submarines. The comments by the former military leaders prompted the committee's chairman, Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., to say that unless the administration pushes for a ban on multiple-warhead missiles in a strategic arms control pact, he would not support the MX and Midgetman. ``I sold a lot of people on that _ people on both sides of this issue _ that I thought a ban on mobile (multiple warheads) was going to be forthcoming from the White House ..., '' Nunn said. ``There is no way that I can support two missiles this year with the current arms control position that we have.'' The United States and Soviet Union are working on a treaty that would cut their long-range nuclear arsenals by 30 percent to 50 percent, to 6,000 warheads apiece. However, the two sides disagree over how to count air-launched cruise missiles, how to handle undeployed missiles and U.S. allegations that the Soviets have encoded data transmissions from ballistic missile tests in violation of arms accords. Secretary of State James A. Baker III is expected to discuss the issues with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze when the two meet next week in Moscow. The administration's new budget released Monday proposes spending $2.8 billion to fund rail-basing of the MX and $202 million for the truck-based Midgetman. Fifty MX missiles are already in silos, along with the older Minuteman long-range missile force, and the administration wants to put 50 more MXs on rail cars to make them less vulnerable to attack. Vessey emphasized any action on the MX and Midgetman should be done along with a strategic arms control agreement with the Soviet Union. ``I would not do this without forcing them to give up their mobile (warheads),'' he said. Jones suggested some money should be left in the missile programs for research and development. Nunn expressed dismay over the failure of the administration to spell out its strategy and arms control agenda, especially in light of the collapse of communist regimes in Eastern Europe. ``We're going to have an arms control position that's out of sync with our strategic planning and our posture and it's just a tragedy we can't get together on this,'' Nunn said. ``It's got to start with some vision coming out of the White House and the Department of Defense.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Marina Ogilvy, a pregnant 23-year-old cousin of Queen Elizabeth II, gave up her longshot claim to the British throne to marry the father of her child. Miss Ogilvy, due to give birth in May, had been 24th in line for the throne. She forfeited that claim Friday by marrying a Roman Catholic, freelance photographer Paul Mowatt, 26. When Miss Ogilvy told her parents she was pregnant, they demanded she either marry quickly or have an abortion. When she refused, they cut off her family allowance, she said in October. Her parents, Sir Agnus Ogilvy and Princess Alexandra, responded by issuing a public statement saying they loved their daughter, had not cut her off and that she always was welcome at their home. On Friday, she was greeted with a kiss from her father when she arrived at St. Andrew's Church 10 miles southwest of London. Afterward, Ogilvy said he felt ``fine'' and was ``delighted,'' while Princess Alexandra declared: ``It was a lovely wedding.'' The princess is sister of the Duke of Kent and is the queen's first cousin. The 45-minute private service was attended by about 40 guests.

The Dalai Lama was holding ``spiritual consultations'' with Czechoslovakia's playwright-president as part of a five-day visit to Prague, the official CTK news agency reported. The Tibetan spiritual leader, winner of the 1989 Nobel Peace Prize, arrived Friday for a visit at the invitation of President Vaclav Havel. Chinese diplomats criticized the invitation as an indication of political support for Tibetan separatism. But Havel said the Dalai Lama's visit was ``of a private nature.'' ``I wanted to invite him a long time ago when I was not yet a president,'' Havel said. ``I want to meditate with him.'' The new government, which was installed after the November democratic revolution, has sought to remove the sanctions against religious observance placed by the former Communist regime. Havel and the Dalai Lama are scheduled to spend Sunday in ``spiritual consultations and meditations'' in the presidential country residence at Lany, west of Prague. The Dalai Lama also scheduled meetings with Czechoslovakia's Roman Catholic primate, Cardinal Frantisek Tomasek, and with other religious representatives, CTK reported.

The rock 'n' roll group The Band, which broke up in 1976, may record another album, bass player and singer Rick Danko says. He and fellow The Band members Garth Hudson and Levon Helm are considering the project, Danko said in an interview. ``We want to do the definitive Band album, which we haven't done yet,'' he said. ``We're taking it in a cautious direction, one that we all know and understand.'' Danko now performs solo and is scheduled to sing at a Nashville nightspot Thursday. He performed on an American concert tour with ex-Beatle Ringo Starr last year.

A former mental patient accused of threatening to kill Johnny Carson unless he received millions of dollars pleaded innocent to 10 counts of making terrorist threats and extortion. Ken O. Gause, 36, of Milwaukee, entered his pleas Friday before Judge Charles Lee of Los Angeles County Superior Court. Lee ordered Gause to return Feb. 23 for a pretrial hearing. Gause, accused of making the threats to the late-night talk show host in letters and videotapes, was arrested Dec. 6 after taking a bus from Wisconsin to NBC Studios in Burbank. He could be sentenced to up to eight years in prison if convicted of all charges. Many of the letters bore a skull and crossbones and were signed ``Ken Orville Gause, the Baron KOG.''

The Rev. Sun-Myung Moon, head of the Unification Church, received a gold crown studded with diamonds and a ruby for his 70th birthday at a day-long party. The church's Segye Times newspaper said 12 former presidents and prime ministers of Bolivia, Costa Rica, Equador, Colombia and Peru were among 5,000 celebrants at the bash Thursday at Olympic Park in Seoul. The crown and a smaller crown given to Moon's wife were made to resemble the gold crowns worn by kings of the ancient Shilla Kingdom, which once ruled Korea, church officials said. Other gifts included a gold globe and a gold crane, a symbol of longevity, they said. Local newspapers said Moon's gifts were valued at several hundred thousand dollars. Moon's church claims to have 4 million followers in 137 countries, including 600,000 in South Korea. Church-controlled companies are involved in businesses ranging from soft-drink manufacturing to printing. The church has been criticized for exercising tight control over its followers, to the extent of selecting their marital partners.

Singer Frank Sinatra has canceled his four-night engagement at Bally's Reno because he has a cold and laryngitis, officials said. Sinatra's doctor recommended that he not perform as scheduled Thursday through Sunday, Bally's publicist Brian Lawson said Friday. Sinatra, 74, who normally sells out the 2,000-seat Ziegfeld Room, also canceled a scheduled appearance at Bally's last year because of illness.

DOC.HEAD: Sources: Iran-Contra Prosecutors Probing Former CIA Agent Clines
DOC.TEXT: Iran-Contra prosecutors are investigating whether former CIA operative Thomas G. Clines failed to report income on his tax returns from arms transactions involving the Contras, according to sources. The sources told The Associated Press Friday that Albert Hakim, who was placed on two years probation and fined $5,000 for his role in the Iran-Contra affair, is a key witness in the Clines investigation. Hakim and business partner Richard Secord set up ``the Enterprise,'' the network of offshore companies used to handle money in the secret supply operation to the Contras and the Reagan administration's sales of arms to Iran. Clines helped buy arms for the Contras starting in 1985 at the rest of Secord. Some $972,728 in commissions were set aside for Clines in the account of an entity code-named C. Tea, according to the congressional Iran-Contra report issued in November 1987. Hakim didn't begin supplying Iran-Contra prosecutors with information on the matter until he entered a plea agreement with the government Nov. 21. In court papers, the government said Hakim has ``indicated his willingness'' to give testimony ``in an anticipated future case'' and is cooperating in a grand jury investigation outside Washington. The papers did not elaborate, but the sources, commenting only on condition they not be named, told the AP the subject of the investigation is Clines. Clines' attorney, John Ellsworth Stein, declined comment Friday. But other sources familiar with the situation say Clines did in fact report money from the transactions on his tax returns. Clines takes the position that he has reported all his income, the sources said. Mary Belcher, a spokeswoman for the Iran-Contra prosecutor's office, declined to comment. Clines worked for the CIA for 30 years. He was an agent in Southeast Asia, was involved in the Bay of Pigs invasion of Cuba and became director of training in the directorate of operations, also known as the clandestine services. He also was a close associate of Edwin Wilson, the former CIA agent who is serving 52 years in federal prison for illegally selling guns and explosives to Libya. Clines pleaded guilty in 1984 on behalf of his wholly owned company to inflating bills submitted to the Defense Department for shipping U.S. military equipment to Egypt. He was fined the maximum $10,000 and paid the government $100,000 on behalf of his firm, Systems Services International.

DOC.HEAD: Day-Care Center Owner Found With Slashed Wrist
DOC.TEXT: A day-care center owner who allegedly took nude pictures of children in his care has been hospitalized with a slashed wrist after an apparent suicide attempt, police said. John Shaver, 56, was admitted as a psychiatric patient and listed in fair condition Friday at Broward General Medical Center after being found in a hotel bathtub with his right wrist cut, said police spokesman Ott Cefkin. Meanwhile, no evidence of physical abuse was found Friday in the first of 14 children scheduled for medical and psychological exams after their parents identified their pictures out of 200-300 nude photos found at Shaver's house, one official said. Six children visited the county's Sexual Assault Treatment Center Friday and none had been sexually assaulted, said center director Joanne Richter. Eight more children were scheduled for tests today. The pictures, which do not depict sex acts or sexual poses, show the children wet or in a wading pool and often covered with finger paint, Cefkin said. More parents are expected to view the pictures next week. Shaver, released on $5,000 bond Wednesday after his arrest Sunday, admits owning the pictures that police confiscated but does not consider them pornography. He faces five counts of possessing child pornography for magazines found at his home, just across the street from his Rainbow Learning Center. Possessing child pornography is a third-degree felony in Florida and punishable by a maximum five-year prison sentence, said Dave Casey of the Fort Lauderdale State Attorney's office. Shaver, who checked into the Guest Quarters Hotel Thursday, was found Friday in the tub dressed only in shorts. His right wrist had been cut with a serrated knife blade. In the room, police found seven empty 1-ounce liquor bottles and two notes. One note reiterated his denial that he took nude photos of children, and said it was easier to kill himself than deal with the situation, Cefkin said. The second note apologized to the hotel staff for the mess he would leave. Police also found a copy of the search warrant of his home and a printout of his money-market account, which showed Shaver was ``quite wealthy,'' Cefkin said. The children identified in the photos reported to the Sexual Assault Treatment Center for medical tests and interviews, director Richter said. The medical tests are ``mostly to alleviate the fears of the parents, and rule out the possibility of actual sexual abuse,'' she said. Although the photographs themselves are not pornographic under the law, they could lead to sexual exploitation accusations against Shaver if the evidence meets that criteria, Cefkin said. ``Our primary interest is the children,'' he said. ``We're not going to subject a child to the criminal justice system if it's not warranted.'' Broward County officials shut down Shaver's day-care center Thursday, contending Shaver ``lacked good moral character.'' Shaver opened the day-care center in 1985 for children ages 3 to 5. Thirty children, mostly 4 and 5, attended the center at the time it closed, and about 200 have attended since it opened. In 1984 in Hawaii, Shaver pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge of operating a day-care center without a license. The plea came a year after the state of Hawaii revoked his license amid allegations that he fondled several young girls at his center. He was never criminally charged and Shaver denied any wrongdoing.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Dismisses Lawsuit By Former Lebanese Ambassador
DOC.TEXT: The Lebanese government of Elias Hrawi has control of the nation's embassy in the United States after a federal judge ended a dispute that reflected the violent divisions in Beirut. U.S. District Judge Harold Greene on Friday dismissed a lawsuit by the former Lebanese ambassador to Washington, an ally of the Lebanese Christian military leader Gen. Michel Aoun. Hours later, the embassy was turned over to Hrawi representatives, said the Secret Service, which is responsible for security at embassies. ``The transition occurred smoothly and there were no difficulties,'' said Secret Service spokesman Rich Adams, although he said there was some shouting between the two factions as they were watched closely by Secret Service officers. Greene ruled that former ambassador Abdallah Bouhabib, who was trying to avoid being evicted, was given adequate notice that the United States was recognizing Hrawi's new government. Greene denied the request for a preliminary injunction by a Lebanese faction to which Bouhabib remains loyal. The Hrawi government has designated the former Lebanese consul in Washington, Bassam Naamani, as charge d'affaires pending the arrival of a new ambassador. Naamani has been working in a commercial office arranged by the Arab League. Bouhabib became Lebanese ambassador to the United States in 1983. Hrawi was elected president on Nov. 24 and dismissed Aoun, who refuses to recognize the rival Christian government. When a group of demonstrators supporting Aoun temporarily occupied parts of the embassy in Washington Jan. 22, Bouhabib was told the U.S. government would send law enforcement personnel to the premises the next day to remove him and all those attached to the Aoun regime. The Aoun faction filed suit against the secretary of state. In court papers, the State Department said it notified Bouhabib Dec. 11 that he was no longer Lebanese ambassador.

DOC.HEAD: Teacher, Librarian Reinstated Over `Catch-22'
DOC.TEXT: The school superintendent reinstated a teacher and librarian who were suspended after high school students were shown the R-rated film ``Catch-22.'' La Cueva High School teacher Joyce Briscoe and librarian Pauline Jones had been suspended Wednesday with pay after the film was shown to college-bound juniors in Ms. Briscoe's English class. The film had been checked out of the school library. Officials said the two were reinstated Friday after they learned that ``Catch-22'' was rated PG at Albuquerque's Manzano High. Superintendent Jack Bobroff said the two would return to work Monday. He said he suspended them ``not for disciplinary reasons but as standard procedure to handle potentially disruptive situations and in situations where school policy has not been strictly adhered to.'' But Richard D. Heffner, chairman of the board of the Classification and Ratings Administration for the Motional Picture Association of America, said late Friday that the PG rating was a mistake. He said in a telephone interview from Los Angeles that ``Catch-22'' has always been rated R. School guidelines released Jan. 10 require a committee to review films rated PG-13 or R before they are shown. The principal would then review the committee's recommendations and make a decision. An R-rated film at a movie theater requires children under age 17 to be accompanied by a parent or adult guardian. Ms. Briscoe, meanwhile, said in a statement that she and Ms. Jones were pleased to be returning to work. She also thanked her colleagues and city residents for their support. Ms. Briscoe had sparked controversy last fall when she showed students with parental permission ``The Last Temptation of Christ,'' which some religious groups find offensive. La Cueva student body president Randy Puro, one of Ms. Briscoe's students, said before the reinstatement that students had believed ``their rights as individuals have been taken away.'' ``If people think movies are going to corrupt kids, as far as I'm concerned, the news on TV is going to corrupt kids,'' he said. La Cueva students and teachers circulated petitions supporting the two, and the Albuquerque Federation of Teachers had filed a grievance asking that Ms. Briscoe and Ms. Jones be immediately reinstated. School board president Diego Gallegos said district administration probably overreacted to the ``Catch-22'' screening because of the furor over ``Last Temptation.'' ``Catch-22,'' based on Joseph Heller's novel of the same name, portrays life in a U.S. bomber squadron during World War II. The book is on the national advanced placement reading list for honors students. The 1970 film directed by Mike Nichols stars Alan Arkin, Jon Voight, Orson Welles, Richard Benjamin, Art Garfunkel, Anthony Perkins and Bob Newhart.

DOC.HEAD: Legislators Hit Big Medigap Price Increases
DOC.TEXT: Members of Congress are criticizing the insurance industry for socking the elderly with huge price increases for ``medigap'' health policies and say tougher regulation may be needed to curb price and marketing abuses. ``Millions of seniors spend billions of dollars each year on medigap policies and many are being ripped off and cheated out of their limited fixed incomes,'' Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., told a Senate Finance subcommittee on Friday. ``This medigap mess has flourished because federal regulation is a voluntary, unenforceable patchwork of legal mumbo-jumbo, more loophole than law,'' he said. Private insurance companies sell medigap policies to the elderly to bridge gaps in their coverage from Medicare. Premiums are rising sharply this year. Insurers say the increases are justified because health-care costs are rising and because benefits must be provided that previously were offered under Medicare's catastrophic-care program. But several members of the Senate subcommittee on Medicare and long-term care questioned whether the big rate increases are warranted, even with rising costs and the repeal of the catastrophic-care program.
_ ^Government Urges Delay in Use of Reagan Diary

The Justice Department is urging a delay in turning over 33 excerpts from former President Reagan's diaries to Iran-Contra defendant John Poindexter and says a summary of the entries should be compiled for Poindexter's use instead. U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene had set a deadline of Monday for Reagan to give the nearly three dozen excerpts to his former national security adviser, who is scheduled to go on trial Feb. 20. In urging a postponement, the Justice Department said Friday that many of the 33 entries duplicate material that came to light in last year's Iran-Contra trial of former White House aide Oliver North. ``Indeed, there may be no information in the diary entries covered by'' Greene's court order ``that is not in the public domain,'' the Justice Department said in a five-page brief. It said Iran-Contra prosecutors and Poindexter's lawyers should attempt to draft a stipulation covering the facts contained in the diary entries. Greene can then compare the proposed stipulation with the diary entries ``to ensure that all pertinent information has been covered,'' said the Justice Department. A stipulation is an agreement on facts by both sides in a lawsuit.
DOC.HEAD: Senators Say Bush's Budget Would Cut Drug Fight On Border
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's proposed budget could gut efforts to fight illegal drug trafficking along the U.S.-Mexico border, contrary to administration promises to step up law enforcement on the front lines, area Democrats say. The Southwest border's four Democratic senators said Friday that Bush's budget seeks personnel reductions in three federal law enforcement agencies that could seriously affect their operations along the border. Bush released his budget Monday, four days after declaring the Southwest border, Houston, Los Angeles, Miami and New York City were ``high intensity drug trafficking areas'' eligible for hundreds of additional law enforcement agents and millions of dollars in additional federal aid. But Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, said the benefit of being targeted for more help has been undercut by the president's budget, which seeks reductions for the Immigration and Naturalization Service, the Customs Service, and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. According to Bentsen and fellow Sens. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., and Jeff Bingaman, D-N.M., a total of 636 positions would be cut from Customs, 423 from the INS, and 185 from the ATF, the lead agency on the border for gang enforcement and firearms investigations. The senators, in a letter Friday to William J. Bennett, director of the office of national drug control policy, ask his help in restoring these law enforcement positions to federal agencies ``which are this nation's front line forces in the war on drugs.''

DOC.HEAD: Guilty Senator May Face Jury of Senate Peers
DOC.TEXT: A powerful state senator who was found guilty of corruption by a federal court jury now faces the prospect of a jury of his 38 colleagues. A U.S. District Court jury on Fridday found state Sen. Joseph Montoya guilty of one count of racketeering, one count of money laundering and five counts of extortion. He was found innocent of three other extortion counts, including one that accused him of asking for money from actor Ed Asner and the Screen Actors Guild in exchange for help with legislation. Montoya, chairman of the Senate Business and Professions Committee, is the first California legislator in 35 years to be convicted of a felony while in office. U.S. District Judge Milton Schwartz set sentencing for April 26. Until then, Montoya will remain free on his own recognizance. He faces a potential maximum sentence of 125 years in prison and a $1.75 million fine, according to prosecutors, who said they would ask for a prison sentence. But the guilty verdicts did not cost Montoya his Senate seat. It would take a two-thirds vote of the Senate to expel Montoya from the Legislature if he doesn't resign first. Defense attorney Michael Sands refused to say Friday if Montoya planned to step down. Senate leader David Roberti of Los Angeles said in a brief statement that he would talk to Montoya and convene a Senate Rules Committee hearing on Monday to consider Montoya's status. Many said the conviction would almost certainly put more pressure on legislators to enact tougher standards of ethics for themselves. Common Cause, a citizens group that supports political reform measures, said Montoya's conviction ``further diminished the reputation of a once respected institution, and, if nothing else, reaffirmed the need for comprehensive ethics and campaign finance reform legislation.'' Montoya, who sat between his attorneys at the defense table, seemed to pale when Schwartz read the guilty verdict on the first count. Montoya, 50, refused to speak to reporters afterwards and left the courthouse through a security gate as U.S. marshals blocked the media. Sands said he would appeal the verdict. Jurors, who deliberated 18 hours over four days, said they had a difficult time reaching their verdicts. ``It was not an easy decision,'' said juror Emily Ingram of Benicia. ``We toiled over it. A few of us lost sleep; some of us could not eat.'' Montoya's former top aide, Amiel Jaramillo, was indicted with the senator and is scheduled to go on trial next month on racketeering and extortion charges.

DOC.HEAD: Government Rules Noriega a POW, But Still can be Prosecuted
DOC.TEXT: Deposed Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega has been given prisoner-of-war status, but the U.S. government said he still will face drug trafficking charges in federal court. The government filed its response to counter defense arguments that civilian courts have no jurisdiction over Noriega and co-defendant Luis del Cid, who surrendered to U.S. troops following the invasion of Panama. ``The government intends to provide prisoner-of-war treatment to Noriega and del Cid,'' said the 39-page federal document filed Friday. Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael Sullivan said the government agrees the Geneva Convention covers the hostilities in Panama. But the Geneva Convention also allows for the prosecution of POWs for offenses committed before the time they came into U.S. custody, Sullivan said. U.S. Justice Department spokesman David Runkel said prisoner-of-war status means Noriega can direct any complaints about prison conditions to a U.S. military liaison officer already designated by the Defense Department, but he will not be moved to a military facility. ``Even if Noriega and del Cid are considered to be `prisoners of war' within the meaning of the Geneva Convention, they are not entitled to dismissal of the charges against them,'' read the response filed with U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler. The judge has scheduled a hearing for Thursday on the issue of his jurisdiction and Noriega's POW status. Prior to the prosecution's response, del Cid's attorney Samuel Burstyn filed his own motion Friday demanding his client's release. Burstyn cited a federal appeals court case, U.S. vs. Toscanino, which says a prisoner should be released if the court ``finds that the United States government deliberately and unreasonably exploited illegal conduct in an outrageous fashion.'' Burstyn said that should apply to the U.S. invasion of Panama. ``The U.S. government illegally dispatched 25,000 agents (members of the U.S. armed forces and others) to forcibly enter the Republic of Panama,'' said the motion. He said the government was ``in effect kidnapping him to the United States'' with the invasion. Noriega and del Cid face drug-trafficking and money-laundering charges in a 12-count February 1988 indictment, which accuses them of turning Panama into a safe haven and shipment point for U.S.-bound cocaine.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. businessman who's worried that that perestroika might fail wants Americans to buck up Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev by sending him a dollar in care of the Kremlin. ``I'm asking the public to spend the price of a good lottery ticket,'' Robert Forrest said Friday. ``This is the biggest lottery in the world. I'm asking people to take a chance on Mikhail Gorbachev. ``It's a way to help'' Gorbachev's reform movement, Forrest said. ``He needs a little help from his friends right now.'' Forrest, an Oregon mortgage broker who is president of a gold mine in California, is promoting his campaign with bumper stickers emblazoned: ``Send a Buck to Gorbachev.'' ``I think people all over the world are saying, `This could go either way,''' he said. ``If we could get an outpouring of support all over the world, we might influence the outcome. The intent is to write a letter, even if you don't send any money.'' Forrest already has sent his letter to Gorbachev. ``I want you to use that $1 to buy soap or bread or milk, meat, butter or shoes or whatever it is that your people need that will help you succeed in your reformation of the Soviet society and economy,'' Forrest wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Swiss Drug Company Buys Majority Share of Genentech for $2.1 Billion
DOC.TEXT: A Swiss drug company will become the majority stockholder of Genentech Inc., the world's leading biotechnology company, in a $2.1 billion deal some say will boost long-term research. Robert Swanson, founder of Genentech, said Friday the merger with Roche Holding Ltd. was made because ``huge investments are needed to get new products to the market.'' Swanson, named chairman of the board on Friday, said at a news conference announcing the transaction that the company will have ``the resources and the independence to fully deliver the dream of biotechnology.'' Swanson referred to the 14-year-old company's need to be free from Wall Street pressures to deliver quarterly profits, which have been needed to invest in products still in development and two or three years from term. Genentech has been the clear leader in biotechnology, racking up profits every year since 1979 except for one, and has a scientific staff considered the biggest and best in the field. But the company's stock was depressed on Wall Street and the company sought a corporate partner to provide funds for development and meet increasing competition on its two existing products. Genentech hopes to sell more of TPA or Activase, which helps dissolve blood clots in heart attack victims, and human growth hormone, a treatment for children with pituitary dwarfism. Sales of TPA failed to live up to expectations in 1988, its first full year on the market. The disappointing results turned Genentech ``from a darling to a dog on Wall Street,'' as The New York Times characterized it, and its stock plummeted. ``We have so much we want to do ... and the quarterly pressures of the stock market would inevitably inhibit our abilities to take advantage of the brain trust that works on these 30 acres here,'' said G. Kirk Raab, Genentech's president and chief executive officer, referring to company headquarters. Analysts generally hailed the agreement, saying it would give Genentech the cash it needs to invest heavily in research and free the company from Wall Street pressures. ``It's an incredible deal for Genentech in that Roche made the purchase not for immediate results on some products, but for the whole, overall goal of gaining the cutting edge of biotechnology research, which is something that's going to come years down the road,'' said Bob Cuper, a Genentech analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Co. in New York. Under the agreement, Roche will invest $492 million in Genentech, buying half its 82 million shares of outstanding stock for $36 per share _ 65 percent above Thursday's closing stock price. Genentech was the most active issue Friday on the New York Stock Exchange, rising $8.12{ to close at $29.87{. Roche will own 60 percent of the 112 million voting shares of Genentech stock that will be outstanding after the companies restructure and merge, the companies said. Genentech will remain a publicly traded company under the deal, they said. The proposal will be submitted to Genentech stockholders in April; the board of directors on Friday approved the agreement. Officials of both companies said Genentech's management and research division would operate independently of Roche, and that Genentech's sales force would remain intact and all the company's employees retained. Although it will become major shareholder, Roche will be given only two seats on Genentech's board of directors, which will be expanded by two members for a total of 13.

DOC.HEAD: Surprise Witness: Gotti's Alleged Victim Testifies
LaserPhoto NY7
DOC.TEXT: The lawyer for reputed mob boss John Gotti called a surprise witness on his client's behalf: the union official who prosecutors say was ordered shot by the defendant. John O'Connor testified Friday in the assault and conspiracy trial of Gotti that he didn't know who had shot him and that police had given him no warning he was in danger. Prosecutors say Gotti had ordered O'Connor shot for leading union goons to wreck a Manhattan restaurant affiliated with the Gambino crime family, which Gotti reputedly heads. They maintain that a secretly recorded tape shows Gotti saying O'Connor was to be ``busted up.'' The defense, arguing the tapes are largely inaudible, said that if the comment was clear enough to prosecute Gotti then it was clear enough to warn O'Connor. Gotti, 49, and Anthony Guerrieri, 60, an alleged Gambino soldier, are on trial in Manhattan's state Supreme Court on charges of assault and conspiracy in the O'Connor shooting. Under questioning by defense lawyer Gerald Shargel, O'Connor detailed the near-fatal shooting of May 7, 1986. O'Connor, 56, said he noticed four or five men hanging around outside the offices of his union local when he arrived at work. While waiting in the lobby for an elevator, O'Connor testified he heard ``a thunderous clap'' and felt something in his body, but did not realize he had been shot. A man shouted ``Mr. O'Connor, Mr. O'Connor.'' When he turned, O'Connor saw a man pointing a gun at him. The elevator arrived, and O'Connor said he got on as the gunman fired into his buttocks. O'Connor said he got off on the seventh floor when he sought help from an acquaintance. Dr. Jose Corvalan, the surgeon who treated O'Connor at St. Clair's Hospital, said the victim would have died without prompt medical treatment. O'Connor said that, in viewing police photos, he was never able to identify any of the men he saw outside his office the day he was shot. He said he initially told police that union trouble had nothing to do with the incident, but admitted in testimony that there were internal problems in the union. The defense argued that O'Connor's enemies in his union might have shot him because of internecine rivalries. Prosecutors, who rested their case Thursday, called O'Connor _ former vice president of Carpenters' Union Local 608 _ a corrupt mob associate who has been charged in a 127-count indictment with perjury, extortion, and labor racketeering. Cross-examined by Assistant District Attorney Michael Cherkasky, O'Connor asserted his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination when asked about his alleged links to organized crime. O'Connor took the stand after Acting Justice Edward McLaughlin denied a defense motion to dismiss the case. Shortly after O'Connor testified, the defense rested. The trial is recessed until Monday when final arguments are expected.

DOC.HEAD: Entertainer Roseanne Barr Reports Love Letters Stolen
DOC.TEXT: Love letters written by actress Roseanne Barr to Tom Arnold, her newlywed husband, have been stolen and are being offered for sale to various periodicals, a publicist said. ``Our purpose in sending the (announcement) out is to notify people that these letters are stolen,'' publicist Alana Rothstein said Friday. ``We're saying, `yes it is for real, and yes they are stolen, and if somebody decides to publish them, then down the road they'll have to deal with the repercussions.''' Barr's public relations firm had received inquiries from several publishers who had been contacted by someone who was offering to sell the letters. Rothstein said she didn't know how exactly how many letters were stolen, or when. She said at least several letters were stolen sometime within the last three weeks. Asked if the theft had been reported to police, Rothstein said it was a legal matter and was being handled by Miss Barr's attorneys.

DOC.HEAD: President Surprised Critics With Dramatic Reforms
With PM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Until a year ago, F.W. De Klerk was a low-key politician viewed as cautious, pragmatic and relatively conservative. Now, the president is being called courageous even by anti-apartheid militants who spent years in jail. De Klerk was raised in a culture that accepted white domination as God's will. His father was in the Cabinet when African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela went to jail in 1962. On Friday, before a national television audience, de Klerk announced that Mandela would soon be freed unconditionally and that his guerrilla movement was no longer banned. ``In a matter of just over half an hour, Mr. de Klerk has set in motion a process of peaceful revolution that will undo four decades of doctrinaire National Party policies that have spelt misery for millions,'' said the Rev. Stanley Mogoba, head of the country's Methodist Church. Mogoba spent three years in prison in the 1960s for membership in the Pan Africanist Congress, another black-led guerrilla group legalized by de Klerk in hopes of promoting black-white negotiations. De Klerk was education minister in Botha's Cabinet. Botha suffered a stroke Jan. 18, 1989, and Feb. 2 _ exactly a year before Friday's speech _ de Klerk took over as National Party leader, narrowly defeating a Cabinet colleague who at the time was considered more liberal. Botha resigned in August after losing a power struggle with the Cabinet, and de Klerk became acting president. He was formally inaugurated to a five-year term Sept. 20, following general elections, and told the country: ``We stand on the threshold of a new era in South Africa.'' Now, even doubters are beginning to believe him. ``We would be unreasonable if we fail to acknowledge that of all the presidents, of all the leaders of the Nationalist governments, de Klerk has taken the most bold step, and has has emerged as the most courageous,'' said black activist Pope Molefe. Molefe, a leader of the United Democratic Front anti-apartheid coalition, was freed in December after more than four years in jail when the appellate court overturned a treason conviction. De Klerk, 53, comes from a long line of politicans going back to his great-grandfather, a senator. His brother, Willem, quit as editor of Rapport, the country's largest Afrikaans-language newspaper, after being criticized for his increasingly liberal views. The Dutch-descended Afrikaners began settling South Africa 350 years ago and account for 3 million of the country's 5 million whites. They are taught in state schools that role as rulers was ordained by God. Until a few years ago, the main Afrikaner church preached that the ideological foundation for apartheid was found in the Bible. When F.W. de Klerk took office, Willem de Klerk expressed uncertainty as to whether significant reforms would follow. But de Klerk moved rapidly _ even before his inauguration he gave approval for the first legal anti-government marches in decades. Since then, de Klerk has freed eight prominent political prisoners, including colleagues of Mandela; declared an end to segregation of beaches; consulted with Mandela and many anti-apartheid leaders, and cut back the power and influence of the security establishment. He halved mandatory military service for white men from two years to one, cut the defense budget, and scrapped a controversial bureaucratic network through which security force officers exercised control over black townships. All these moves paled compared to Friday's pronouncements. Publisher Tertius Myburgh, whose Sunday Times is the country's largest newspaper, called it the most important speech of the century in South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Genscher Says Baker Agrees Greater Germany Doesn't Mean Greater NATO
DOC.TEXT: West Germany's foreign minister says he and U.S. Secretary of State James Baker agree that a unified Germany will not mean a greater NATO military umbrella. Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, who met with Baker late Friday at the State Department, said afterward, ``We were in full agreement that there is no intention to extend the NATO area of defensive security toward the East.'' Genscher, who was returning to Europe during the night, crossed the Atlantic and back in less than 24 hours to consult with Baker before the Secretary of State's meetings next week with Soviet leaders in Moscow. German unity was expected to be a major issue Baker will take up with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and President Mikhail Gorbachev. Both Genscher and Baker said they agreed that if a 35-nation European summit Gorbachev has proposed for next autumn is held, it should add the right of free elections to other human rights enumerated at the original summit on cooperation and security in Europe, held at Helsinki in 1972. Genscher suggested the autumn summit could set the stage for major steps toward German unification. Unlike Helsinki, ``the two German states at this summit will come not with diverging views but _ as I hope _ with a joint concept,'' he said. Genscher's whirlwind visit came after Gorbachev softened his opposition to German unification over the past week. East German Prime Minister Hans Modrow also endorsed creation of a single Germany, providing it belongs neither to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization nor to the Warsaw Pact. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government has opposed military neutrality for a unified Germany. Baker also indirectly rejected the idea, telling reporters Friday, ``I'm frankly encouraged'' by what Genscher has said about continued German membership in NATO. Western allied governments, remembering the struggle against Nazi Germany in World War II, have long considered West Germany's membership in NATO and the European Community more effective than neutrality in deterring any revival of German expansionism. Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary, after ending 40 years of communist rule, have asked the Kremlin to withdraw its military forces from their soil, drawing predictions the Warsaw Pact will collapse. Genscher said the West can offer East European countries ``partnership in stability.'' ``We can make it quite clear to the East that whatever happens in the Warsaw pact, on our side there is no intention to extend our area, NATO's area, toward the East,'' he said. Baker said he and Genscher ``agreed we need to develop a process and a framework for it (reunification), taking into consideration the interests of all who are involved in the issue.'' Genscher said that after East Germany's promised March 18 free elections, ``we are going to enter into negotiations with that freely-elected government about the future of the two German states. ``And we are convinced that the freely-elected government of the (East German) GDR, will just as ourselves, want to see the process of a unity be imbedded in the process of European unity,'' he added, suggesting major agreement could be reached by the autumn summit. Baker planned to meet French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas in Ireland on Tuesday before flying on to Prague for one day of talks with Czechoslovakia's new leaders. From there he'll continue on to Moscow. Genscher also planned to meet Shevardnadze next week.

DOC.HEAD: Campaign Launched For Vote That Could Reshape Japan's Government
DOC.TEXT: More than 900 candidates hit a frosty campaign trail today, officially launching a race that will provide the first serious challenge to the conservative Liberal Democrats in decades. The candidates, including Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of the Liberal Democrats and Takako Doi of the Japan Socialist Party, came out in bitter cold to lure voters to their parties in the Feb. 18 vote for parliament's lower house. Polls show the Liberal Democrats could lose their majority in the powerful chamber, partly because of an unpopular 3 percent sales tax and partly because of scandals that have soiled the party's image over the past year. The party has controlled Japan's government for 34 years. The contenders have been conducting unauthorized stumping for months. But they intensified their efforts today with speeches at major train stations as the official two-week campaign got under way. Kaifu, 59, addressed about 200 people at Shibuya station in Tokyo. Most of his audience, toting Japan's red-and-white flags, appeared to be party members invited to the rally, with passersby lingering in the near-freezing temperatures only until traffic lights changed. Sounding his major theme, Kaifu declared that the election is a ``critical one that will determine whether the nation will give credit to the Liberal Democrats for their efforts or give power away to socialism.'' The Socialists are the largest opposition party. ``My administration started out under the worst possible circumstances,'' Kaifu said. ``I need your support.'' Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita resigned in April because of a stock-profiteering scandal. His successor, Sousuke Uno, lasted only two months after allegations surfaced that he kept paid mistresses. The Liberal Democrats lost their majority in the upper house of Parliament in July. At Shinjuku station in Tokyo, about 400 police guarded the Socialists' kickoff rally. Ms. Doi, 61, told about 1,000 people that ``the only road left is for each of you to change politics with your votes.'' Flanked by waving girls in bright blazers and short skirts, Ms. Doi reiterated her opposition to the sales tax and to recent moves to open Japan's agricultural markets to imports. Those stands were popular in the July election. Another key issue in the election is expected to be calls for political reform prompted by the stock scandal. ``I don't really understand the differences in policies, but I'm supporting the Socialists because I think it's time someone else took over government,'' said one 22-year-old woman who refused to give her name. ``Also, Doi is a woman, and I feel she wouldn't lie to me like those men do,'' she said. A total of 931 candidates are expected to register their candidacy for the 512-seat lower house, Kyodo News Service reported. Newspapers gave mixed reviews to Friday's debate between Kaifu, Ms. Doi and three other party leaders, the first major televised debate since 1960, saying the party leaders avoided the substantive issues. The leaders ``failed to provide substantial new information for the voters,'' said the English-language Japan Times. It attacked Kaifu's campaign theme of warning voters that a vote for the opposition would endanger their democratic freedoms, calling it ``scare tactics.'' The mass-circulation Yomiuri Shimbun criticized the four opposition leaders, saying they ``offered no image of what that political authority ought to be.''

DOC.HEAD: Washington State Wants to Kill Troublesome Sea Lions
DOC.TEXT: Hungry sea lions are beginning to fatten up on the prized and protected steelhead trout, driving state authorities to a drastic plan to end the free lunch: They want to kill the blubbery creatures. The easy pickings at the Ballard Locks have led wildlife officials to try a number of remedies to get rid of the sea lions as the state-protected steelhead begin their annual run. As many as 40 sea lions have gathered near the locks inside city limits each winter for the past eight years to eat the trout, which climb a fish ladder on their way from Puget Sound to freshwater Lake Union, en route to upstream spawning grounds. The sea lions weigh up to 800 pounds, and they can eat 5 percent of their body weight in fish each day. One option is a plan by state and federal officials to truck 10 male sea lions to their breeding grounds off Southern California and harass the remainder with firecrackers, rubber-tipped arrows and fish laced with ``vomit capsules.'' Another plan would be to alter the structure of the locks, a possibility under preliminary discussion with the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, said Curt Smitch, director of the state Department of Wildlife. But Smitch noted Friday that wildlife agents have tried just about all the non-lethal actions they can think of. ``We would like to have access to that option,'' he said of the proposal to kill. ``We think that we are trying to protect a resource, which is Washington's wild steelhead.'' Federal officials say they're researching the question of whether sea lions protected under federal law can be killed if they threaten to destroy the state-protected wild steelhead run, which generally lasts from late February to April. A period of public comment is expected to begin by the next month, Rolland Schmitten, Northwest regional director of the National Marine Fisheries Service, said Friday. Representatives of environmental and animal rights groups did not return calls for comment late Friday on the proposal to kill the sea lions, which were at the locks eating steelhead, said acting lockmaster Bill McGraw. Cynthia Rust, a spokeswoman for Greenpeace Action, said earlier Friday she lacked details to comment on the trucking plan, but she said the vomit capsules probably would not work. The sea lions weren't considered a problem until 1985, when they caught 30 percent of the wild fish run. Last year they gobbled up 65 percent, and at the current rate the run would disappear within a decade, Smitch said. This year, officials hope that more than a third of the approximately 2,100 fish will survive to spawn. In past years, wildlife officials have tried chasing the sea lions with boats, scaring them with firecrackers and taped sounds of orca whales, their natural predator, feeding them chemical-laced fish and keeping them from the fish with nets. Nothing worked. The sea lions managed to have their feast last year even though 37 of them were trucked 270 miles to the southern Washington coast. Within an average of 12 days, 29 had returned to the locks _ in time to eat steelhead. Washington state sent a letter last fall asking the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, which enforces the Marine Mammal Protection Act, for a ruling on whether killing sea lions might be permitted. A federal ruling should be made by the end of this year after the public comment period, in time for next year's steelhead run, Schmitten said. In the next few weeks, wildlife agents plan to corral 10 sea lions and haul them at a cost of about $15,000 to breeding grounds in the Channel Islands, northwest of Los Angeles.
