Authorities hope the sea lions will stay there, or at least take 45 days to swim the 1,100 miles back to Seattle. That would give the fish enough time to get to the spawning grounds, Smitch said. The sea lions will be tagged with radio transmitters to track their movements and monitor whether the effort has been effective, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Poland Sees First Signs of Unemployment Under Economic Reform
DOC.TEXT: The rate of unemployment soared nearly 600 percent last month after the Solidarity-led government imposed a host of market-oriented economic reforms. At the same time, prices rose by almost 70 percent, compared to government projections of 50 percent, Finance Ministry Undersecretary Andrzej Podsiadlo told a news conference Friday. The number of unemployed people registered with the government grew from 9,600 in December to 55,800 in January, said government spokeswoman Malgorzata Niezabitowska. The number of job vacancies fell from 254,000 in late 1989 to 35,200 in January, she said. The Solidarity-led government, anticipating the first postwar wave of unemployment, has set aside funds to provide social benefits to up to 400,000 jobless people. However, critics of the plan have said the number of unemployed could go much higher. The steepest price rises came at the beginning of the month, when the government loosened controls on almost all goods and increased the price of energy by up to 700 percent, Podsiadlo said. But most producers, faced with a sharp decline in purchases, had to begin reducing prices by the end of the month, he said. The government hopes that by mid-year, prices will be rising by only 1 or 2 percent a month, he said. The government's economic shock treatment calls for a tight money policy limiting state subsidies and bank loans, limits on wage growth, and the loosening of price controls. The program, approved by the International Monetary Fund, is designed to quickly bring Poland's 1989 annual inflation rate of 700 percent under control by limiting the amount of money consumers have to spend. It is also supposed to drive inefficient companies into bankruptcy. The Solidarity-led government took over in September of last year after the opposition scored an overwhelming victory over Communist candidates in June elections.

DOC.HEAD: Factory Closes; Detroit Left With One Auto Assembly Plant
DOC.TEXT: Motor City was down to its last auto assembly plant with the closing of Chrysler Corp's Jefferson Avenue factory. After 83 years and about 8.3 million cars, the plant on Detroit's lower east side closed Friday. It had been the nation's oldest active auto factory. Its last car was a gray Dodge Omni with a gray interior. ``The days are gone forever when you didn't even have to graduate from high school before you went down to Dodge or Ford or Chrysler or GM and got a job,'' said Jesse Sandifer, 47, a pipe fitter. ``We were fortunate enough to be the last of a dying breed. Now you must have an education in order to succeed in life.'' The last full assembly plant in Detroit is General Motors Corp.'s Poletown plant. Several other factories in the city manufacture auto parts. Some of the 1,700 workers being laid off indefinitely hope they will go back to work in late 1991 at the Chrysler's planned Jefferson North plant, which will be built next to the closed factory. Ralph Winchester of Warren, who worked at the plant for a quarter-century, said he was unsure of his plans. ``I'm just going to get settled and see what happens,'' he said. Winchester said he hopes that he'll be recalled late next year, when Chrysler begins training workers for its Jefferson North plant, where the company hopes to build a sport-utility vehicle by late 1992. But, he added, ``I didn't get any guarantees.'' Harry Anderson, who also closed out 25 years with Chrysler on Friday, said he wasn't counting on work at the Jefferson North plant. He went through another closing in January 1980, when Chrysler shut down its Dodge Main plant, and he said he's had enough of layoffs. ``I'm going to school for robotics and TV and radio repair,'' Anderson said. The laid-off workers can draw from a variety of funds that could bring benefits to as much as 95 percent of their straight-time pay while they were working. Officials of United Auto Workers union Local 7, which represents the Jefferson Avenue workers, doubt if the funds will stay at that level until retraining for Jefferson North begins. They said layoffs the automaker already has announced for later this year will boost the number of eligible workers _ those on indefinite layoff _ drawing against the funds. Between now and the end of March, Chrysler plans to indefinitely lay off nearly 6,000 workers. ``All of us in America have got to turn this thing around,'' said Larry Gorzelski, a tool room supervisor at Jefferson Avenue. ``We're losing all our jobs, and pretty soon this will be just a service industry.'' Jefferson Avenue is the second plant Chrysler has shut down since 1988. On Thursday, the company announced it would close its St. Louis car plant in mid-September. That closing will bring to seven the number of assembly plants Chrysler and General Motors Corp. will have shut down in three years. Ford Motor Co. has been able to avoid closing plants because its car and truck sales are healthy and it can eliminate large amounts of overtime it used instead of opening a new plant.

DOC.HEAD: Regents Keep ROTC but Order Lobbying of Congress
DOC.TEXT: The Board of Regents allowed ROTC to stay at the University of Wisconsin after the school's faculty said it wanted them off because of the military's restrictions against homosexuals. The board decided 13-3 Friday to accept UW President Kenneth Shaw's recommendation against evicting the Reserve Officers Training Corps. But regents also approved a resolution that requires UW administrators to report annually on their efforts to lobby Congress for a change in the military's restrictions against enlisting gays and lesbians. ``We intend to hold their feet to the fire,'' Regent Ruth Clusen said. ``Writing letters isn't going to get us anywhere.'' ``I think it was the appropriate resolution to pass,'' Regent Erroll Davis Jr. of Madison said. ``This resolution keeps the issue in the front line and will force us to deal with it.'' Capt. Cheryl Batterman, head of UW recruiting for the Air Force ROTC, said she was pleased the regents decided to keep ROTC. But she said the resolution makes the situation seem uncertain and may discourage enrollment. ``We're already feeling the pinch,'' Ms. Batterman said. ``I had hoped they would've gotten this all resolved at once. Now, we still don't know what might happen. That's a hard plan to sell to students and parents.'' The faculty senate voted 386-248 in December in favor of evicting ROTC unless the military agreed by 1993 to enlist gays and lesbians. About 200 people rallied at the campus earlier this week, arguing it was unfair to make a student pay tuition for ROTC courses and then deny him enlistment. Shaw said severing ties with ROTC probably wouldn't influence the military. Canceling the courses would only harm the students who benefit from the classes, he said. There are about 440 students in Army, Navy and Air Force ROTC programs at Madison out of an enrollment of 42,000. There are 1,300 ROTC students in the entire UW System, which has 135,000 students at 13 major campuses and several smaller centers.

DOC.HEAD: Disney World Raises Prices At Three Theme Parks
DOC.TEXT: For the seventh time in 5{ years, Walt Disney World says it's raising the price at three theme parks. The prices will increase on Feb. 11 an average of 5 percent to help pay for several new attractions, Disney spokesman John Dreyer said Friday. ``We believe we are giving greater value to our guests and they believe they are getting increased entertainment,'' said Dreyer, pointing to the new ``Star Tours'' attraction at the Disney-MGM Studios and ``Body Wars'' at Epcot Center. Disney last raised prices on May 1 to accompany the opening of its $500-million Disney-MGM Studios, its third major park.

DOC.HEAD: Fleeing Christians Say Beirut Fighting Is Worst of Civil War
With PM-Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: Passengers arriving today on the ferry from Lebanon's Christian enclave said the battles raging between Christian factions are inflicting more damage on Beirut than any others in 15 years of civil war. ``We never had a war like this,'' said 24-year-old Robin Haik. Like most of the 40 passengers on the boat, Haik was fleeing the fighting that police say has killed at least 140 people and wounded 550 since it broke out Tuesday. Haik said he took advantage of a lull in the fighting to escape brutal exchanges in Beirut's Ashrafiyeh district. Hundreds of shells fell near his apartment building, he said. ``The Lebanese Forces put all kinds of artillery between every house to try to get the army, and the army tried to hit them with all kinds of shells.'' The fighting pits Christian Gen. Michel Aoun's troops against the Lebanese Forces, the main Christian militia headed by Samir Geagea. Traffic on the coastal highway from Ashrafiyeh to the Christian port at Jounieh, north of Beirut, was reduced because of sniper fire and checkpoints set up by the opposing forces, Haik said. He said he had seen a car lying on the road with four dead bodies in it. Crewmembers on the ferry Baroness said 200 burned cars littered the parking lot at the port, evidence of the struggle for control of the tiny naval facility held by Geagea's militia. ``One street is controlled by the army, the next by the Lebanese forces. It's terrible,'' said crewmember Elie, who like his colleagues wanted only his first name used. The ferry normally docks for several hours in Jounieh, but today it stayed only a half hour before leaving on the seven-hour, 125-mile trip to Larnaca on southeastern Cyprus. Passengers said the sound of gunfire and rockets thundered across the port. ``It was very bad. There were bombs, rockets. The crewmembers were afraid, and so were the passengers,'' said Chief Officer Demetris Asnasis. Most of those who made it onto the boat live in Jounieh and its immediate surroundings. ``Our house is just two minutes from the port. That's how we were able to get out,'' said Tony Helou, another passenger. ``We don't want to go back again,'' said his wife, Susan. Aoun's forces attacked on Tuesday to try to gain full control of the enclave north and east of Beirut where 1 million Christians live. Geagea has 6,000 militiamen bolstered by several thousand reservists. Aoun comands 20,000 soldiers. Aoun was fired by Moslem President Elias Hrawi, who was elected in November under the terms of an Arab League-brokered peace plan aimed at shifting political power to the Moslem majority and ending a 15-year-old civil war. The war has left 150,000 people dead. Aoun says the peace plan, approved by Parliament in October, provides no fixed withdrawal timetable for Syria's estimated 45,000 troops. Geagea has neither accepted or rejected the peace accord, but has recognized Hrawi as president.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer Sentenced to 12 Years in Prison
DOC.TEXT: Attorney Barry Kane was sentenced to 12 years in federal prison and fined $500,000 after being convicted of making two cocaine flights for Colombian drug baron Carlos Lehder Rivas. Kane, 53, of Hyannis, Mass., was convicted in October in the so-called ``Son of Lehder'' trial of conspiracy to import cocaine into the United States. He made two 250-kilogram cocaine flights from Colombia for Lehder in 1977. U.S. District Judge John H. Moore II, who could have sentenced Kane to 19 to 24 years under sentencing guidelines Friday, said he gave the lesser sentence out of ``downright fairness.'' As Kane was led out of the courtroom in shackles, his daughter Jennifer, who had testified in his behalf, yelled, ``I love you, Dad!'' In a statement to Moore on Friday, Kane said that his life had been destroyed, his career ruined and his family vilified and devastated. ``I am sorry for having caused all of this. Hasn't there been enough retribution? I pray your honor that there has been,'' Kane said, his voice cracking. Three of Kane's sons and his daughter asked the judge for leniency. ``There is nothing left to be taken. Everything is gone,'' said his son Barry Stephen Kane, 30. ``I don't believe he's an evil man. He's a man who made some mistakes. I'm begging for mercy.'' Kane, who collapsed when he was convicted Oct. 26, seemed at times to be shaky Friday. The case grew out of testimony in the 1987-88 trial of Lehder, 40, who is serving a life term plus 135 years for directing the smuggling of some 20 tons of cocaine into the United States. Ten defendants have pleaded guilty and received sentences ranging from six months to 10 years.

DOC.HEAD: Population Growth Rate up Slightly in 1989
DOC.TEXT: China added another 15.77 million people last year to bring its population to 1.112 billion, according to the State Statistical Bureau. The bureau's figures, reported today by the official People's Daily, said the natural population increase for the year was 14.33 per 1,000 people, up slightly from 14.2 per 1,000 in 1988. It said there were 20.83 births per 1,000, up from 20.78 in 1988, and 6.5 deaths per 1,000, a slight decline from the previous year. The world's most populous nation in the past decade has achieved one of the lowest growth rates in the developing world _ the rate is 20 per thousand in India and 28 in the Philippines _ as a result of strict family planning policies limiting most families to one child. However, the natural growth rate has moved up again somewhat in recent years because of resistance to the one-child policy in rural areas and a sharp increase in the number of women reaching childbearing age. Between 1986 and 1997, another 11 million to 13 million women will reach childbearing age every year, a consequence of high birth rates in the 1960s and 1970s when communist China's revolutionary founder Mao Tse-tung paid little attention to family planning. China had hoped to keep its population down to 1.2 billion at the end of the century, but demographers now say it will be closer to 1.3 billion, about one-fifth of the world's people. ``From the viewpoint of age structure, our country will continue to see a rising birth rate trend for the next few years,'' the report said. ``Family planning work cannot be relaxed by even an iota.''

DOC.HEAD: Source: Pilot's `Emergency' Not Relayed by Co-pilot
DOC.TEXT: The pilot of Avianca Flight 52 asked his co-pilot if he had told the control tower that they had an ``emergency'' shortly before the jet crashed on Long Island, a source close to the crash investigation said. Co-pilot Mauricio Klotz did not directly answer Capt. Laureano Caviedes Hoyos' question, saying ``I told them we're low on fuel,'' the source, who asked not be identified, told The Associated Press. Investigators have pointed to the crew's use of the word ``priority,'' instead of ``emergency,'' in conversations with controllers in explaining the handling of the Boeing 707. When a pilot declares a fuel ``emergency'' to controllers, the plane is cleared to land immediately. That doesn't happen when the word ``priority'' is used. Friday's disclosure was the first indication that a crew member used the word ``emergency'' in describing their situation. Cockpit tapes show that the crew never told air traffic controllers they had an emergency, investigators say. The plane glided powerless into a hillside on Long Island's north shore Jan. 25, killing 73 of the 159 people aboard, including the cockpit crew. The investigation has focused on the conversations between controllers and crew in the final leg of its flight from Bogota and Medellin, Colombia. After nearly an hour and a half of delays, the crew told regional controllers the plane was low on fuel and needed priority handling. The plane was then put in the hands of local controllers. The flight was handled in a routine manner on its first approach, which was aborted in wind and fog. It was then told to loop back over Long Island to try again _ another routine direction, which was OK'd by the crew. It was during this loop that the engines quit and the plane crashed. The cockpit conversations shifted back and forth between English and Spanish, according to the source, who quoted an unofficial translation. Less than five minutes after the missed approach, Caviedes, 56, asked Klotz, ``Did you tell them we have an emergency?'' Klotz, 28, replied: ``I told them we're low on fuel.'' After the exchange, the talk turned to a brisk but businesslike discuss of altitude, control positions and other normal landing routine, the source said. Fred Farrar, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration, said he was not familiar with the internal cockpit conversation and therefore could not comment on whether the pilot used the word ``emergency.''

DOC.HEAD: Snow, Sleet, Rain from Texas to Northeast
DOC.TEXT: More snow, sleet and freezing rain were expected from northern Texas to New England this weekend as a slow-moving storm system moved northeast from the southern Plains. Low pressure over the Texas panhandle extended to the Mississippi Valley while cold high pressure over the Ontario-Quebec border edged into the Northern Plains. Freezing rain has been a factor in 10 traffic deaths in Kansas and Missouri since Thursday, and roads in both states continued to be slick today. Missouri braced for another 2 to 4 inches of snow, perhaps mixed with freezing rain or sleet, through Sunday morning. Up to 6 inches of snow was forecast across parts of central and eastern Kansas by today. Snow fell at the rate of an inch per hour in some parts of New York on Friday. About 6 inches fell in Syracuse, and 5.8 inches in Buffalo was accompanied by an unexpected blast of cold air. Another 6 inches is possible by Sunday. Thunderstorms produced hail the size of marbles Friday evening south of Rye, Ark. Chinook winds blowing at 30 to 50 mph caused travel problems across north-central Montana by whipping up blowing, drifting snow, and blizzard conditions prevailed in parts of the state. On the West Coast, a cold front moving inland was expected to soak western Oregon into central California today. Cold, dry air from Canada should chill northern New England temperatures to well below zero. The Southeast enjoyed record high temperatures for Groundhog Day in Washington, D.C., with 72 degrees; Huntsville, Ala., 73; Augusta, Ga., 79; Jackson, Miss., and Meridian, Miss., 81; and Fort Myers, Fla., 88 _ the nation's high. Other reports at 4 a.m. EST today: _EAST: Albany, N.Y., 14 cloudy; Atlanta 63 foggy; Boston 30 cloudy; Buffalo 17; Charleston, S.C., 63 fair; Chattanooga 56 foggy; Cincinnati 38 drizzle; Cleveland 29 cloudy; Detroit 24 foggy; Hatteras 63 fair; Jacksonville 61 foggy; Key West 77 windy; Knoxville 52 foggy; Macon 58 foggy; Miami 75 fair; New York 38 cloudy; Philadelphia 44 foggy; Pittsburgh 29 foggy; Portland, Maine, 20 partly cloudy; Richmond 50 foggy; Tampa 66 fair; Washington, D.C. 47 foggy. _CENTRAL: Birmingham 67 foggy; Bismarck 3 fair; Chicago 32 foggy; Denver 16 fair; Des Moines 26 freezing drizzle; Fort Worth 46; Indianapolis 36 foggy; Kansas City 27; Louisville 47 drizzle; Memphis 60 showers; Nashville 56 showers; New Orleans 70 foggy; North Platte 15 fair; Oklahoma City 31 rain; Omaha 20 snow; Rapid City 20 fair; St. Louis 41 foggy; Minneapolis-St. Paul 20 snow; Sault Ste. Marie 3 fair; San Antonio 60 cloudy. _WEST: Albuquerque 28 partly cloudy; Anchorage 9 fair; Boise 32 fair; Casper 20 fair; Fairbanks 36 fair; Great Falls 35 windy; Honolulu 73 partly cloudy; Las Vegas 35 fair; Los Angeles 51 fair; Medford 34 foggy; Pendleton 49 cloudy; Phoenix 44 fair; Portland, Ore., 44 cloudy; Reno 28 partly cloudy; Salt Lake City 29 cloudy; San Diego 47 fair; San Francisco 45 cloudy; Seattle 49 windy; Spokane 36 cloudy. _INTERNATIONAL: Calgary 37 partly cloudy; Montreal 1 fair; Ottawa 0 fair; Regina 0 fair; Toronto 16 cloudy; Winnipeg 3 fair; Merida 73; San Juan 72.

DOC.HEAD: Incumbent Favored to Win Second Term
DOC.TEXT: Voters cast ballots today in an election pitting Mayor Sidney Barthelemy against a challenger who has accused him of race-baiting. Barthelemy, New Orleans' second black mayor, is running for a second term. His main challenger is Donald Mintz, a white attorney who wears a lapel button showing white and black hands interlinked. Mintz, 46, who left New Orleans' dock board to make his first run for elective office, claimed Barthelemy's ads on a black radio station appealed to anti-white racism. Barthelemy, 47, said it was Mintz who interjected the issue of race during the campaign, which also included anonymous fliers depicting Barthelemy as an opportunistic Uncle Tom. Barthelemy predicted that he will win by about 10 percentage points _ slightly below the margin shown in recent polls. ``I think without question that the vast majority of black voters are going to vote for me and the vast majority of white voters are going to vote for Mintz,'' he said Friday. ``There'll be some crossover. I think I'll get more crossover votes than he will.'' About 54.4 percent of the city's voters are black and 44.4 percent white, with Asians making up most of the rest. About 55 to 60 percent of the city's 237,342 voters are expected to turn out for the election, said Registrar Louis Keller. The ballot also includes races for five City Council seats and nine other city offices. The low-key election campaign has been upstaged by the Christmas holidays, the Sugar Bowl and the Super Bowl. Even the issue of race, which sparked the two televised debates, did little to enliven the campaign. Early polls put Mintz ahead of Barthelemy, even though Mintz has no government experience. But Barthelemy, a former state senator and city councilman, has drawn ahead by 10 to 12 percentage points in recent polls. Also running are Herman J. ``Buster'' Bustamente and black businessman Rudy E. Mills Sr., who are expected to draw few votes. If no candidate gets more than half the vote, a runoff will be held March 3.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``In a matter of just over half an hour, Mr. de Klerk has set in motion a process of peaceful revolution that will undo four decades of doctrinaire National Party policies that have spelt misery for millions.'' _ The Rev. Stanley Mogoba, head of South Africa's Methodist Church, on President F.W. de Klerk's announcements that jailed activist Nelson Mandela would soon be freed and that his guerrilla movement was no longer banned.

``The war is by no means over, but it is clearly winnable and the momentum, I think, is shifting our way.'' _ William Bennett, national drug policy director, telling the Senate Judiciary Committee that the government is winning the war against narcotics.

``I wanted to invite him a long time ago when I was not yet a president. I want to meditate with him. If the Chinese republic is not satisfied with this explanation, I am sorry.'' _ Vaclav Havel, Czechoslovakia's playwright-president, on the five-day visit of the Nobel Peace Prize-winning Dalai Lama, who champions autonomy for Chinese-ruled Tibet. China criticized the visit.

DOC.HEAD: Mail Bomb Investigation Shifts to Printing Shop Owner
DOC.TEXT: The FBI shifted part of its investigation of the mail bombings that killed a federal judge and a civil rights attorney to an operator of a print shop and his wife. Blood, hair and saliva samples will be taken from Brian Joseph Fleming and his wife, Georgia, their attorney said. The FBI seized documents filling nine boxes Friday at Fleming's home, but his attorney, John Knowles, said they were ``nothing really important'' to the mail bomb probe. ``No typewriters in the septic tank,'' the attorney said. In the last two weeks, agents have canvassed Enterprise, a southeastern Alabama community of 18,000 residents, and the surrounding area _ even digging up septic tanks _ for a typewriter believed used by the bomber. Killed in the December bomb attacks were 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals Judge Robert Vance and Savannah, Ga., attorney Robert Robinson. No one has been charged in the case. Another 10 boxes of material were removed from Fleming's business, the Printing Press, located across the street from the FBI's temporary command post. Fleming, 32, just shrugged when asked why the agents wanted the material. The agents maintained their silence on the case. Knowles said the government apparently was trying to link the mail bomb case to Fleming's indictment on a charge of conspiring to export firearms, reportedly to Northern Ireland. Fleming pleaded innocent to the gun exportation charge and is free on $5,000 bond. The Fleming searches drew attention away from salvage dealer Robert Wayne O'Ferrell, a part-time preacher who has been at the center of the FBI investigation. Last month, O'Ferrell's home and business were subjected to similar FBI searches. Doug Marshall, an FBI spokesman in Mobile, said the FBI would continue to make Enterprise the base of its mail bomb investigation for an indefinite time. Meanwhile, in Houston, an apparently unrelated mail bomb that injured a pastor's daughter on Tuesday was mailed from Elizabethtown, N.C., a federal postal inspector said. List Osteen, 31, suffered bruises and flash burns and was in good condition Friday at Methodist Hospital in Houston.

DOC.HEAD: Regulators Seize Thrift; Good News For Two Large Savings Institutions
DOC.TEXT: The state comptroller said the federal takeover of Florida's largest thrift is in the taxpayers' best interests, but some analysts say the government dragged its feet in seizing the financially troubled CenTrust Bank. The Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision Friday declared that the savings and loan was operating in an unsafe and unsound condition and turned it over to the Resolution Trust Corp. for sale or liquidation. The seizure, which had been imminent for some time, came as two large savings institutions in Texas and California showed signs of recovery with the help of federal subsidies. But two other Florida banks also were seized Friday. Federal investigators fanned out through Centrust's towering Miami headquarters on Friday, making sure employees left the building without taking any documents. CenTrust's offices remain open for business with deposits guaranteed to $100,000 per account. The institution had $6.2 billion in 325,813 accounts and was not insolvent, federal regulators said, but would soon be if changes were not made. CenTrust's failure was blamed on junk bond investing and lavish spending on art, a company yacht and high salaries. Since December, the thrift was losing an estimated $2 million a day, analysts said. ``The big question is why the OTC didn't act sooner,'' said Miami thrift analyst Kenneth Thomas, who contended having seized the bank in December would have saved taxpayers millions of dollars. ``It's inexcusable. Basically (CenTrust Chairman) David Paul gouged his thumb into the (thrift office's) eye and kept it there,'' said Bert Ely, a financial institutions analyst in Alexandria, Va. But thrift office enforcement director Rosemary Stewart said, ``We don't think this took long at all. ... Proof that this institution was in serious enough financial condition to warrant a takeover was just recently obtained.'' A CenTrust spokesman did not immediately return telephone messages seeking comment Friday and a man who answered a phone at Paul's Miami Beach office also declined to comment. ``This is not an action you like to take, but it is one we thought was in the best interests of the depositors and taxpayers,'' said Florida Comptroller Gerald Lewis, whose office participated in Friday's action. ``This whole situation with the thrift industry is one that has to be turned around.'' Two banks seized by federal authorities indicated the industry can prosper. The Bright Banc Savings Association of Dallas, one of the nation's largest savings institutions, was sold for $48 million. And the American Savings Bank in California said it earned $214.2 million in 1989. In separate actions Friday, federal regulators also seized Pioneer Savings Bank in Clearwater, the state's 11th largest thrift, with $2 billion in assets; and state regulators closed Commerce Bank of Tampa, with $21 million in assets. CenTrust, with $8.2 billion in assets, is Florida's largest and the nation's 23rd largest savings institution. The thrift office, in announcing the takeover, said that as of Sept. 30 CenTrust was $245 million in the red. The agency also cited ``substantial dissipation of assets and earnings due to violations ... (including) excessive and inappropriate expenses and investments.'' In December, the thrift office issued a ``cease and desist'' order instructing CenTrust to sell what was left of its $30 million art collection, much of it displayed in Paul's home, plus limousines, a corporate jet and a $233,000 company sailboat.

DOC.HEAD: Move To Restart Peace Talks In El Salvador
DOC.NOTE: EDS: ADDS 5 grafs at end with info on Boston visit.
DOC.TEXT: Salvadoran President Alfredo Cristiani says he hopes to hear by Monday whether leftist guerillas will agree to talks brokered by the United Nations aimed at settling El Salvador's prolonged civil war. ``Our government is set on finding a political solution to the conflict,'' Cristiani said Friday. ``There is no use for a military solution. We are ready to sit down and discuss the incorporation of the FMLN in the democratic process.'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said Friday that Secretary of State James A. Baker III telephoned UN Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar to express support for U.N. efforts to restart negotiations. Cristiani, holding talks with U.S. officials in Washington, told the National Press Club that de Cuellar told him Wednesday he would immediately try to contact leftist FMLN rebels and get talks started. Cristiani said he hoped there would be an answer from the rebels by the time he returns to San Salvador on Monday. Ms. Tutwiler said President Bush and the secretary of state discussed the issue with Cristiani on Thursday. ``The United States strongly supports President Cristiani's efforts to enlist U.N. assistance in resuming negotiations,'' she said. Cristiani also appealed in his speech for continued U.S. aid to El Salvador. ``We believe for the first time in 10 years we have a great possibility of finding a solution to the Salvadoran conflict,'' he said. ``It would be a shame to give the extreme right and the extreme left a negative sign. Any change in the status of aid would be a negative sign.'' U.S. economic aid to El Salvador in the current fiscal year was cut by the Bush administration to $130.6 million from the previous year's $185 million. The administration has requested an increase to $180 million in economic aid to El Salvador for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. After leaving Washington, Cristiani made an unannounced visit to Boston Friday night, where he was met by demonstrators protesting the slaying of six Jesuit priests in his county last November, according to a published report. David Voisin, a spokesman for Central American Solidarity Association, told The Associated Press that Cristiani was planning to meet with Cardinal Bernard Law, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Boston, to try to smooth over strained relations between his government and the church. However, Law's press secretary, Monsignor Timothy Moran, said Cristiani had not contacted Law and no such meeting was scheduled. The Herald reported that a State Department spokesman would only say that Cristiani was in Boston for a ``private visit.'' Voisin said more protests were planned today.

DOC.HEAD: GE, Former Employees Guilty Of Defrauding Government
DOC.TEXT: A 2{-month trial has ended in guilty verdicts for General Electric Co. and two employees accused of bilking the government of $10 million on a battlefield computer system. The verdict Friday raised the possibility GE could be suspended from new Pentagon business, a step the government often takes against contractors accused of wrongdoing. The jury found GE, the nation's second-largest defense contractor, guilty of four counts of mail fraud and 282 counts of making false claims. It was acquitted of one mail fraud count and 30 other false claim counts. Gerald A. Leo, former materials manager of GE subsidiary Management and Technical Services Co., was convicted of four counts of mail fraud and one count of trying to deceive federal investigators. James Badolato, former subcontracts manager for the subsidiary, was convicted of one count of obstructing justice and one count of trying to deceive investigators. Leo, 52, faces up to 25 years in prison and a $1 million fine. Badolato, 43, faces up to 10 years in prison and a $500,000 fine. Both men now work in other GE departments. Both men were acquitted on separate mail fraud and racketeering charges. U.S. District Judge Lowell A. Reed Jr. allowed Leo and Badolato to remain free on bail pending sentencing scheduled for April 10. Attorneys for GE and Badolato said they would appeal. An attorney for Leo declined to comment on an appeal. The case involved a $250 million contract to supply the Army with an updated version of its Decentralized Automated Service Support System computer, known as DAS-3. Prosecutors claimed Leo and Badolato _ with the tacit consent of GE officials _ padded costs and failed to notify the Pentagon of savings negotiated with subcontractors. GE faces a fine of about $50 million, plus the costs of prosecution, Assistant U.S. Attorney David Howard said. In addition, the government has filed a $23 million civil suit against GE, alleging overcharges and seeking damages. GE said in a statement from its Fairfield, Conn., headquarters that its subsidiary had been ready since 1985 to settle the civil case. The indictments were issued in November 1988. Assistant U.S. Attorney Nicholas Harbist said the verdict ``sends a message that once a company engages in this kind of conduct, merely opening up their wallet isn't enough.'' But GE said the verdict ``stretches the theory of `vicarious corporate liability' beyond reasonable limits.'' Harbist said a decision on whether GE would be suspended from Pentagon contracts would rest with the secretary of the Army. Badolato's attorney, Greg Miller, said he was shocked with the verdict, but called his client's acquittal on racketeering charges a victory. It was GE's second defense-related fraud case in four years. In May 1985, the company pleaded guilty to illegally claiming $800,000 in cost overruns on Minuteman intercontinental ballistic missiles and paid a $1.04 million fine. GE receives approximately $6 billion annually for defense contracts ranging from jet engines and electronic warfare equipment to highly classified strategic work.

DOC.HEAD: Crash Survivor Possible Hit Man for Medellin Cartel
With PM-Jetliner Crash
DOC.TEXT: A survivor of the Avianca jet crash who had swallowed packets of cocaine before boarding the flight may be a hit man for the Medellin drug cartel, federal authorities said. FBI spokeswoman Lorraine Johnson said Friday the information on Antonio Zuluaga, 46, came from the Colombian government. She said a probe of the Colombian man would continue for several days. Zuluaga is being held on drug possession charges in the prison ward of the Nassau County Medical Center, where he is listed in satisfactory condition with back and arm injuries sustained in the Jan. 25 crash of Avianca 52. The crash killed 73 people and left 85 injured. Zuluaga was arraigned at his bedside on Tuesday on charges of criminal possession of a controlled substance, a charge punishable by up to 25 years to life in prison, said Assistant District Attorney Pamela Kelly-Pincus. Zuluaga has passed 29 condom-like bags containing eight ounces of what he identified as cocaine, she said. Also Friday, a widowed mother of three filed a $40 million lawsuit in New York City against Avianca for injuries she suffered in the crash. Maria Elsa Amado Gonzalez, 41, said in court papers that both her legs were broken, her right hip fractured and facial bones cracked. She had to undergo skin grafts and cosmetic surgery and will require more such operations in the future. On Tuesday, a man and his young son filed a $202.5 million negligence suit against the airline, in what apparently was the first lawsuit filed by survivors of the crash.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Chooses Moderate As Premier
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with details, Lukanov speech, reax from opposition, details; DELETES outdated material; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Parliament today chose a moderate reformer as Bulgaria's new premier, a day after the ruling Communist Party expelled much of its old guard and picked another advocate of change as its leader. The new premier, Politburo member Andrei Lukanov, promised immediate reforms in a speech after his unanimous election. The opposition, however, continued to reject a Communist offer to join a provisional government. On Friday, the Communist Party ended a watershed party congress by electing Alexander Lilov, a Politburo member, as its new chief. Lilov, 56, replaces Petar Mladenov, who will continue as president. Mladenov took over both jobs on Nov. 10 following the ouster of hard-line leader Todor Zhivkov's after 35 years in power. The Communist-dominated government of former premier Georgi Atanassov resigned late Thursday. It was not immediately clear which of the three leaders _ the premier, the party chief or the president _ would have the most substantive power in the new government. Lukanov, a 51-year-old economist who speaks several languages, became the third moderate Communist reformer in the upper echelon of the crisis-ridden party, which is struggling to remodel itself under the wave of popular pressure for democratic reform that has swept Eastern Europe. Lukanov and his reform-minded colleagues face public skepticism about their commitment to reform the party and the nation, as well as their ability to handle a flagging economy hobbled by unprecedented labor unrest. ``We have to make fundamental economic reforms, and we have to do them immediately,'' Lukanov told Parliament in his address today. He said he would present new ministers for his government on Thursday and prepare an ``anti-crisis program'' for social and economic problems by Feb. 28. During the party congress, the Communist Central Committee was replaced by a 153-member Supreme Council less than half its size. The new policy-making body contains a much broader political spectrum, including radical pro-reform factions. Ninety percent of the Central Committee members failed to win election to the new council, party sources said. At a joint news conference Friday with Lukanov, Lilov told reporters that consultations would start today with ``other parties and groups for setting up a government of national concord.'' His comment was a renewed offer for the opposition to enter into an accord to set up a new government to rule until multiparty elections set for May. Petar Beron, a senior member of both the Ecoglasnost environmentalist group and the opposition Union of Democratic Forces, described Lukanov today as ``very capable and resourceful.'' But he repeated the opposition's refusal to take part in a provisional government. Beron said there was little point in taking part because the Communists dominate Parliament anyway. On Friday, Beron also appeared to reject, at least for now, multiparty elections in May. Opposition activists say they need more time to prepare. Beron said he could envisage elections under international supervision, possibly by the United Nations. Also Friday, state radio and television reported that Zhivkov, who was earlier reported under arrest, has been transferred to an undisclosed hospital for an unspecified illness. Television quoted his doctors as saying Friday he could not be held further under arrest at the Central Investigation Center in Sofia. Television also announced that the Bulgarian attorney general was appealing to Western European countries to establish whether there are accounts under Zhivkov's name or those of his relatives in their banks. The attorney general wants such funds impounded.

DOC.HEAD: Israel: Troops Kill Two Guerrillas in South Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: Israeli soldiers shot and killed two guerrillas in a pre-dawn clash in southern Lebanon today, an army spokesman said. The Israeli force suffered no casualties, the army said. The Palestine Liberation Front, based in Sidon, Lebanon, said a three-man guerrilla squad ``from the front's heroes'' clashed with an Israeli patrol in Ein Ebl on the northern edge of Israel's self-proclaimed security zone. The group, led by terrorist mastermind Mohammed Abbas, better known as Abul Abbas, said one of its guerrillas returned to his base wounded. It did not say what happened to the other two fighters. The statement claimed the guerrillas killed or wounded several Israeli soldiers and destroyed an armored vehicle. An Israeli military spokesman said the soldiers were on patrol when they spotted a group of guerrillas southeast of the village of Rashaf, four miles north of the Israeli border, and opened fire, killing two. The guerrillas were armed with Soviet-made, RPG-7 grenade launchers and assault rifles, the military said. The army said it was unclear to which organization the guerrillas were tied. The clash took place in the area of Israel's self-declared security zone, a six-to-10-mile wide strip of land patrolled by the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army militia and the Israeli army. The security zone was carved out in 1985 when Israel withdrew most of its forces from Lebanon, ending its three year occupation of the southern part of that country. The last incident in the tense security zone was on Jan. 26, when three Israeli soldiers were wounded in two separate mine blasts. On Jan. 22, troops shot and killed two Palestinian guerrillas who killed an Israeli colonel a day earlier in what was the first attempt this year to infiltrate into Israel from South Lebanon, army officials said.

DOC.HEAD: West German Chancellor Confident on Unity, Warns of Neutrality
With PM-Soviet-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today he is certain that East Germans will vote in favor of reuniting with West Germany, but he hinted that a neutral new Germany could be dangerous. Kohl sought to defuse recent Soviet worries about the revival of a strong Germany. He reiterated that a united Germany should be achieved within ``security structures in Europe spanning both alliances,'' at lower levels of armament. East German Communist Premier Hans Modrow on Thursday offered a four-point plan for a united but militarily neutral Germany. Bonn immediately rejected the neutrality idea. Kohl and Modrow planned to meet later today at Davos for talks expected to focus on the continuing domestic crisis in East Germany. In a speech to a privately sponsored meeting of business executives and statesmen, Kohl said the continuation of Eastern Europe's reform drive, particularly in East Germany, is indispensable for European stability. ``Every successful reform in a country is a step toward more stability in all of Europe,'' he told the annual World Economic Forum in this Swiss resort. Kohl said the Western military alliance, while it must adapt to changes in the Warsaw Pact, ``remains indispensable.'' ``This includes also in future a substantial security role for the United States on our continent,'' he said. The goal of unity ``corresponds to the wishes and hopes of an overwhelming majority of all Germans,'' Kohl said, adding that West Germany will respect the decision of East Germans in any referendum on unification. ``But I have no doubt what it will be,'' he said. Yet Kohl also said, ``The Germans do not want to go their own, nationalistic way.'' ``That is why I am also strictly against the idea of German neutrality. Such a proposal is contrary to the logic of the process of pan-European unification,'' he said. ``A united Germany in the heart of Europe should not have any special status which would isolate it,'' he added. He was apparently referring to the disastrous attempt by other European powers to rein in Germany after World War I. Kohl also said there could be no firm timetable for unification. He said his 10-point plan for eventual German unity, advanced last fall, respects ``legitimate security interests of all participants in East and West, not least of the Soviet Union.'' In Moscow, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said in an interview published Friday that the issue of German reunification be put to an international referendum because the world suffered so much at the hands of the Nazis.

DOC.HEAD: Albanian Opposition Coalition Seeks Dialogue With Authorities
DOC.TEXT: Five ethnic Albanian groups appealed to Yugoslavia's leaders today to open a dialogue with them in the troubled southern province of Kosovo. Thousands of police backed by tanks and planes patrolled the province, where 21 people have been killed in clashes with police in the past 11 days. No new demonstrations were reported. In an English-language statement, the five groups said they supported the government's attempt to resolve the unrest and asked for talks. The statement urged the government to investigate reports that police fired without cause or warning several times in the past week, killing people in several villages. It said authorities used ``classic forms of state terrorism'' to put down ethnic Albanian calls for greater autonomy from Yugoslavia's largest republic, Serbia, which has administrative control over Kosovo. It demanded ``an immediate ban on the use of lethal firearms by police, establishing a commission to investigate all alleged murders as a way to defuse the explosive situation that threatens to turn into a bloody civil war.'' Serbian authorities claim the ethnic Albanian majority is harassing the Serb minority population in Kosovo and that the republic must retain control over the province. They claim that the ultimate goal of ethnic Albanian ``separatists'' is to secede from Yugoslavia and join neighboring Albania. Yugoslavia's liberal northern regions of Slovenia and Croatia have backed ethnic Albanian calls for greater self-government and blamed the unrest on Serbian moves, backed by nationalist Serbian leader Sloboban Milosevic, to reduce the province's autonomy. On Friday, President Janez Drnovsek appealed to ethnic Albanians and Serbs in the province to stop the violence, which he said threatened the process of economic and political reform nationwide. The government has pledged to allow a multiparty democracy and observe human rights according to internationally recognized standards. Drnovsek has said that the use of arms is in no group's interest and has repeatedly called for a dialogue. But officials of Serbia have demanded that opposition leaders first renounce their alleged separatist plans before any dialogue can be expected. The groups who made the statement were the Kosovo branch of the Yugoslav Union for Democratic Initiative, the Committee for Human Rights and Freedoms, the Democratic League of Kosova, the Society of Philosophers and Sociologists of Kosova, and the Initiating Board for the Youth Parliament. Kosova is the name Albanians use to refer to the province.

DOC.HEAD: Shevardnadze: World Should Have a Say On German Unity
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 5th graf, `While giving...' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Kohl comments today. Pickup 6th graf, ``We wish ...'
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet foreign minister has proposed that the issue of German reunification be put to an international referendum because the world suffered so much at the hands of the Nazis. Eduard A. Shevardnadze, in an interview published Friday, said Europe must be assured that another militaristic regime will not arise. ``It is not the idea of German unity itself but the revival of sinister shadows of the past associated with it, as well as a possible growth of militarism, that are met with apprehension in the world,'' Shevardnadze told a group of Soviet reporters, according to Tass, the official news agency. ``It's necessary to find a method of sounding out public opinion in the most democratic and open way possible, say through an all-European referendum with the participation of the U.S.A. and Canada, or at least through wide parliamentary discussions,'' the foreign minister said. In Davos, Switzerland today, West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl said he is certain that East Germans will vote in favor of reuniting with West Germany, but he hinted that a neutral new Germany could be dangerous. He also sought to defuse Soviet worries about the revival of a strong Germany, while at the same time saying he opposes making a united Germany neutral. ``The Germans do not want to go their own, nationalistic way,'' he said. While giving the strongest Kremlin endorsement yet of a united Germany, Shevardnadze repeated long-standing Soviet conditions that the process not happen too quickly or cause instability in Europe. ``We wish the movement of Germans toward a united motherland to develop without upheavals, not to upset the European and world balance and not to create a threat to their neighbors,'' he said. Tass did not say when the interview took place, but Shevardnadze's comments responded to an outline offered Thursday by East German Premier Hans Modrow on how a single German state should be attained. Modrow called for a militarily neutral ``united fatherland'' with Berlin as its capital. While Shevardnadze generally supported Modrow's plan and endorsed the idea of neutrality, he said the issue was too important for politicians alone to decide. ``It's important that not only the politicians but the peoples as well decide the fate and the future of Europe,'' he said. Suggesting a say for third parties appeared to conflict with Shevardnadze's stated support for self-determination for East and West Germany. In the Kremlin's clearest endorsement of reunification, he told the interviewers: ``We favor the eventual creation of a united, peaceful, democratic Germany.'' The Soviet Union has traditionally opposed a single Germany, but President Mikhail S. Gorbachev softened that position with a hands-off policy that has allowed radical reform in Eastern Europe. Shevardnadze said the suffering of World War II, in which 20 million Soviets were killed, meant ``all peoples, especially the peoples of the Soviet Union, should have the right to a guarantee that there will never again be a threat of war from German land.'' ``They will accept and support German unity only if they are sure of this,'' he told Soviet journalists. Third countries also must have pledges that the Germans will ``recognize unconditionally and strictly observe'' borders in Europe formed after World War II and not make territorial claims, he said. Gorbachev met Friday with Gregor Gysi, chief of the East German Communist Party. Gysi told reporters afterward they agreed that any reunification must not threaten stability in Europe and ``only time will give the answers'' to how it can be achieved. In Washington, visiting West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said Friday he and Secretary of State James A. Baker III had agreed that German reunification would not mean extending NATO's military area eastward.

DOC.HEAD: ANC Leadership Meets to Discuss de Klerk Speech
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 5th pvs, `President F.W. ...' with 2 grafs to ADD Mandela's age, CLARIFY when he was sentenced. Pickup 6th, `De Klerk...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The newly legalized African National Congress called a meeting of its senior leaders Saturday to begin reviewing strategy in light of the dramatic policy changes in South Africa. ANC Secretary-General Alfred Nzo and Joe Slovo, head of the South African Communist Party, flew into Stockholm late Friday to join Walter Sisulu and other ANC veterans touring Scandinavia after their release from prison in October. The meeting was described as a session of the executive committee of the ANC, the largest movement opposing South Africa's apartheid system of legalized racial discrimination. ``The ANC will discuss new strategies because of the new situation which has arisen,'' said David Kgabang, an official of the ANC's Stockholm office. President F.W. de Klerk told the South African Parliament in Cape Town Friday that the government was lifting the 30-year ban on the ANC and about 60 other opposition groups, and promised to unconditionally free ANC leader Nelson Mandela. Mandela, 71, the country's best-known black leader, was jailed in 1962 and is serving a life sentence for helping plan the start of the ANC's sabotage and bombing campaign against the white-run government. De Klerk also rescinded most emergency regulations imposed in 1986 to quell anti-government uprisings, and declared a moratorium on executions. In a statement drafted in Stockholm Friday, the ANC gave a cautious welcome to the speech, but voiced concern that some emergency restrictions remained in place, including the power to detain without trial. It called for the continued international isolation of South Africa until apartheid is dismantled. ``Victory is in sight,'' said Sisulu, but he added that the measures were only a preliminary step toward creating the conditons for negotiations. Kgabang said he expected the ANC to reopen its offices in Johannesburg and elsewhere in South Africa. The group operated openly for 48 years until it was outlawed in 1960, and launched a campaign of sabotage the following year. The arrival of Nzo and Slovo brought together in Sweden most of the ANC's top decision makers. Nzo is the group's acting president in place of Oliver Tambo, who is recuperating from a stroke in a Stockholm clinic. Slovo is a former head of the ANC's armed wing. They joined Thabo Mbeki, who is in charge of the ANC's foreign relations, Sisulu and five other recently freed leaders from the Mandela era. ``This is an opportunity to discuss developments with the leadership which has been in the cold for so many years,'' Kgabang told The Associated Press. Meetings were expected to last until Monday, when Sisulu and the other released veterans planned to return to South Africa while the rest head back to the ANC's headquarters in Lusaka, Zambia. The ANC said in its statement Friday that it would consult with the Mass Democratic Movement, the main alliance of anti-apartheid groups. ``The review of the new situation will include an assessment of the prospects of genuine negotiations to end the apartheid system,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Party to Consider Shedding Guarantee of Power
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party will consider shedding its constitutionally guaranteed leading role in Soviet society at a key Central Committee meeting next week, a published report said today. The Soviet Union, ruled exclusively by the Communists since a few months after the 1917 Russian Revolution, is the last remaining Warsaw Pact nation to give the Communists a guaranteed monopoly on power. A draft platform to be presented at the Central Committee meeting on Monday and Tuesday calls for the party to ``fight for its leading role, but assume no state or government powers, nor lay any claim to having its role set down in the Constitution,'' said Interfax, a news service of official Radio Moscow. Interfax did not say how it obtained its information on the platform that party leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev apparently will present Monday as a basis for preparing the party's next Congress, scheduled for October. The Central Committee meeting is widely expected to turn into a crucial political battle between party reformers and hard-liners. In addition, it is likely to be the hard-liners' last chance to make a power play before the voters decide on their future in local and republic-level elections in February and March. Communist Party officials have said Gorbachev would present a program to the two-day session calling for a ``radical democratization'' of the party. A group of reform-minded deputies calling itself the Democratic Platform also has drafted an alternate program for the party calling for a multiparty system and a virtual apology for decades of strict one-party rule. Members of the Democratic Platform group have said they would try to have their program introduced at the Central Committee meeting as an alternative. The leading role of the Communist Party, written into the Soviet Constitution under former President Leonid I. Brezhnev in 1977, has come under increasing attack in recent months. The Lithuanian republic already has struck that reference from its constitution as it prepares to legalize other parties. Reformers tried to have the issue brought before the 2,250-member Congress of People's Deputies at its December meeting, but they were defeated by a margin of about 300 votes. Gorbachev, in a visit to Lithuania less than a month ago, tried to persuade Lithuanian Communists to heal their split with the national party that they declared in December. But he added that he saw ``no tragedy'' if a multiparty system evolves. Nevertheless, Gorbachev continues to insist that a multiparty system also is ``no panacea'' for all the country's troubles. The Demcratic Platform is considering declaring that the Communist Party cannot be reformed and breaking away to form a social democratic party if the Communists refuse to embark on radical reforms. Interfax said the draft ``recognizes the right to platforms inside the party and the right of a minority to defend its views. However, the party will not permit factions with an internal organization or discipline of their own.'' The report also said new party structures would be proposed. The Central Committee, cut from more than 300 members to 251 at a meeting last year, would be reduced to 200, it said. The party would have a chairman and two deputy chairmen, and a new structure called the Political Executive Committee would be formed and include representatives of all 15 Soviet republics. It was unclear whether the Executive Committee would replace the current Politburo, the ruling force of the party and of Soviet society as a whole.

DOC.HEAD: Militants Enforce Strike As Curfew Lifted in Kashmir
DOC.TEXT: The government today lifted curfew for several hours, but shops remained closed because of a strike called by Moslem militants leading a secessionist campaign in Jammu-Kashmir state, witnesses said. The Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front spread the strike call by word of mouth on Friday night and early today, local journalists said, quoting shopkeepers in downtown Srinagar and its suburbs. The front is spearheading the four-decade-old campaign for secession of Jammu-Kashmir state's predominantly Moslem Kashmir region. At least 76 people have been killed since the government began cracking down on the increasingly violent secessionist movement Jan. 20. Most of those killed during the crackdown were curfew-breaking militants shot by the security forces. The government reported no deaths between Jan. 25 and Friday, when at least four people were killed. Three of them died when police opened fire on a mob defying curfew in neighboring Sopore, police said. The fourth was a Hindu shopkeeper who was shot by the militants, according to Gov. Jagmohan, who uses only one name. Today's strike in Srinagar was to protest the Sopore deaths, Kaiser Mirza, a local journalist, quoted the shopkeepers as saying. The curfew relaxation began at 5 a.m. and was scheduled to end at 5 p.m. Mirza said most shops did not open in the morning when curfew was lifted and a few shops that did open soon put down their shutters when owners learned of the general strike call. It was not immediately clear if the shops were closed fearing attacks by the militants or to sympathize with the separatist cause. During earlier curfew relaxations, which began one week ago, vegetable shops and groceries were crowded and streets were filled with people and traffic. This morning, small groups of men stood at the street corners but little traffic moved on the streets, Mirza said. The Moslem militancy dates back to 1948 when the Hindu maharajah of mostly Moslem Jammu-Kashmir opted for union with predominantly Hindu India. Pakistan, born out of a 1947 division of the Indian subcontinent, objected saying a Moslem area should go to predominantly Moslem Pakistan. Two wars over Kashmir left a slice of the old royal state under Pakistani control, while the rest remained part of India's Jammu-Kashmir state. Jammu-Kashmir, with 64 percent of its 5 million people following Islam, is the only Moslem majority area among India's 25 states. Nationwide, Moslems account for 12 percent of the 880 million population. Kashmiri militants at first demanded union with Pakistan but have recently campaigned for a separate neutral country which if formed would nestle between India, Pakistan and China.

DOC.HEAD: Another Officer Tied to December Coup Arrested in Philippines
DOC.TEXT: Intelligence agents today arrested another renegade officer involved in December's failed coup attempt, the military said. Navy Capt. Proceso Maligalig was intercepted by government soldiers as he drove his car through a residential district of Manila, said Brig. Gen. Pantaleon Dumlao, chief of the military's Criminal Investigation Service. Maligalig, 46, had disguised himself with a wig and a pair of thick-rimmed glasses, Dumlao said. Maligalig was unarmed and did not resist arrest. Authorities had issued a $22,300 reward for his capture. Maligalig, a bomb expert, is believed to be a security aide of Commodore Domingo Calajate, former chief of the military's logistics command. Maligalig and Calajate both defected to the rebels on the first day of the Dec. 1-9 failed coup, Dumlao said. Maligalig, presented to reporters hours after his arrest, denied being a ring leader of the December coup. He said his troops simply fought back when government troops attacked the logistics command. ``It was a sudden decision on our part,'' Maligalig said. ``I have no prior knowledge of the coup plot.'' ``We thought our lives were in jeopardy,'' he said. He said he and Calajate, who remains at large, decided to abandon their troops during the attack for fear of their own lives. Maligalig said he is a member of the Reform the Armed Forces Movement, which launched the February 1986 popular rebellion that ousted President Ferdinand Marcos and installed Corazon Aquino as president. The movement has launched several coup attempts since then, accusing Mrs. Aquino's government of the kind of corruption and nepotism common in Marcos' 20-year rule. The December coup, which left at least 115 people dead and more than 660 wounded, was the sixth and most serious attempt to topple Mrs. Aquino.

DOC.HEAD: China Protests Dalai Lama's Visit to Czechoslovakia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 5th pvs, `The Dalai...' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Dalai Lama comments. Pickup 6th pvs, `Havel said...'
DOC.TEXT: China today protested a visit to Czechoslovakia by the Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, and Beijing retaliated by postponing the visit of a Czechoslovak minister. The Dalai Lama, who received the Nobel Peace Prize last year, has championed Tibetan autonomy. Chinese diplomats in Prague earlier criticized his visit as an indication of political support for separatism in Tibet, which is ruled by Communist China. Czechoslovakia's ambassador to China, Eduard Saul, was summoned to the Foreign Ministry today and told the Dalai Lama's visit ``constitutes a gross interference in China's internal affairs,'' the official Xinhua News Agency reported. Saul also was told that China is postponing a visit by Czechoslovakia's minister of metallurgy, engineering and the electrotechnical industry, scheduled to begin Feb. 17, Xinhua said. The Dalai Lama was invited by Czechoslovakia's new non-Communist president, Vaclav Havel, for a four-day private visit that began Friday. The Tibetan religious leader talked to reporters today but did not address the Chinese protest directly. He said he was pleased to visit Czechoslovakia following its peaceful, pro-democratcy uprising in November that ousted its hard-line Communist leadership. He said only time will tell whether the Chinese government will change, and he appeared to urge other countries to take a firm stand with the Beijing leadership. ``Our experience is that when somebody tries to appease them they get bolder and bolder. But if you stand firm, they show more compliance,'' he said. The Buddhist monk is to spend Sunday in ``spiritual consultations and meditations'' with Havel. Havel said Monday he had told China's ambassador to Czechoslovakia that the Dalai Lama's visit was personal. ``I wanted to meet with him a long time ago when I was not yet a president. I want to meditate with him,'' the Czechoslovak leader said. ``If the Chinese republic is not satisfied with this explanation, I am sorry.'' Havel, a playwright and former dissident, became president last month in the culmination of Czechoslovakia's revolution. China says Tibet has been part of China for 700 years and accuses the Dalai Lama of instigating pro-independence violence that has hit the Tibetan capital of Lhasa repeatedly in the past two years. Lhasa remains under martial law imposed nearly a year ago after a round of anti-Chinese rioting. The Dalai Lama fled Tibet to India in 1959.

DOC.HEAD: Activists Enjoy Newly Won Freedoms in South Africa
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 9th pvs, `The concessions...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with today's protest against cricket team. Pickup 10th, `Notices were...'
DOC.TEXT: Anti-apartheid activists long banned from public comment spoke out freely today as the government put into effect sweeping political reforms announced a day earlier by President F.W. de Klerk. Thousands of blacks celebrated the changes at a stadium at Alexandra, a black township near Johannesburg, chanting ``Viva ANC!'' and swaying to the rhythm of freedom songs. Blacks also celebrated in Cape Town and in the Natal provincial capital of Pietermaritzburg. The day before, de Klerk legalized the African National Congress, the main guerrilla group fighting white rule, and lifted restrictions on 60 opposition groups and 374 individuals. For the first time in three decades, Helen Joseph, a friend of jailed black leader Nelson Mandela and the first white person ever placed under house arrest for anti-government activity, was quoted by newspapers. ``This is a wonderful day. I am very excited about my personal freedom since I am no longer a listed person,'' Ms. Joseph, 84, was quoted as saying by The Star in Johnannesburg. ``Above all I am excited about the return of all my friends and comrades and all the exiles who will be coming back home, all my comrades who will be released from jail.'' In his speech, de Klerk also promised to release Mandela, the jailed leader of the ANC. But de Klerk did not say when. In addition, the president placed a moratorium on executions and partially lifted emergency restrictions on the news media. Police still will retain control over photography or the filming of political unrest and police action. De Klerk's announcements Friday met most of the conditions set by the ANC to begin negotiations on a new constitution to bring the black majority into the nation's political life. However, many activists said the government must go further and dismantle apartheid, under which the 28-million black majority has no say in national affairs. The concessions announced by de Klerk will help efforts to end an international sports boycott on South Africa, Johan du Plessis, chairman of the South African National Olympic Committee, said today. ``A lot more people will listen to what we have to say now,'' he said. Blacks have repeatedly demonstrated against a British cricket teams that is touring South Africa in defiance of the international ban on sports teams competing here. Today, 7,000 people gathered outside a cricket stadium in Pietermaritzburg to protest the team. English captain Mike Gatting walked out to a truck where protest leaders handed him a petition. Members of the crowd hurled stones and insults as he left, but no injuries were reported. Notices were published today in the Government Gazette making official the lifting of 30-year-old bans on the ANC, the Pan-Africanist Congress, the South African Communist Party and other organizations. ANC leaders have been cautious about an invitation by de Klerk for exiled black activists to return home. Even with the groups legalized, they say there are many security laws and emergency regulations in effect that could be used to arrest leaders of the ANC and other groups. The government repealed laws that banned 175 people, including ANC President Oliver Tambo, now recovering from a stroke in Sweden; and the ANC's chief spokesman, Tom Sebina; the leader of the South African Communist Party. It removed state-of-emergency prohibitions on travel and public speaking on another 200 people. The Citizen, a pro-grovernment newspaper, said if the atmosphere remained calm, the 71-year-old Mandela might be freed by next weekend. De Klerk had said concerns about Mandela's safety and other issues would delay his release from a life prison term for sabotage and plotting to overthrow the white-run government. ``The state president is very fluid and moves very fast. Judging by his speech in parliament, Mr. Mandela's release could happen any day now,'' the newspaper quoted an unidentified government source as saying. On Friday, the Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu, winner of the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize, called de Klerk's speech ``incredible.'' ``What he said has certainly taken my breath away,'' Tutu said. ``We could say that we are probably seeing history in the making in South Africa.'' The exiled ANC said de Klerk's announcements ``go a long way to creating the climate conducive to negotiations.'' But the Zambia-based group said more changes are needed before talks could begin. The ANC was outlawed in 1960 after 48 years of non-violent campaigning for black rights. In 1961, it launched a guerrilla war. The ANC and all leading anti-apartheid groups demand a one-person, one-vote democracy, which de Klerk opposes, saying it will result in the 28 million blacks dominating the 5 million whites. De Klerk, since taking office in August, has said he envisions some type of system in which no single racial group would dominate.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Implant First Lung Booster Device
DOC.TEXT: Surgeons have implanted into a human an experimental device consisting of a slender bundle of fibers that works like a lung in bringing oxygen to the heart, LDS Hospital said. The device, the IntraVascular Oxygenator, or IVOX, is not a lung replacement but a temporary mechanism to give patients with lung damage time to heal. The Food and Drug Administration has approved its use for up to seven days. The Salt Lake Tribune said the hospital is apparently the first to insert the device. Hospital spokesman Tim Madden said Friday that the two-hour procedure had taken place that afternoon. He said he could not confirm the age, sex or condition of the patient in accordance with the wishes of the patient's family. The Tribune, quoting an unidentified hospital source, reported today that the recipient is a 16-year-old girl. Dr. Roger C. Millar performed the operation, which involved inserting the device _ a long bundle of tubes as thin as hairs _ into the inferior vena cava, the large vein that brings blood to the heart from the body. In September, the FDA granted approval for limited testing of the device. The device consists of hollow fibers through which oxygen is delivered and carbon dioxide removed. Two intravenous tubes attached to the bundle leave the body, one to deliver oyxgen, the other to remove carbon dioxide. Developers of the device say it could help patients recover from acute respiratory failure caused by inhalation of smoke or other noxious fumes or by drugs, severe pneumonia and scores of other ailments. The only alternative for people with acute lung failure is an extracorporeal oxygenator, a large machine that requires pumping the blood outside the body. Dr. J.D. Mortensen, the device's inventor, said the device performs much like the natural membranes in the air sacs in the human lung. The developer of the new device, CardioPulmonics Inc., a Salt Lake City biomedical technology company, announced Jan. 11 that the IVOX would be tested in 10 patients at four U.S. medical centers. Other centers approved to use the IVOX are Penn State's Hershey Medical Center, the University of Michigan Medical Center in Ann Arbor, and the Los Angeles County-University of Southern California Medical Center. The IVOX is to be tested on patients with acute respiratory failure who have little chance of survival using previous treatment methods. Madden said doctors at LDS Hospital and the Hershey Medical Center have been evaluating patients who might qualify for the first clinical trials. Several centers in Europe and Japan also have been selected to try the procedure. The product was the outcome of membrane technology that makes much higher concentrations of oxygen available using polypropylene tubes the width of a hair. The temporary artificial lung is threaded through a vein in the leg or neck into the body's main vein and can be removed the same way. It has been tested on dogs and sheep. A spokesman at CardioPulmonics said Friday he had been asked not to comment on the medical procedure.

DOC.HEAD: Rival Militias Break Vatican-brokered Cease-fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with cease-fire broken, details on new shelling, UPDATES overall casualties. Pickup 8th graf, `Fires burned ...'
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces fought with tanks and gunboats for a fifth day today, violating a Vatican-brokered truce after just three hours. Shellfire killed 25 people and trapped 500,000 in shelters. The renewed artillery barrage caught unprotected civilians who had emerged from shelters to inspect damage inflicted on their property in Moslem west Beirut and the city's eastern Christian sector. It was the sixth failed attempt to stop the fighting between Gen. Michel Aoun's army and the Lebanese Forces militia for control of Lebanon's Christian enclave. The Lebanese Forces, led by Samir Geagea, is the main Christian militia. Aoun and Geagea had announced they accepted a cease-fire called by the Vatican through papal Nuncio Pablo Puente and Maronite Catholic Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir, spiritual head of the Maronite community. Aoun and Geagea belong to that sect. The big guns fell silent shortly after the 1:15 p.m. deadline, but shellfire resumed three hours later, with about six shells falling every minute, a police spokesman said. It was not immediately clear who had broken the cease-fire. Geagea said in an interview broadcast live by the Christian Voice of Lebanon radio that his militia was ``fully abiding'' by the cease-fire. Aoun's command, in a statement broadcast by his Radio Lebanon, said the general's positions were being shelled. The short statement did not elaborate. No clear victor emerged from the earlier fighting, which sent shells crashing into high-rise apartment buildings, schools, hospitals, power plants, water pumping stations and fuel tanks. Police said 25 more people were killed overnight and 70 wounded, bringing the overall toll to at least 152 dead and 586 wounded in the showdown between the rival militias. Casualty figures from the latest fighting were not immediately available. Fires burned out of control earlier today, as snipers kept firefighters from battling the blazes. Police appealed to civil defense squads to race to the rescue of trapped tenants in three burning apartment buildings in East Beirut's main residential district of Ashrafiyeh. The Lebanese Forces claimed it had brought most of Christian east Beirut under its control with a mass defection by enemy soldiers at Beirut's port and along half the city's three-mile dividing Green Line. ``This brought the bulk of east Beirut under Lebanese Forces control,'' the statement claimed. It did not say how many soldiers had defected. If the claim is accurate, Aoun's forces would have lost their only sea outlet for replenishing supplies, the Beirut harbor. Aoun denied the claim. In a statement, he said Lebanese Forces militiamen ``shot the soldiers in the back'' while they defended the Green Line. There was no independent confirmation of the claims. Police said at least half of the Christian enclave's 1 million people had been huddled in basements and bomb shelters before the cease-fire today, with rapidly dwindling food and water and no lights. The warring forces had ignored earlier appeals by the International Red Cross for a humanitarian cease-fire to allow evacuation of casualties on the streets and to send food to trapped residents. Hospitals appealed for blood, plasma, oxygen and water supplies. Aoun, 54, insists on disbanding the 6,000-member Lebanese Forces to strengthen his hold on the Christian enclave. But Geagea, 40, has vowed to fight to the death to defend the militia that has borne the brunt of the fighting against the Moslems in Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war. Aoun, who has been dismissed as army commander but clings to command of about 20,000 soldiers, attacked Tuesday to gain full control of the enclave north and east of Beirut. Aoun was fired by President Elias Hrawi, who was elected in November under the terms of a peace plan brokered by the Arab League. The plan was aimed at increasing political power of the Moslem majority and ending the civil war, which has left 150,000 people dead. Aoun complains that the plan, approved by Parliament in October, provides no fixed withdrawal timetable for Syria's estimated 40,000 troops. They came in 1976 under an Arab League peacekeeping mandate, but Aoun says they are simply fighting as an ally of Moslem militias. Geagea has neither accepted or rejected the peace accord, but he has recognized Hrawi as president. Syria, the United States, and much of the international community also recognize Hrawi's government.

DOC.HEAD: Armed Men Steal Two Bazookas From War Museum
DOC.TEXT: Armed men on Saturday stole two bazookas from a display at the War Museum, and the Defense Ministry said the old weapons could be made to fire. No group claimed responsibility for the robbery. Witnesses told police that five men wielding pistols entered the museum at 9:45 a.m., keeping guards at bay while grabbing the bazookas. All five fled in a waiting car, one witness reported. The ministry announcement said that the bazookas ``with slight modificiations and the addition of a few spare parts'' could be made to work. It did not say where the weapons had been made, but most equipment used by the army is supplied by the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Two Ugandan Journalists Arrested
DOC.TEXT: Police have detained two journalists, and a government newspaper said it might have been because of questions they asked Zambia's president. Festo Ebongu, a New Vision reporter and stringer for the BBC, and Alfred Okware, an associate editor of the magazine Newsdesk, were picked up by police Friday. Both apparently were still being held Saturday, but police declined comment on the case and it was not known if charges had been filed.
