New Vision, a government-owned paper, said the arrests may have been in connection with a news conference Monday when Okware and Ebongu were among reporters who intensively questioned Kenneth Kuanda, the Zambian president, at the end of a four-day state visit. Okware asked Kuanda why after 25 years in office he has not considered relinquishing power. Uganda's president, Yoweri Museveni, immediately intervened and told Kuanda not to waste his time answering the question.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Armed Robbers Executed
DOC.TEXT: Nine men convicted of armed robbery were executed by firing squad Saturday morning, police said. A police statement said the men belonged to two different gangs and in some cases had shot and killed their victims. Some of the men dressed in phony military or police uniforms during robberies, the statement added. No other details were immediately available.

DOC.HEAD: Meditation Lengthens Lives of Elderly, Study Suggests
DOC.TEXT: Elderly people who were taught Transcendental Meditation lived longer than their peers in a new study that experts called the first direct scientific evidence that meditation can prolong life. The technique worked better than two others for lowering blood pressure and improving several aspects of mental function as well as extending lifespan, researchers reported. ``It's a rather dramatic finding,'' said psychologist Arthur Aron of the University of California at Santa Cruz, who was familiar with the work. ``I think it's very impressive.'' Two other psychologists who study meditation said they suspect the outcome was due to factors other than Transcendental Meditation itself. They also suggested that other techniques might do as well or better. The work, done at Harvard University, is presented in the December issue of the Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, which is published by the American Psychological Association. The study included 73 volunteers, with an average age of 81, from eight homes for the elderly. They were assigned randomly to learn Transcendental Meditation, another technique called mindfulness training, a simple relaxation program, or no training at all. Three years later, all 20 of those taught Transcendental Meditation were still alive. Survival rates in the other groups were 88 percent, 65 percent and 77 percent, respectively. Transcendental Meditation, or TM, was taught in the 1960s and '70s by the Indian Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, a guru to the Beatles and other celebrities. TM induces a ``a distinctively deep state of rest'' while the mind is alert but ``in a very settled, quiet state,'' said study co-author Charles Alexander, now an associate professor of psychology at Maharishi International University in Fairfield, Iowa. Students there practice TM as part of the curriculum, Alexander said. The mindfulness training used in the study was not the Buddhist technique of the same name. Instead, it was designed to stimulate creation of ideas or new perspectives through a verbal exercise and a challenge to think about topics in new and creative ways. Each technique was practiced for 20 minutes twice daily with the eyes closed during the 12-week experiment. Alexander attributed the study's outcome to TM's combination of high wakefulness, which he said combats atrophy of the mind and so the body, and deep restfulness, which he said releases stress from the nervous system and leads to reduced ``wear and tear'' on mind and body. He said the study suggests TM should be combined with standard Western medicine, not replace it. Some other meditation researchers suggested different explanations for the outcome. Michael Maliszewski, director of behavioral medicine at the Diamond Headache Clinic in Chicago, said TM instructors may have differed from the instructors of the other techniques in terms of motivation or other factors that could have given their teachings more impact. The TM group had fewer dropouts than the other groups, he noted. He also said he suspected that Chinese Taoist meditative techniques, which he said were designed to increase longevity, might do so better than TM. Taoism has not been studied experimentally so far, he said. Alexander replied that a survey covering most dropouts found their decision had nothing to do with the quality of the instructors. He also said other studies have found TM superior to alternative techniques in improving aspects of physical and mental health, even though the commitment of the instructors of other techniques was presumeably as high as that of the TM instructors. Jonathan C. Smith, director of the Roosevelt University Stress Institute in Chicago, said the result could have come from combining relaxation with the idea of connecting to something larger than oneself, TM's notion of a consciousness underlying all beings. Any relaxation technique with what he called such religious undercurrents might have done as well, he said. Alexander said instructors for each of the techniques strongly downplayed philosophical considerations in the training. Only one TM student said he perceived TM in spiritual terms, Alexander said.

DOC.HEAD: Saudis Block Entry of Thai Workers Over Embassy Killings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with Saudis blocking Thai workers, quotes from authorities. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia has blocked the entry of Thai workers to protest the slaying of three of its embassy workers in Thailand, a newspaper reported today. On Friday, Saudi Arabia threatened to close its embassy in the Thai capital of Bangkok if the government fails to track down the killers. The Saudi government earlier summoned the Thai ambassador in Riyadh to hear the protest. Deputy Interior Minister Prince Ahmed bin Abdul-Aziz was quoted in the Saudi daily Al-Jazira as saying the slayings were ``a horrendous matter that has shocked and pained us all. King Fahd is deeply concerned about his sons.'' The coffins with the bodies of the three Saudi Embassy workers were flown in Friday night aboard a special Saudi jet ordered by the king. The deputy governor of Riyadh, Prince Sattam bin Abdul-Aziz, led an official delegation to the airport and told reporters, ``These are three martyrs who died for their religion and homeland ... at the hands of evil.'' According to reports from Bangkok on Thursday, gunmen killed the three employees in two shootings that occurred minutes apart. They were identified as second secretary and consular head Abdullah Abul-Rahman al-Basri, 32; consular officer Fahd Abdullah al-Bahli, 35; and telex operator Ahmed Abdullah al-Saif, 26. Prince Ahmed said the ``necessary measures'' had been taken to halt the entry of Thai workers in Saudi Arabia. About 140,000 Thais live in Saudi Arabia, part of the 3 million expatriate labor force in the kingdom. Thailand also has enjoyed good commercial and tourism ties with Saudi Arabia. Last year, gunmen fatally shot a third secretary of the embassy, Abdullah al-Malki. He was responsible for processing visa applications. The crime has not been solved and speculation at the time said the assailants could have been frustrated workers unable to secure entry visas for the oil-rich kingdom. The Saudi newspaper Asharq Al-Awsat said in a report today that the same pistols that killed Maliki were used in this week's murders. It quoted unidentified Thai police sources.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Faces Tough Issues in Moscow Talks
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: With revolution in Eastern Europe accelerating and Germans driving to reunite, Secretary of State James A. Baker III is off this week on a diplomatic journey that tests the influence of the superpowers to shape these fast-paced events. In Baker's bulging briefcase are a dozen tough problems, ranging from the German issue and the sometimes nasty turns the changes in Eastern Europe have taken to the lingering 12-year war in Afghanistan between the Soviet-backed Marxist government and U.S.-armed rebels. The centerpiece of Baker's nine-day trip, which begins Monday evening, is a face-to-face session with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev toward the end of the week in Moscow. That will give Baker a firsthand account of the course the Kremlin is taking on German reunification and of how Gorbachev is addressing Soviet political and economic problems. Rumors last week that Gorbachev might surrender his post as general secretary of the Communist Party at a Central Committee meeting Monday and Tuesday renewed U.S. interest in his personal fate and the course of Soviet reform. Both President Bush, hailing in his State of the Union speech ``the new era in the world's affairs'' launched by Gorbachev, and Baker, praising ``the reformers'' in testimony to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, are making a calculated effort to bolster Gorbachev as he tries to overcome resistance to his program of perestroika. Baker is taking new offers of technical cooperation to Moscow, and in three days of talks with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze hopes to remove some of the remaining roadblocks to completion of a treaty to reduce U.S. and Soviet long-range nuclear missiles, submarines and bombers by 30 percent to 50 percent. The idea is to have a treaty ready for Bush and Gorbachev to sign at a Washington summit meeting in June. Baker's talks with Shevardnadze, which begin Wednesday night, are intended as preparations for the event. Baker also is prepared to extend the promise of trade privileges, provided the Soviets codify their recent easing of emigration restrictions. At the same time, though, the Bush administration has to assess ways of encouraging democratic trends in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe in the event Gorbachev's powers ebb. There seems to be little doubt, however, that the Bush-Baker team is determined to cooperate with Gorbachev. The question that hangs over Baker's mission, apart from the slow response of the Soviet economy, is how much influence the two superpowers working together can have on world events. The accelerating drive by East and West Germans to form one country again _ and the tremors this causes among some Europeans _ apparently is only slightly responsive to U.S. and Soviet wishes. Gorbachev last week softened his opposition, saying unification was not in doubt but must come as part of a revision of Europe's political and military structure. Baker, meanwhile, reiterated U.S. support for reunification but steered clear of picking and choosing among the approaches that have surfaced. Among them is one by Hans Modrow, the East German premier, for a neutral, single state that would belong neither to NATO nor the Warsaw Pact, and another by West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher that would keep Germany in NATO but leave the East German region demilitarized. Baker met with Genscher on Friday night on the German question and planned a session with French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas at Shannon Airport in Ireland early Tuesday while Baker's jet is being refueled. Pursuing a fast pace, Baker will then fly to Prague for 27 hours in the capital of Czechoslovakia, the Central European ally of the Soviet Union that is in the midst of an untroubled transition to democracy. During that brief visit Baker will meet with President Vaclav Havel and other leaders of the new government and make a speech in which he is expected to strengthen his qualified endorsement of a 35-nation European summit meeting this year _ a Gorbachev formula for easing East-West tensions. Bush set the tone for Baker's trip in his State of the Union speech with a proposal to cut U.S. and Soviet troops in Europe to 225,000, with a limit of 195,000 in Central Europe. That meshes with calls on Gorbachev by Czechoslovakia, Poland and Hungary to remove Soviet forces _ and with Gorbachev's apparent willingness to comply _ while leaving tens of thousands in East Germany. What the Bush initiative may do to negotiations in Vienna is not clear. NATO and the Warsaw Pact are in the midst of completing a treaty to cut the troop levels to 275,000, as Bush proposed last June, along with reductions in tanks and other weapons. The spokesman for the Soviet foreign ministry, Gennady Gerasimov, welcomed the new troop cut proposal on Thursday as ``a step in the right direction,'' but a more complete response is expected when Baker sees Shevardnadze. In this area, too, the influence of the superpowers has its limits. While both the United States and the Soviet Union want to make deeper cuts, some of the U.S. allies, particularly Britain, are edgy about withdrawing around 100,000 American soldiers from Europe. Administration officials acknowledge that if there is a hangup it will be with the allies, although so far most of them seem to be going along. On Saturday, at the end of his visit, Baker will make an unprecedented appearance and answer questions before the 44-member International Affairs Committee of the Supreme Soviet, the nation's chief legislative body. He will make a brief opening statement and then answer questions for 90 minutes in the presence of American and Soviet reporters. On the way home, Baker will stop in Ottawa, Canada, to attend a meeting Feb. 12-13 of NATO and Warsaw Pact officials to discuss an ``open skies'' proposal that would open U.S. and Soviet territory to overflights. There is room on his schedule before then to squeeze in another East European stop or to hold a meeting somewhere in Europe with Foreign Ministers Moshe Arens of Israel and Esmat Abdel-Meguid of Egypt. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said Baker had no other stops planned, but said she could not rule anything out. ``Anything is possible,'' she said.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Barry Schweid covers foreign affairs for The Associated Press, specializing in U.S.-Soviet relations.

DOC.HEAD: Neighborhood Shaken by Two Shootings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 18th graf pvs, `On Friday ...' to UPDATE with gun unloaded.
DOC.TEXT: Residents in a neighborhood ravaged by drugs, crime and poverty say they now even fear police after the fatal shootings of two unarmed teen-agers by officers in separate incidents. Hundreds marched on the local police precinct Thursday night to protest the shootings in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn. On Friday, residents remained angry. ``People are tired of this,'' Manuel Vasquez, 38, said. ``We're supposed to be more afraid of the criminals than the cops. It's getting not that way anymore.'' ``It's just murder, plain old murder,'' said one marcher at the demonstration, where three people were arrested after rocks and bottles were thrown at police in riot gear. Residents of Bushwick, which has one of the highest murder rates in the city, have seen the number of people killed by police climb in recent years. ``When they see you with gold, right away cops think you're a drug dealer,'' said George Ponce, 20, as he stood Friday across from the police precinct. Ponce, along with others, talked about the death of 14-year-old Jose Louis Lebron, who was killed Wednesday in front of a candy store after he was shot behind the right ear by Officer Frank Albergo. A preliminary police investigation showed Albergo, who thought he saw Lebron reaching into his jacket for a weapon, acted ``within police guidelines.'' Police have promised a thorough investigation. Police said Lebron had robbed someone of $10. Four days earlier and five blocks away, Louis Liranso, 17, was shot in the back and killed by Officer Hyda Hernandez after Liranso, who was unarmed, allegedly lowered his hands and turned toward the officer. Hernandez has been suspended and a grand jury is examining the case. Residents mince no words about the shootings. ``Killer cop Albergo,'' was painted on a blue badge on a wall near the slaying scene. And on the sidewalk where Lebron died were the words, ``Killed by a man in blue.'' But one officer, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said Lebron was a neighborhood tough who bullied others and was ``always on the street, hanging out and drinking.'' The Hispanic officer, who described walking the beat in Bushwick as ``wearing a uniform, standing around and hoping nothing goes on around you,'' said local youths ``won't back down if they're with one another, not even to an officer.'' Lebron was the seventh person fatally shot by police in January; six of the shootings have occurred in Brooklyn. In 1989, 30 people were killed by police; in 1988, 25 died and 14 died in 1987. On Friday, police fatally shot a teen-ager carrying what turned out to be an unloaded gun and 35 vials of crack after he attempted to hold up a man, said Sgt. Nick Vreeland, a police spokesman. Police shot Robert Cole, 13, as he approached officers and was warned three times to drop his handgun, Vreeland said. Lebron was recalled as a happy kid. ``He was always smiling,'' said his 22-year-old brother, Ruben, wiping a tear from his cheek. ``He was the clown of the block. If this tragedy happened to someone else, he'd make us laugh.''

DOC.HEAD: One-Time FBI Agent Leads Liberal Crusades on Capitol Hill
DOC.NOTE: EDS: CORRECTS Commission to Committee in lede; Moved in advance Feb. 2 b0519
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX21 of Feb. 2
DOC.TEXT: Don Edwards got a good look at the House Un-American Activities Committee when he arrived in the nation's capital nearly three decades ago. He never wanted to see anything like it again. Edwards, 75, is now in his 14th term as a Democratic representative from California. During those years this one-time Young Republican and former FBI agent has acquired a reputation as one of the House's most outspoken yet effective civil libertarians. Conservatives grumble that he has thwarted them on abortion, school prayer and a wide range of other potentially explosive issues. Liberals, meanwhile, have come to venerate him for his willingness to speak out when others fear the political consequences. When President Bush launched his war on drugs, for example, Edwards warned that the president's proposals would move the country ever closer to ``a police state.'' ``In a free society, values are not imposed by wholesale arrests and imprisonment of minor offenders,'' he declared. He blasted Bush as ``trigger happy'' in Panama, much as he had called the U.S. invasion of Grenada under Ronald Reagan ``international outlawry.'' This year, Edwards is a chief sponsor of legislation to counteract Supreme Court rulings on job bias that dismayed civil rights forces last year. He also is pushing a bill to erase the impact of a 1989 ruling that widened the power of states to restrict abortions. He concedes that chances of approval this year are not the best but plans full-scale hearings in his Judiciary subcommittee anyway, doubtless with an eye to driving home the election-year message. If anti-crime legislation currently in the Senate reaches the House, the spotlight again is likely to fall on Edwards. He makes no bones about his dislike for a provision that would ease restrictions on the kind of evidence prosecutors may introduce in criminal trials. Despite his combative role, Edwards' presence is far from fierce. His affability has made him popular in the House despite his naysaying. Over the congressional recess, he grew a moustache for the first time in his life but told an interviewer that top aide Roberta Haeberle had ``ordered'' him to shave it off. ``I have to,'' he chortled. Born in San Jose, the heart of the district he now represents, Edwards was educated in public schools there, Stanford University and Stanford law school. Before coming to Washington, he was an FBI agent, a naval intelligence and gunnery officer and founder of a title insurance business. So conservative was Edwards in younger days that he became a leader of California Young Republicans and once led a candlelight demonstration of support for Richard Nixon. Over the years, he has given a variety of reasons for his 180-degree political turn. They have included his experiences in the Navy in World War II and the advent of nuclear weapons. In an interview, he suggested the chief catalyst was that ``when I got here in January 1963 I was terribly offended by the House Un-American Activities Committee.'' Edwards was a stern critic of the committee, whose hearings into alleged communist subversion in the 1950s were labeled ``witch hunts'' by liberals. It was Edwards who offered the resolution in the Democratic Caucus that led to abolition of the panel, whose name by that time had been changed to the House Internal Security Committee. ``I remember the day we did it in,'' he says with evident satisfaction. The panel's once dreaded files are today locked up for 50 years and stored in a Capitol Hill basement under custody of the House Judiciary Committee. As chairman of the Judiciary Committee's subcommittee on civil and constitutional rights, Edwards has considerable power to block legislation dear to conservatives. And he has done so often, especially in the case of proposed amendments to the Constitution. He has blocked amendments to ban abortion, halt school busing, restrict the president to a single term and require a balanced budget, among other things, by locking them up in his subcommittee and throwing away the key. As a result, the proposals never reach the House floor for a vote. ``Don Edwards is the guardian of the Constitution,'' says Ralph Neas, executive director of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights. ``And his subcommittee has been a graveyard for regressive and unconstitutional legislation, so he has blocked the right-wing agenda as well as implemented the progressive agenda on civil rights.'' Rep. Henry J. Hyde, R-Ill., once complained that Edwards' panel is ``the Bermuda Triangle of proposed constitutional amendments.'' In Edwards' view, the Constitution has worked just fine and doesn't need to be tampered with, especially not with proposals to restrict civil and individual rights. ``The subcommittee that I chair takes very seriously its responsibility to protect the Constitution,'' he says. ``I think that it is my obligation to use every legitimate weapon that we have to defend the Constitution.'' In recent years, just two proposed amendments have emerged from the committee. One would provide the District of Columbia with House voting rights. The other is the Equal Rights Amendment. ``We think that would be beneficial,'' Edwards says. ``I'm sure he takes heat'' for his outspoken ways, says Althea Simmons, chief lobbyist for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, ``because civil rights is sometimes in fashion and sometimes out of fashion, but you can count on Don Edwards whether its fashionable or not.'' ``Not only does he almost always vote correctly from our point of view but he is willing to speak out on very controversial issues,'' says Morton Halperin, head of the Washington office of the American Civil Liberties Union. Edwards pooh-poohs the political dangers. He cites his first vote against funds for the Un-American Activities Committee. The clerk was so surprised that he did a double take and called Edwards' name again. ``It hit the fan back home,'' recalls Edwards, ``but then before you know it, people were saying, `Well, it wasn't much of a committee anyway.''' Democrats say Edwards's constituents for the most part see him as a nice guy and don't worry too much about his crusading. Their relaxed view, however, was not shared by Edwards' one-time boss, the late FBI Director J. Edgar Hoover. ``He didn't like criticism,'' the congressman recalls. ``I felt it was my duty to criticize the agency.'' Some time back when Edwards was going through some personal turmoil he considered leaving Congress and went so far as to announce his retirement. On the wall in his Watergate apartment today is a framed copy of an FBI memo reporting his decision. The director's comment was scrawled at the bottom: ``Good riddance _ H.'' It was more than a little premature _ that was 20 years ago and Edwards soon changed his mind and ran for re-election after all.

DOC.HEAD: Government Buffeted by 1970s Dirty-Tricks Allegations
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: If the allegations are to be believed, right-wing extremists in the MI5 intelligence service schemed to portray two former prime ministers and an array of other politicians as terrorist dupes and Soviet stooges. These lurid tales, once confined to the political fringes, have suddenly gained a measure of credibility through a series of official disclosures. Although the allegations date back years before she came to power, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher finds herself caught in mounting clamor for an inquiry. The basic claim is that in 1973-74, when Britain was suffering from Irish separatist violence, trade union militancy and weak government, secret service right-wingers plotted to destabilize any politician, from Prime Ministers Harold Wilson and Edward Heath downward, who didn't share their hard-line anti-communist views. The main source of these claims is Colin Wallace, a former army press officer in his native Northern Ireland, who says his secret job was to spread disinformation. Wallace, 46, says he didn't mind using his natural charm and air of trustworthiness to spread lies about terrorists at the height of the province's troubles in the early 1970s. But he says he became uneasy when the disinformation campaign, code-named ``Clockwork Orange,'' turned against politicians. ``We were fabricating information that alleged that key individuals were corrupt in terms of their moral, political or financial behavior through their links with communists or their extramarital activities,'' Wallace said in an interview. Wallace says his disenchantment grew over suspicions that homosexual abuse at a Belfast boys' orphanage was covered up to protect or blackmail senior unidentified figures. In 1975, Wallace was dismissed for leaking a document to a journalist. He insists the leak was part of his job, and that the dismissal was contrived to silence him. Wallace says this was followed by a series of attempts to destroy his credibility by portraying him as a fantasist. In 1981, he was jailed for manslaughter _ a frame-up, he claims. Released in 1986, he has sought to interest the media in his story, with limited success, until Tuesday, when Armed Forces Minister Archie Hamilton told Parliament that recently discovered papers suggested the possibility that Wallace was indeed under verbal instructions to engage in disinformation. Hamilton also confirmed some of Wallace's specific claims, such as that the dirty tricks included using forged CIA identity cards in 1973. Hamilton insisted the disinformation was directed only at the Irish Republican Army, and never expanded to smear politicians. He said the operation had no clearance from senior officials, and was shut down in the mid-1970s. But it was the first admission by a government official that a dirty-tricks campaign existed, and that Wallace was part of it. It triggered uproar in Parliament and the media. The next day, Mrs. Thatcher disclosed that several statements she and other ministers had made on the matter ``were incorrect or require clarification.'' She said these past statements had relied on information provided by civil servants, and that there had been ``errors in the handling of departmental papers.'' But she stood by her previous statements that there was no evidence of politicians being smeared. The events in question predate 1975, when Mrs. Thatcher succeeded Edward Heath as Conservative Party leader. But they are an embarrassment, given her record of unwavering support for the security services. Wallace has a file in his handwriting which he says consists of notes fed to him in the 1970s by ``security service intelligence officers'' to be used against politicians. The notes, reproduced in a book about his case, are mainly insinuations about alleged Soviet influence over the Labor Party, such as the bizarre theory that the KGB murdered party leader Hugh Gaitskell to make way for the supposedly pro-Soviet Harold Wilson. Merlyn Rees, the chief minister in Northern Ireland during part of the disinformation campaign, displayed on television a pro-IRA leaflet which he said had been doctored to include his and other Labor politicians' names. Conservative Party moderates, including former Prime Minister Heath, also turn up in Wallace's notes. The conservative Daily Telegraph, in an editorial, dismissed Wallace as ``a loose cannon'' who was being exploited to embarrass the government, and Wallace's critics say that having once been paid to lie, he can't expect to be believed now. Wallace replies: ``Don't believe me; have a look for yourselves. All the evidence is there.'' An inquiry has been ordered into whether Wallace was unfairly dismissed. But opposition lawmakers, as well as a few Tories, want a much broader inquiry. ``This will not go away. There is no hiding place,'' Rees warned In Parliament. ``The next Labor government will look at it and those who are hiding things from this government had better remember that.''

DOC.HEAD: Lawmaker Disciplined For Singing Spiritual
DOC.TEXT: A black lawmaker who led students in singing a spiritual on Martin Luther King's birthday has been told she will lose her committee assignment for violating the chamber's rules of decorum. House of Delegates Speaker R. Clayton Mitchell Jr. said Friday that Juanita D. Miller defied him after he refused her request to let a high school group sing on the House floor Jan. 15. ``It is a disciplinary action. She and everyone has to know that open defiance is not the way,'' Mitchell said. ``Certain things are followed by tradition.'' As Miller, a Democrat from Prince George's County, finished an emotional speech about the slain civil rights leader, she began singing ``Give Us This Day,'' and the choir joined in from the visitors' gallery. She said the students began singing spontaneously. Mitchell is ``going to flog Juanita Miller for being an uppity black delegate,'' said Wayne Curry, a black lawyer and president of the Prince George's County Chamber of Commerce. ``He wants to make her behave and put her in the closet in the big house.'' Mitchell, who is white, cited a House policy barring non-members from performing in the chamber. Not all legislators perceived racial overtones in the move. ``I think it's a matter of internal discipline,'' said Sen. Albert R. Wynn, also a Prince George's Democrat and one of six blacks in the 47-member Senate. ``I don't think it's racial.'' Miller said she was told Mitchell would reassign her from the House Economic Matters Committee, which oversees business, banking, consumer and labor laws, to the Judiciary Committee. The two committees are about equally prestigious, although members of Economic Matters tend to receive more campaign contributions from industry groups they regulate. Miller noted that the House has observed St. Patrick's Day for decades by having a non-member sing ``Danny Boy.'' ``I want to see what happens on St. Patrick's Day this year,'' she said. ``Is (Mitchell) telling me, as an African-American, that we can't do this but they can because it's been done for 20 years?''

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of `Discouraged Workers' Part of Hidden Unemployment
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Americans who have stopped looking for work because they are discouraged are part of a ``hidden unemployment'' problem that some analysts say boosts the real jobless rate to around 8 percent. The Labor Department reported Friday that the nation's unemployment rate, or the number of Americans actively seeking work, held steady in January at 5.3 percent for the eighth straight month. So-called discouraged workers, however, are not included in the department's monthly unemployment figure, an exclusion some analysts consider misleading. Those experts also think a percentage of ``under-employed'' workers, or those who hold part-time jobs but would rather be full-time, should be included to give a more accurate picture of the nation's jobless problem. ``We think including those numbers would give a truer picture of what's going on,'' said Candice Johnson, a spokeswoman for the 14.2 million-member AFL-CIO. ``The unemployment rate hides a lot of things and masks many of the problems with our economy. We need to be taking a broader look,'' said Barry Bluestone, a political economist at the University of Massachusetts. Because the number of discouraged workers tends to rise and fall with economic swings, some economists believe those people _ or at least some of them _ should be counted in the unemployment figures. There were about 827,000 discouraged workers in the final quarter of 1989 _ the last period for which figures are available _ while 1.8 million Americans had given up on looking for work at the height of the 1982 recession. ``The number increases during recessions and decreases during good times. If you believe a growth in the number of discouraged workers means an increase in unemployment, then it should be counted,'' said Sar Levitan, an economist at George Washington University. Discouraged workers have been overlooked as the nation enjoys a relatively low and steady jobless rate, according to some analysts. ``There's been relatively low unemployment for the past few years, and those left behind are being forgotten. By and large, we pay very little attention to them,'' Levitan said. In the Labor Department's unemployment report for December, a quarterly report showed that had all discouraged workers been counted, along with half of the involuntary part-timers, the unemployment rate would have been 7.9 percent. However, others contend the Labor Department includes too many people when calculating the official unemployment level, such as students and those who have been jobless only for a few weeks. ``There are as many people who think we overestimate as there are those who think we underestimate,'' said Deborah Klein, an economist with the department's Bureau of Labor Statistics. Some discouraged workers have lacked jobs in months and therefore should not be considered part of the workforce, Ms. Klein said. ``It's a state of mind. Two people in the same situation might respond differently,'' she said. The argument over what information to include has been going on since measurements for unemployment were defined in the 1940s, Ms. Klein said. Over the years, outside commissions have studied and refined the definitions. Congress does not control the guidelines. ``It is not willy-nilly, though it is not mandated. We would not feel comfortable with wholesale changes. The definition is one that's stood the test of time,'' Ms. Klein said. Levitan headed the last commission to study the issue and recommended in 1979 that further review be given to including a portion of discouraged workers in the official unemployment figure. When the Reagan administration took office, officials cited a lack of resources in turning down the request, Levitan said. About half of those who classify themselves as discouraged workers should be counted as unemployed, Levitan said, which would still put the unemployment figure above the government's official rate. Bluestone and a colleague, labor historian Jim Green, said many of the discouraged workers probably lost high-paying factory jobs in the recent manufacturing slump and cannot bring themselves to accept lower wages. ``If I were in that situation, I would probably also say, `Geez. What's the point? I'm working only to be poor,''' Green said. ``It used to be that if you worked hard and saved your money, things would improve. It's not necessarily like that anymore.''

DOC.HEAD: Vets Who Built Vietnam Memorial Soliciting Funds
DOC.TEXT: The veterans who built the Vietnam Veterans Memorial are going back to their contributors, this time asking for $376,500 to repair hairline cracks and correct errors in names on the granite wall and pursue a claim against the contractors. The Vietnam Veterans Memorial Fund, Inc., which raised $7 million from the public to build the monument, sent a solicitation last fall to 100,000 addresses, in a mailing to test the likely response, and a revised mailing of 700,000 pieces recently. Further appeals are planned over the course of this year. ``As I write to you today, I desperately hope that great healing spirit still exists, because we need your help urgently,'' reads one of the fund appeals. It is signed by fund president Jan Scruggs, the former infantryman who conceived of the memorial and saw it through to its completion in 1982. ``You see, a number of cracks in the granite wall have been found,'' Scruggs' letter says. ``Eventually we may need to replace these panels. But it is imperative that we buy the stone now. If we wait, the replacement panels won't match the rest of the memorial. ``Our attorneys have filed a claim against the contractors, but that may take years. Quite frankly, your memorial can't wait! ... We need to raise $376,500.'' Of that amount, said Bob Frank, a Virginia accountant who is treasurer of the tax-exempt fund, $90,000 is needed to replace black granite panels which have developed hairline cracks and $111,000 to engrave additional names on the memorial and to replace misspelled names. The remainder is to be set aside to pay the costs of arbitration in the attempt to persuade the contractors to absorb the cost of replacing cracked panels, Frank said. The granite for the replacement panels has been purchased and is weathering at the Quantico Marine Base in Virginia in hopes the new panels will match those on the existing wall, Scruggs said. ``In retrospect, it's something I wished we'd done in 1982,'' he said. From time to time, names have been added when the Defense Department determined that the death of a Vietnam veteran had been the result of war wounds or when misspellings were found. The monument now carries 58,174 names. Most of the errors were on lists provided by the Defense Department, Frank and Scruggs said. They said they hope the fund drive actually will raise between $1 million and $1.5 million, enough to build an endowment for future improvements, repairs and contingencies. Frank said the fund now has $450,000 in the bank. Frank declined to say how effective the mailings have been since they are still undergoing testing. ``It is premature to discuss the outcome, but we are very encouraged,'' he said. Scruggs said, however, that the solicitation was drawing a response from about 5 percent of recipients. He said that was encouraging because charity drives generally get only about a 2 percent return. The appeal is being conducted by a professional fund-raising organization, using rented list of potential donors. Scruggs said the letter was professionally written. Scruggs said previously the fund had staged rock concerts or sought corporate donations to meet such expenses as installing lights and wider walkways and adding names to the 493-foot wall and conducting Veterans Day and Memorial Day ceremonies at the monument. Under an agreement with the National Park Service, the fund pays for permanent changes to the memorial and the government pays for day-to-day maintenance, guards, cleaning and the like, said Park Service spokesman Earle Kittleman. For a number of years, the monument was the most popular visitors' stop in Washington. Now, Kittleman said, the monument and the nearby Lincoln Memorial both draw about the same number of visitors.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats' Choice Involves More Than French Quarter, Speedway
DOC.TEXT: Democrats will have to decide between major meetings next month in New Orleans or Indianapolis, and the rivalry has more to do with philosophy than a preference for pork tenderloin or jambalaya. For party chairman Ronald H. Brown and the members of the Democratic National Committee, the choice was easy. They're going to Indianapolis to showcase Indiana's youthful Democratic governor, Evan Bayh, and tout their chances of capturing the Senate seat once held by Vice President Dan Quayle. Another large group of Democrats, including many of the party's leading officeholders, will convene at the same time in New Orleans. Somehow _ and nobody is willing to call it anything but an accident _ the DNC and the Democratic Leadership Council chose the same dates the last week in March for their meetings. ``It was not some deliberate picking a fight,'' said Brown when asked about the conflict. ``When we set the date, I didn't know about the DLC meeting.'' ``As far as I know it was inadvertent,'' said DLC executive director Al From, who went on to suggest that the most important party business would take place in New Orleans. ``They're (the DNC) not going to do anything,'' he said. ``It's a routine business meeting as opposed to something that might be really spectacular.'' From said the DLC, formed in 1985 by elected officials concerned about what they perceived as the national party's leftward drift, would spend its time in New Orleans discussing an agenda for the '90s ``that will lead this party and the country in a different direction.'' He said that at the DNC sessions ``the same old activists get together and dance on the same ground that people lose on every time.'' Brown will not ignore the DLC. He plans to address its closing session, and deliver a tough message calling on its members to stop bashing the national party. ``I'd be less than honest if I didn't think that some of the speeches that I've heard recently are just kind of gratuitous,'' said the party chairman. He declined to specify which speeches bothered him. But an attack on national Democrats by Sen. Charles Robb, D-Va., seemed to fit the bill. Robb told a DLC meeting that Democrats were in ``a quandary because we have difficulty conceiving of our mission in terms other than federal activism.'' The senator, a former chairman of the DLC and one of its founding members, described the party as ``in thrall to the special interests.'' Brown made it clear he was tired of attacks on the national party. ``We've been moving in a pretty solid, pragmatic, common-sense direction this year and I think everybody acknowledges that,'' he said ``So when folks attack the national party I don't know who they're talking about.'' The chairman said the message he wanted to deliver to the DLC was that while they and the DNC don't always agree ``we're certainly moving in the same direction.'' Shortly after he was elected party chairman last year, Brown attended a DLC meeting and said pointedly that ``I know there are many in this room who were less than wildly enthusiastic about the prospect of Ron Brown being chairman of the Democratic National Committee.'' For Brown, the political attraction of Indianapolis was clear. Party leaders view 34-year-old Bayh, the first Democratic governor of Indiana in 16 years, as a rising star. They also have their eyes set on Republican Sen. Dan Coats, appointed last year to replace Quayle. Coats has yet to be tested in a statewide race. While the DLC will talk issues, the DNC members will discuss the rules for selecting the 1992 presidential nominee. No major changes are foreseen. But the DNC remains the party's governing body, a fact pointed out to From, who responded, ``That is true. They are, at least at the moment.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: ``The Pat Sajak Show,'' reeling in the ratings race against late-nighters Johnny Carson and Arsenio Hall, is undergoing a makeover that will include a round-table chat with guests. Starting Monday, the ``Sajak'' show will feature a new set, new music, less banter with announcer Dan Miller and no exchanges at all with bandleader Tom Scott. On some shows, the host's traditional entrance to applause will be skipped, with Sajak instead already sitting down when the show opens. Michael Weisman, the new executive producer of the 13-month-old CBS show, said the changes are designed to overcome the talk show's ``loser'' image. ``What we're trying to do is make Pat as comfortable as possible, play up his strength and get away from that old cliched talk-show look,'' he said. Celebrity guests and interviews will still be a part of the show, but Weisman also is considering documentary-style pieces on real-life personalities, such as outrageous cab drivers or nutty waitresses.

If someone offers to sell you Roseanne Barr's love letters to her new husband, don't print them unless you want trouble. The letters were stolen, her publicist, Alana Rothstein, said Friday. The star of ``Roseanne'' married fellow comedian Tom Arnold last month. ``We're saying, `Yes, it is for real, and yes, they are stolen, and if somebody decides to publish them, then down the road they'll have to deal with the repercussions.''' Barr's public relations firm had received inquiries from several publishers who had been contacted by someone offering to sell the letters, Rothstein said. She said several of the letters were stolen sometime within the last three weeks.

Italian critics praised the newest film by Federico Fellini, ``The Voice of the Moon,'' which opened in 170 cities throughout the country. Scores of people lined up to see the latest work by the director of ``La Dolce Vita,'' ``8{'' and ``Amarcord.'' The movie opened Thursday. The Milan daily Corriere Della Sera described the film as ``stylistically severe, artistically superior and professionally beyond reproach.'' Fellini's 24th work, the quixotic tale of two lunatics wandering the Italian countryside, did not receive unanimous praise in the capital, however. ``Roman viewers of `The Voice of the Moon' are divided between enthusiasm and boredom,'' the daily La Republica said. The $22.5 million movie features comic actors Roberto Benigni and Paolo Villagio. It will be presented at the Cannes Film Festival in May.

AIDS patient Ryan White has received a ``Mickey'' award from the Mickey Mouse Club. The 14-inch, gold-colored statuette, which is awarded to ``children who make a difference,'' was mailed to the 18-year-old because he was too sick to travel to Florida to receive it, said his mother, Jeanne White. Ryan had been scheduled to be on the ``Mickey Mouse Club Show'' in November and be inducted into the Mickey Mouse Club Hall of Fame. Ryan, a hemophiliac who contracted AIDS from a transfusion, received wide attention in 1985 when his family sued a school near Kokomo for not allowing him to attend. A judge ruled that Ryan should be allowed to attend class because AIDS cannot be spread through casual contact. Since then, Ryan and his family have moved to Cicero, a town of about 3,200, where they were welcomed by the school district. For the last six months, Ryan has been suffering from numerous ailments, including a protein deficiency, Ms. White said.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Former baseball star Steve Garvey and ex-wife have reached an agreement in the child custody battle that at one point landed her in jail, lawyers say. No terms were announced, but after the closed meeting Friday with Superior Court Judge Frances Rothschild, attorney Stephen Kolodny said, ``The nature of the agreement resolves all of the issues before the court.'' He represents Cynthia Truhan, the former Mrs. Garvey. Neither Garvey, the former first baseman for the Los Angeles Dodgers and San Diego Padres, nor his ex-wife appeared in court. The couple have two teen-age daughters. It was not clear what impact the settlement would have on Ms. Truhan's contempt-of-court jail sentence for violating child visitation orders. On Oct. 3, Rothschild ordered her to serve a five-day sentence. But she was released the day she entered jail after an appeals court ruled that Rothschild should have set bail after denying a request for a jury trial.

Conductor and pianist Daniel Barenboim has canceled an appearance because of chicken pox. The 47-year-old musician, who rarely appears in London, had been scheduled to perform Bach's Goldberg Variations at the Barbican performing arts center on Sunday. He pulled out on doctor's orders, the concert hall said Saturday. Barenboim, born in Argentina and reared in Israel, last year was chosen as the next music director of the Chicago Symphony, shortly after his firing as director of the new Paris Opera House. The Chicago appoinment takes effect in the fall of 1991. Barenboim will succeed Sir Georg Solti.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Ethics Probers Ready for `Unpleasant Task'
DOC.TEXT: In a Senate often compared to a club where members take care of their own, the Democratic and Republican leaders of the Ethics Committee are ready to sweep aside ``personal emotions'' and judge the conduct of seven politically troubled colleagues. Chairman Howell T. Heflin, D-Ala., and Vice Chairman Warren B. Rudman, R-N.H., said in interviews that they have an institution to protect and won't be influenced by close relationships or intense media attention. ``We're dealing with the reputation of individuals and the integrity of the institution,'' Rudman said. ``You must find the truth and you must act on it. You cannot be swayed by personal emotions. The public ought to have full confidence that the members of this committee care about the institution more than anything else.'' Added Heflin, ``It's an unpleasant task but it has to be performed'' because the Constitution requires the chambers of Congress to judge the conduct of their own members. ``The integrity of the institution supersedes the clubbiness that might exist.'' Neither Rudman nor Heflin would discuss details of the cases before them, and Rudman said he agreed to be interviewed only so there could be ``a better public understanding'' of the committee's work. The most intense attention is focused on the investigation of five senators who received some $1.3 million from businessman Charles H. Keating Jr. and who intervened with regulators on behalf of his now-failed Lincoln Savings and Loan. The so-called ``Keating Five'' are Republican John McCain of Arizona; and Democrats Dennis DeConcini of Arizona, John Glenn of Ohio, Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan and Alan Cranston of California. The committee also is investigating whether Sen. Alfonse M. D'Amato, R-N.Y., steered federal housing contracts to friends and contributors; and whether Sen. David Durerberger, R-Minn., evaded outside income limits in a book promotion deal, improperly charged the Senate rent for a Minneapolis condominium he partially owned, and received improper reimbursements for trips to the Boston area _ made in part to see his marriage counselor. Rudman admitted the Senate ``is certainly a club in which members protect each other, I suppose in a legislative way.'' But he maintained the ``history of the Senate in recent years is that when serious ethics matters have been brought before us, the importance of the institution transcends personal friendship. I would cite the Harrison Williams case and the Talmadge case.'' In October 1979, the Senate voted 81-15 follow the Ethics Committee's advice and denounced then-Sen. Herman E. Talmadge, D-Ga. for ``reprehensible'' handling of government funds. Sen. Harrison A. Williams Jr., D-N.J., resigned in 1982, just as the Senate was about to go along with the Ethics Committee's recommendation of expulsion. Williams had already been convicted in the bribery and conspiracy investigation known as Abscam. One of his main accusers in the Senate debate was Heflin, then the senior Democrat on the committee, who gave one of the final speeches of the debate urging expulsion. Heflin now says, ``We have to make tough decisions all the time. We have to say no to senators on vital issues that affect their re-election.'' Members often are assigned to the committee by their backgrounds, so it's no accident that Heflin, 68, headed the Alabama Ethics Commission from 1969-71 and was chief justice of the Alabama Supreme Court from 1971-77. Rudman, 59, was attorney general of New Hampshire from 1970-76. Other committee members are Sens. David Pryor, D-Ark.; Terry Sanford, D-N.C.; Jesse Helms, R-N.C. and Trent Lott, R-Miss. Rudman defended committee rules that place the utmost secrecy on the committee's investigative and grand jury phases, before exposing the trial phase to public view. ``I would never, ever, think a preliminary inquiry or an initial review (the grand jury phase) should be publicized step-by-step'' to satisfy the public or news media, he said. ``If you were to trot out every allegation without having the chance to corroborate or carefully draw it out, you'd have people trashed all over the press who might wind up being totally innocent.''

DOC.HEAD: Debt Renegotiation Saves Mexico $1.7 Billion in Interest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th pvs with one graf to CORRECT first name of treasury secretary; picks up 5th pvs: Mexico's total...
DOC.TEXT: Mexico and its foreign creditor banks sign a historic debt reduction agreement Sunday that will save the country $1.7 billion a year in interest and provide a measure of security to the banks. President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has called the renegotiation essential to solving Mexico's economic problems but warned it alone will not guarantee growth. ``The result of the negotiation has been rational for the creditor banks and satisfactory for Mexico,'' Salinas said in a speech Thursday in Switzerland. The first major agreement under U.S. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady's debt reduction strategy will lop $7 billion off Mexico's $48.5 billion commercial bank debt, save $1.7 billion a year of the $9 billion a year the country pays in interest and bring in $1.5 billion in new loans over the next three years. Mexico's total foreign debt is $92 billion, down from $107 billion in 1987, according to the government, the second highest in the developing world after Brazil's $114 billion. Sunday's agreement will be signed by the heads of 15 major banks who made up the so-called ``steering committee'' that negotiated the accord for all the creditor institutions. The new plan gave 460 participating banks three options to reduce Mexico's debt burden: Reduce the principal on their loans to the government by 35 percent, drop interest to a fixed rate of 6.25 percent annually or grant new loans of 25 percent of their outstanding Mexican debt. Many banks combined options. Reductions of the principal account for $20 billion of the renegotiated debt, interest reductions for $22.5 billion and new loans for $6 billion. In exchange, banks picking the principal and interest reductions receive Mexican government bonds for the remaining debt. The bonds are backed by U.S. Treasury zero-coupon bonds and the first 18 months of interest on them is guaranteed by a $7 billion package of multilateral credits and Mexican funds. ``I believe it helped the banks quite a lot. For at least a couple of years more they can feel calmer about the quality of the Mexican debt,'' said Manuel Sanchez, director of the private Center for Analysis and Economic Research. But apart from those in the agreement, few new foreign commercial bank loans are expected, and officials and analysts say the next step toward economic stability is Mexico's. ``What we have to do and what we are doing in Mexico is to create attractive conditions for doing business in Mexico,'' Assistant Treasury Secretary Angel Gurria, the government's debt negotiator, said. Salinas' government has opened the domestic market to imports, stepped up the sale of state-owned enterprises to private ownership, relaxed foreign investment controls and brought down inflation with an economic program that controls wages and prices. If the government continues such steps, Gurria said, money will come. Sanchez warned that the progress toward stabilization is precarious. ``We are on a fine line, very thin, in which any event can make us fall into another crisis,'' he said. The agreement to reduce the debt payments followed Mexico's efforts to repay the interest in recent months, unlike other major Latin debtors. Brazil was $4.4 billion behind in interest payments to private foreign creditors in December. Argentina, which has a $64 billion debt, has about $4 billion in interest overdue.

DOC.HEAD: Utah's Liquor Laws Get Overhaul, But Not Everyone's Happy
DOC.TEXT: Restaurant patrons will no longer have to mix their own cocktails under a bill about to become law in Utah, but critics say the liquor law in the Mormon-dominated state will be as bewildering as ever. ``If they think Utah's joked about now, this is comical,'' said Kurt Nelson, owner of one of the state's ``beer bars,'' which will face new restrictions under the law even as things are loosened up for restaurants. Until 1988, restaurant diners intent on a cocktail had to order a mixer, buy a minibottle of liquor at an in-house package store, return to the table and mix the drink themselves. They could also bring in their own liquor, bought at a state-run liquor store, under the time-honored practice of ``brown-bagging.'' Since 1988, waiters have been permitted to bring minibottles to the table, but the diner still had to do the mixing. Only private clubs, which sell memberships at a minimum of $5 for two weeks, could serve a mixed drink without a meal. The bill that sailed through the Legislature, hungry for tourism and economic growth, brings Utah to the brink of liquor-by-the-drink by allowing licensed restaurants as well as private clubs to serve cocktails at the table. But the drinks will be weaker _ the bill requires that restaurants and clubs use bottle meters that dispense an ounce of liquor; minibottles held 1.7 ounces. And brown-bagging will be prohibited, in restaurants and in beer bars. Utah's restrictive liquor laws date generally from the end of Prohibition in 1930s. Residents may have complained about the laws in the past, but they adjusted. It's tourists that the bill's sponsors were out to accommodate. With tourism an increasingly important part of the economy and the prospect of being selected host of the 1998 Winter Olympics, Utah had to step into the American mainstream, sponsors said. Indeed, the legislation permits lounges at Salt Lake International Airport to sell drinks to travelers, making the airport the state's only ``free-pour'' zone. ``I do think we've made a giant step forward,'' Rep. Stan Smedley said Friday after the bill gained final clearance in the House and Senate. Gov. Norm Bangerter said he'll sign the legislation when it reaches his desk this week. The bill's drafters were keenly aware of the Mormon Church ban on alcohol. The faith counts as members 70 percent of the state's 1.7 million people and more than 90 percent of its 104 lawmakers, and the church's world headquarters are three blocks from the Capitol. ``There was to be no change in the state's philosophy of control, availability to those who do drink and consideration of those who don't,'' said Sen. Richard Carling, chairman of the task force that fashioned the bill. Last year, calls from church representatives to senators doomed a bill that would have allowed passengers in limousines and chartered buses to bring alcohol aboard. This time, church officials said they would not oppose the new bill, virtually guaranteeing passage. Among its other changes, the new legislation allows limo and bus passengers to ride and drink, with some limitations. But liquor opponents have much to cheer about in the new law. Besides the crackdown on brown-bagging, which beer bar owners say will eliminate their highly profitable sales of mixers, the new law puts an end to ``happy hours'' and retail sales of beer by the keg. The demise of happy hour sounds ``the death knoll for a lot of taverns,'' said Greg Arata, who owns one of the 415 beer bars in Utah. Perhaps the most hard-hit will be rural beer bars unable to afford the license and equipment necessary to upgrade their status to that of a private club or a restaurant, said Utah Tavern Owners Association lobbyist Randy Horiuchi. Horiuchi also warned that old habits die hard, and bartenders will find themselves in the difficult position of trying to keep customers from sneaking in liquor. ``What laws like this do is force Utahns to break the laws,'' he said. That doesn't bother tavern owner Nelson, who's seen too many customers overdo it. But Nelson said visitors will be confused if they can get a drink at the airport, only to find themselves searching for a club or licensed restaurant in Salt Lake City or nearby ski resorts. `They'll stop at the airport, have a drink, then get to New York or L.A. and say, `Hey, I had a drink in Utah,''' Nelson said. ``That's just duping the traveler.''

DOC.HEAD: Pattern, Progress Difficult to Detect in Mail Bomb Probe
LaserPhoto MY1
DOC.TEXT: FBI agents have grilled a Bible-quoting junk dealer, fingerprinted an alleged gun runner and dug up a septic tank looking for a typewriter, but how close they are to solving a series of mail bombings that killed a judge and a lawyer no one is saying. Scores of federal agents, who set up offices in a vacant bank building two weeks ago, have made some splashy raids that provided grist for rumor mills. But it appears no arrests are imminent in the December bombings. The latest action by the FBI, a daylong search Friday of the home and print shop of an Enterprise man indicted on gun exportation charges, left investigators with more than a dozen boxes of confiscated documents to examine. Doug Marshall, an FBI spokesman in Mobile, said Friday the investigation here would continue indefinitely. The most well-known figure in the investigation, salvage store owner Robert Wayne O'Ferrell, has been closely scrutinized but not charged. ``It's time for them to bark up another tree,'' he said Friday. Brian Fleming, the print shop operator subjected to the search on Friday, has not been charged either. Fleming and his wife have been fingerprinted but not questioned in the case, said their attorney, John Knowles. Knowles said authorities are making a futile attempt to link the bomb cases to Fleming's indictment on a charge of conspiring to export firearms, reportedly to Northern Ireland. Fleming pleaded innocent and is free on $5,000 bail. O'Ferrell said that he has made copies of court documents at Fleming's print shop but that he doesn't know Fleming well. Killed in the December bomb attacks were Judge Robert Vance of the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals and civil rights attorney Robert Robinson of Savannah, Ga. Bombs were also mailed to the 11th Circuit headquarters in Atlanta and an NAACP chapter in Jacksonville, Fla., but did not explode. A much-coveted clue is the typewriter used to write a letter, signed ``Americans for a Competent Federal Judicial System,'' claiming responsibility for the bombs and threatening more violence. The FBI has searched pawn shops, O'Ferrell's store, a septic tank, a lake, schools, a trash dump and Fort Rucker for the typewriter but apparently has not found it. Federal sources have said the letter, received in December by an Atlanta TV station, appeared to have been written on the same typewriter as a document O'Ferrell prepared in 1988 in a case before the 11th Circuit. Vance sat on a panel that ruled against O'Ferrell when O'Ferrell sued his former employer, Gulf Life Insurance Co., in an employment compensation case. In a legal brief he prepared while acting as his own attorney, O'Ferrell called the judicial system corrupt. FBI officials are quick to note that the investigation is continuing full-scale in other cities, notably Atlanta. But it is Enterprise, a pleasant, growth-conscious city of about 20,000, that is receiving most of the attention. Until the agents moved in, the town was best known for a 10-foot monument of a boll weevil. Holding court from behind the cash register at his junk shop or atop its loading dock, O'Ferrell, a 46-year-old part-time preacher, dispenses small-town wisdom and proclaims his innocence several times daily. ``Two people know I'm innocent,'' he often says. ``Me and Jesus.'' Visitors have been impressed by O'Ferrell's calmness in the wake of such scrutiny. Pressed, however, he acknowledges the spotlight has bothered his family. If he is cleared, O'Ferrell said last week, he expects an apology from the government. ``They can't pay me for what they've done to me,'' O'Ferrell said. ``They don't have that kind of money.'' At times, more than 100 agents from the FBI, Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms and the Postal Inspection Service have worked on the investigation. Federal authorities defend the numbers, even though they have not produced an arrest. ``A hundred agents on a case like this? That's not overkill,'' Justice Department spokesman Doug Tillett said. ``In law enforcement you always should err on the side of having more than enough troops rather than a shortage.''

DOC.HEAD: Retailers Study Ways to Keep Goods Out of Shoplifters' Pockets
DOC.TEXT: When Don had a tough day at the office he didn't unwind at the health club or corner bar. ``I'd go to a store and steal,'' said the highly paid engineer, who sought counseling last year to end his 20-year spree of thefts. ``It was my release. I was good at it and it didn't take much time.'' But the ``middle-class look'' that Don credits with helping him avoid the suspicions of store detectives is becoming less of an armor as retailers and security industry executives try new tactics in the war on shoplifting. Don, who spoke on condition his name not be used, told his story Friday at a conference of retail and security executives seeking to gain an edge. Shoplifting has risen 35 percent since the mid-1980s and now equals about 2 percent of all U.S. retail sales excluding gas and car purchases. Conference speakers said high-technology surveillance and psychological methods will probably lead the battle to reverse the trend. In the 1960s, Deerfield Beach-based Sensormatic Electronics Corp., the conference sponsor, developed the plastic tags that hang on many store garments today. Recently, the company introduced tags that sound an alarm if tampered with. Other projects include a surveillance camera that simultaneously monitors the cash register and sales clerk. Some stores have tried mixing background music with barely audible voices _ so-called subliminal messages _ stressing honesty and anti-theft themes. And, experts say, cameras programmed to watch for known shoplifters may someday be used. ``It would be programmed to recognize face patterns and analyze the customers as they walk in,'' said Bob McCrie, editor of the New York-based publication Security Letter. ``These are the type of things that are coming.'' Don epitomized one of the conference's themes: Shoplifters range from the impoverished to the elite and often steal simply for the emotional high. Don figures that before he sought counseling in May, he stole more than $160,000 worth of merchandise _ much of which he threw away _ with only 47 apprehensions and nine prosecutions. He once spent 14 days in jail on paid vacation from work. ``Who would suspect me? I had that middle-class look,'' he said. ``If you feel comfortable in a store, you become a wrecking ball and could take anything you wanted.'' Peter Berlin, a former department store security chief who runs Shoplifters Anonymous in Jericho, N.Y., said, ``There is no profile of shoplifters. I've caught them all: nuns, policemen, attorneys. It doesn't matter.'' An estimated 20 million Americans steal from a store at least once a year, said Berlin. Yet the thief is caught only about one in 50 times. Theft is also a greater concern among retailers now because increased competition and low inflation keep stores from simply raising prices to cover losses, called ``inventory shrinkage'' in the retail vernacular. Shoplifting is still mostly committed by women, although crack addicts of both sexes have turned to stealing to support their habits, conference participants said. McCrie said a 1981 study in Spokane, Wash., found 59 percent of shoplifters were women, mostly in their teens or 20s. The study also concluded divorced, separated or widowed women are more likely to shoplift. ``Many people see shoplifting as a substitute for gratification of unmet needs,'' said McCrie. ``They could be personal, psychological, revenge _ any number of things.'' Only 4 percent of shoplifters are diagnosed as true kleptomaniacs with an obsessive desire to steal, he said. Berlin said studies indicate between 1.5 percent and 3 percent of all shoppers may attempt to shoplift. But he found the rate rose to about 6 percent in department store costume jewelry sections. Berlin also said employee theft has become an increasing problem because of lower hiring standards and the takeover mania of the 1980s that reduced job security. ``There's a feeling that, `I better take care of myself because nobody else will,' and they are not wrong,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Will Propose Eliminating Communist Monopoly on Power, Report Says
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will ask the Communist Party leadership to break its seven-decade hammerlock on power and accept the possibility of competing political parties, a Soviet news agency said Saturday. The report also said the Soviet leader would propose a complete change in the party structure and tacitly endorse the concept of private ownership. The stunning disclosures came just two days before a party Central Committee meeting that is expected to be a forum on the future course of the nation and probably the most crucial test of Gorbachev's five years in power. If Gorbachev does indeed ask the party to break its monopoly on power, and the increasingly splintered party leadership agrees, it could thrust the superpower into a cycle of change that already is being played out on a smaller scale throughout the East bloc. A bitter fight over reform in expected at the closed-door Central Committee meeting on Monday and Tuesday. Progressives are calling for a multiparty system and a virtual apology for decades of dictatorship. Diehard Communists want to retain their lock on power and keep central planning and collective farming, which have brought the country to economic ruin. This is likely the last Central Committee meeting before local and republic elections in the coming weeks, where hard-liners could suffer humiliating defeats as did many of their colleagues last spring, when the nation held its first competitive elections. The Soviet news agency Interfax says Gorbachev wants to trim the Central Committee from 251 members to 200, which could jeopardize the votes of many hard-liners in the key policy-making body. Gorbachev, as usual, has placed himself squarely in the middle, according to the Interfax report. He is proposing a new Communist Party platform where ``the multiparty principle is not rejected, but is not treated as a panacea,'' reported Interfax, a news service of Radio Moscow. The platform says the party ``will fight for its leading role, but assume no state or government powers, nor lay any claim to having its role set down in the Constitution,'' Interfax said. An attempt to remove the Communists' guarantee of supremacy inscribed in the Soviet Constitution failed during the December session of parliament. The Soviet Union, ruled exclusively by the Communists since a few months after the 1917 Russian Revolution, is the last remaining Warsaw Pact nation to give the Communists a guaranteed monopoly on power. Gorbachev's nurturing of greater social freedoms sparked the changes in the East bloc, but the pace of reform in those nations have quickly outraced change in the Soviet Union, overhauling the ideological landscape of Eastern Europe. Interfax also said Gorbachev's platform does not reject the concept of private ownership, but did not say if that includes ownership of land and businesses by individuals. The Central Committee is expected to vote on the platform, for presentation to a full party congress of about 5,000 delegates scheduled for October. Tass said Saturday some party members have suggested holding the party congress earlier, in two parts, with local party elections between the two sessions. The fight in the Soviet Communist Party comes at a time of stunningly rapid change. Since the Central Committee last met six weeks ago: _ The Communist split has come into the open, with reformers threatening to form their own party if changes are not made. _ The Soviet Union itself tumbled closer to fracturing with open rebellion in Azerbaijan, and peaceful independence movements in the Baltics, particularly in Lithuania, where Gorbachev promised the people a choice on secession. _ In four countries of Eastern Europe, the price paid by Communist hard-liners has risen. Men who fell from power in the autumn are now being arrested. Only in Poland and Hungary, where reform has come most gradually, are former dictators still free. The Soviet press, too, has been full of portents of political change. A letter to the editor of Pravda suggested, ``The Communist idea is dead,'' while Moscow News reported suggestions the party be disbanded. Economic deprivation only worsens with each passing day as more daily necessities disappear from store shelves. ``It has become increasingly difficult to prove that an American worker with $2,000 a month in wages is suffering from exploitation, while his Soviet counterpart enjoys its absence with an income of 237 rubles ($395) a month,'' said Pravda this week. Gorbachev heads into Monday's showdown strengthened by the world's horrified reaction to a broadcast report that he might resign as party chief, and by a series of disgraces suffered recently by hard-liners. Gorbachev denied the report of his possible resignation after letting the world stew for 12 hours. Izvestia ran a front-page article Friday noting the report had already had its effect in Washington, where a cut in American military troops in Europe had just been proposed. Progressives and even ordinary citizens sick of shortages worried that the alternative to Gorbachev would be far worse. The Interfax report also says Gorbachev is proposing a new party structure, with an elected chairman and two deputy chairmen. However, Tass on Saturday said individual party members have suggested that delegates to the party congress, which would formally adopt the new platform, should be chosen in direct elections from the district level. The Interfax report also says the Gorbachev platform calls for a new executive committee that would include representatives of the 15 republics. It was not clear if this would replace the current Politburo. The party's rules of unity and secrecy, already being broken, could be eased under the various proposals. The Gorbachev plan would permit minority viewpoints but not formal factions inside the party, Interfax said. In a strong hint of impending demotions, Tass said Saturday the many rank-and-file Communists blame the Central Committee for the slow pace of reform.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Faces Mammoth Task in Finding Peaceful Solution For South Africa
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 10th pvs, `In the...' to ADD more background on apartheid, South African racial groups. Pickup 11th, `Major pillars...'
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: With a single stunning speech, President F.W. de Klerk has set South Africa on the road to a new future after decades of racial confrontation and white domination. De Klerk repudiated the white supremacist principles that guided his ruling National Party for decades and cleared the way for blacks _ including Communists and guerrilla leaders _ to take part in political life. ``The aim is a totally new and just constitutional dispensation in which every inhabitant will enjoy equal rights, treatment and opportunity in every sphere,'' he told the nation at the opening of Parliament on Friday. In a speech that would have been unthinkable one or two years ago, the president ended bans on the African National Congress and other anti-apartheid groups that have waged a 30-year guerrilla struggle against white minority rule, repealed many repressive regulations and promised to end the state of emergency used to stifle dissent. The speech was a remarkable change for a party that created apartheid to permanently exclude blacks from power. H.F. Verwoerd, a former prime minister and the architect of apartheid, set the tone for Nationalist rule when he said in 1961: ``When I talk of the nation of South Africa, I talk to the white people of South Africa.'' De Klerk warned that the quest for a peaceful solution would not be easy and the country would face many challenges. He appealed to all South Africans to work with him. Government leaders and their opponents agree that nobody knows just how to solve the country's problems. In a front page editorial Saturday hailing de Klerk's reforms, The Cape Times newspaper said, ``We have now entered a more dangerous phase of the inevitable process of change, where the situation is going to be much more volatile... '' De Klerk deliberately avoided many major questions facing South Africa, including the extent to which the government is willing to share power with blacks and the pace at which it will make reforms. In the past, de Klerk has said he opposes black majority rule _ the main goal of all anti-apartheid groups, which say they will not accept anything but full democracy with no special status for any ethnic group. Apartheid sets up a racially segregated society in which South Africa's 28 million blacks have no vote in national affairs. The 5 million whites control the economy and maintain separate housing, schools and health services. Major pillars of apartheid, such as laws segregating residential areas and public amenities, remain in force. Power and wealth are overwhelmingly concentrated in the hands of whites. Government ministers declined to say when apartheid laws would be abolished, saying such changes would have to be negotiated. But de Klerk promised that the Separate Amenities Act, which allows local governments to segregate public facilities, would be repealed during the current session of Parliament. While most anti-apartheid leaders hailed de Klerk's initiative, they warned that the government had not gone far enough. Exiled ANC leaders welcomed the reforms, but said there could be no instant peace. ``An armistice can only take place once a democratic government is in place,'' said an ANC spokesman. Denis Worrall, leader of the white liberal Democratic Party, said the search for a political solution could resemble the tortured quest for peace in Northern Ireland and the Middle East. The government is not in danger of collapsing, and de Klerk is offering to negotiate from a powerful position. The government is in full control of the country, black resistance is minimal, and the ANC has admitted its guerrilla campaign has been largely ineffectual. The biggest obstacle facing de Klerk and his allies may be white opposition. De Klerk, as leader of the white Afrikaners of Dutch descent who dominate South African politics, must maintain substantial white support as he attempts to work out a solution. Government leaders have expressed concern about a terroist campaign by white extremists. Andries Treurnicht, leader of the pro-apartheid Conservative Party, reacted with fury to de Klerk's plans and demanded an immediate general election. ``We say he has no mandate for doing the drastic things he intends doing,'' the leader of the main white opposition party said. De Klerk will have to persuade whites to accept change, overcoming centuries of ingrained conviction of white superiority and privilege. Most political observers say the president does not have much time to change the hearts and minds of whites if he is to maintain his momentum.
