There is little sign that most whites are ready to share schools, hospitals and other amenities with blacks or to accept a division of wealth and opportunity with the masses of poor blacks. Many whites reacted to de Klerk's speech with caution and concern. Some whites expressed fears about their future and safety in a black majority state. ``Whites are feeling a bit insecure. There is reservation in the hearts of whites,'' said one white businessman after hearing de Klerk's speech. De Klerk has gained respect and time from many South Africans who hope he will now lead them to the peaceful solution he has promised. The question, he acknowledges, is whether that time and support will be adequate to forge a solution acceptable to the majority.

DOC.HEAD: Ethnic Albanians Seek Talks With Gov't to Try to End Clashes
LaserPhoto PR13
DOC.TEXT: Five ethnic Albanian groups on Saturday asked the government to investigate reports that police fired without warning on protesters in Kosovo province, where unrest has killed 25 people and injured 120. About 300 ethnic Albanians chanting ``Democracy! Democracy!'' rallied Saturday in the town of Podujevo, and a smaller group was dispersed by riot police in the provincial capital of Pristina, 20 miles to the south. A government statement, however, said there were ``visible signs'' that the situation was calming down in Kosovo. Thousands of police backed by tanks and planes maintained patrols in the southern province. The ethnic Albanian majority in Kosovo has demanded increased autonomy from the largest of Yugoslavia's six republics, Serbia, which said it tightened control over the province last year to protect the Serbian minority from harassment. More than 100,000 Kosovo residents have signed a petition calling for an end to the year-old state of emergency and for democratic elections, said Veton Surroi, head of the regional chapter of the Yugoslav Union for Democratic Initiative. The petition also called for an end to the violence. In an English-language statement, the five ethnic Albanian groups said they supported the government's attempt to resolve the unrest and asked for talks. A statement urged the government to investigate reports that police fired without cause or warning several times in the past week, killing people in several villages. It said authorities used ``classic forms of state terrorism'' to put down ethnic Albanian calls for greater autonomy from Serbia. It demanded ``an immediate ban on the use of lethal firearms by police, establishing a commission to investigate all alleged murders as a way to defuse the explosive situation that threatens to turn into a bloody civil war.'' On Friday, President Janez Drnovsek appealed to ethnic Albanians and Serbs in the province to stop the violence, which he said threatened the process of economic and political reform nationwide. The government has pledged to allow a multiparty democracy and observe human rights according to internationally recognized standards. Drnovsek has said that the use of arms is in no group's interest and has repeatedly called for a dialogue. But officials of Serbia, who accuse the ethnic Albanians of wanting to secede from Yugoslavia and join neighboring Albania, have demanded that opposition leaders first renounce any such intention before talks can begin. Yugoslavia's liberal northern regions of Slovenia and Croatia have backed ethnic Albanian calls for greater self-government and blamed the unrest on Serbian moves, backed by nationalist Serbian leader Sloboban Milosevic, to reduce the province's autonomy. On Saturday, the official Tanjug news agency said 25 ethnic Albanians have died over the past 11 days of protests. It did not report any new deaths overnight, however, and there was no explanation for the increase in the official death toll from 21 on Thursday. In addition, 75 demonstrators and 45 riot policemen were injured in the clashes, the agency said, citing official sources. The groups that made the statement were the Kosovo branch of the Yugoslav Union for Democratic Initiative, the Committee for Human Rights and Freedoms, the Democratic League of Kosova, the Society of Philosophers and Sociologists of Kosova, and the Initiating Board for the Youth Parliament. Kosova is the name Albanians use to refer to the province.

DOC.HEAD: Billie Sol Estes Files for Bankruptcy
DOC.TEXT: Billie Sol Estes, a confidant of Lyndon Johnson who went to prison for a fertilizer-tank scam in the 1960s, has filed for bankruptcy, claiming debts of $52 million and assets of just $150. The Chapter 7 filing in U.S. Bankruptcy Court came after the flim-flam artist's indictment last year on charges of plotting to manufacture container cargo trailers with trade secrets stolen from another company. He is free on $10,000 bail. Estes, 64, and his wife, Patsy, cited debts that include $50 million in back taxes and interest, said his attorney, Charles McDonald. ``This could get Uncle Sam off his back,'' McDonald said Friday. Under Chapter 7, assets are liquidated to pay off creditors. Estes reported a monthly income of $700, from Social Security, a far cry from the days when the agricultural tycoon's personal fortune was estimated as high as $400 million. In court papers Estes noted his only activity as ``sewing in home for Patsy.'' Estes was convicted in 1963 in a multimillion-dollar swindle involving non-existent fertilizer tanks backed by federal agriculture loans. He went to prison in 1965 and was paroled in 1971. He went back to prison in 1979 for fraud. On the eve of his release in 1983, Estes said, ``I'm just one drink away from being a drunk and just one deal away from being back in prison.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Upholds Firing of Man Who Used Ladies' Room Before Sex Change
DOC.TEXT: A judge has ruled that Boeing Co. took reasonable steps to accommodate a software engineer who was preparing for a sex-change operation before it fired him for wearing a necklace and using the women's bathroom. Superior Court Judge Fred Rasmussen affirmed Friday that state law banning discrimination against the handicapped applied to the former employee's psychosexual condition, known as gender dysphoria, or transsexualism. But the judge found no discrimination by Boeing against the plaintiff, who is now a woman. The American Civil Liberties Union represented the 34-year-old woman, known to the court as Jane Doe, who was employed by Boeing Computer Services as a male from 1978 to 1985. The former employee underwent a sex change operation in 1988. The lawsuit, the first of its kind in the state, accused the company of discriminating against Doe because of her physical and mental handicap and of refusing to provide any reasonable accommodation for her disability. Doe was fired in 1985 for wearing a strand of pink imitation pearls. Doe's former Boeing Computer Services supervisor testified during the trial that the jewelry made Doe's attire unacceptable and disruptive to co-workers. Further testimony showed that Doe had been warned not to wear the pearls but had been allowed to wear a bra, stockings, earrings and makeup. Doe admitted in testimony that she violated the dress code and women's restroom restriction but did it to ``push'' the company. She said Boeing had no right to set any dress code or bar her from the ladies' bathroom. She said her doctor and therapist had told her she needed to live and act as a woman full time before undergoing sex-change surgery. However, the judge ruled that Boeing had the right to require Doe to wear sex-neutral clothing. He also pointed out that Doe intentionally violated the company dress code and prohibition against using the women's restroom. The judge also pointed out that the employee's doctor and therapist also told her that compromise was needed and that she didn't have to violate the dress code. Boeing spokesman Paul Binder said during the trial that Boeing believed the claim did not represent a handicap under the classic definition and that the company tried to accommodate the employee prior to sex-change surgery.

DOC.HEAD: Assaults, Thefts Prompt Churches to Hire Guards
DOC.TEXT: Two downtown churches still ask God to watch over them, but parishioners feel better that there are armed guards on hand, too. Burglaries, assaults and car vandalism have driven the churches to hire off-duty police officers or sheriff's deputies to watch churchgoers and their cars on weekends. ``There has been a generalized sigh of relief,'' said the Rev. Jim Barnes, pastor at Trinity United Methodist Church, which began using officers in November after suffering break-ins and the theft of cars from a parking lot nearby. ``People don't want to come downtown if they think their cars are going to be stolen. So we decided to bite the bullet, pardon the phrase, and do it.'' Most downtown pastors have stories to tell of assaults, threats and vandalism, and the occasional mentally disturbed or drunken person who interrupts services. The Rev. C.B. Woodrich, pastor of Holy Ghost Roman Catholic Church, which has employed guards for years, calls it ``just part of doing business downtown. It was getting to the point that everyone was being scared away.'' Armed guards at Holy Ghost sometimes walk women and older people to their cars. The church spends roughly $150 a weekend on the guards, Woodrich said. Other churches are using guards, but not armed ones. St. John's Episcopal Church hires two unarmed security guards to patrol parking lots on Sundays. ``There is just some crazy thing with me _ I don't want weapons on the church grounds,'' said Dean Donald McPhail. Jim Burris, business manager for the Basilica of the Immaculate Conception, said the church took its cue from Holy Ghost when it began hiring sheriff's deputies in December. The officers are uniformed but are not armed. ``It kind of adds to the peace of mind of people coming to church,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Rejects Soviet Proposal For Referendum on German Unification
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany flatly rejected on Saturday a Soviet proposal that Americans, Canadians and Europeans vote on whether a united Germany should be allowed. Kohl spoke with reporters after a one-hour meeting with Communist Premier Hans Modrow of East Germany that focused on the economic crisis caused by the exodus of East Germans to the West. ``The main topic was that both of us stressed once again the exceptional seriousness of the situation, as the number of migrants remains high _ about 55,000 in January,'' Kohl told reporters. Modrow said they discussed intra-German relations ahead of his Feb. 13-14 visit to Bonn. Neither official disclosed details of the talks held in this resort, where both were attending an international business forum. Kohl said signs of economic collapse had increased in East Germany. ``It must be our common concern to stop this process,'' he said. The chancellor said the talks did not touch on Modrow's four-point plan for a united but militarily neutral Germany, unveiled Thursday. Bonn had immediately rejected the neutrality idea. Kohl was asked about Soviet Foreign Eduard Shevardnadze's proposal that Europeans, Americans and Canadians vote to decide whether East and West Germany should merge because they had suffered so much in World War II. ``I don't support that because this is a truly German issue,'' Kohl replied. Europeans would back German unity in any case, he added. Shevardnadze made the suggestion in an interview with Soviet reporters published Friday. At the same time, he gave the Kremlin's strongest endorsement yet to German unification, while repeating conditions that this must not destabilize Europe or occur too quickly. At the annual Davos business forum, West Germany's economics minister, Helmut Haussmann, counseled caution in proceeding with economic and monetary ties between the two Germanys. He said talks about the relation between the two countries' currencies will have to wait until after the East German elections, scheduled for March 18. Haussmann was responding to comments at the conference by Dresden Mayor Wolfgang Berghofer, a popular reformer who quit East Germany's Communist Party last month. On Friday, Berghofer described the situation in East Germany in dire terms. An average of 2,000 East Germans are fleeing their country daily for their more affluent neighbor. The exodus is draining East Germany of skilled workers and straining West German social services. Berghofer said complete collapse is imminent unless workers are given a convertible currency this year and the steady flood of people leaving the country is stopped. West German Finance Minister Theo Waigel on Friday suggested circulating his country's currency in East Germany to prop up the failing economy. Modrow and Kohl have proposed a common currency as one of the steps toward unification. In a speech earlier Saturday, Kohl sought to defuse Soviet worries about the revival of a strong Germany at the heart of Europe. He reiterated his stand that a united Germany should be achieved within ``security structures in Europe spanning both alliances,'' at lower levels of armament. He said the Western alliance, while it must adapt to changes in the Warsaw Pact, ``remains indispensable'' and includes a ``substantial security role for the United States on our continent.'' Kohl called for increased Western investment in the reforming economies of Eastern Europe, provided they guarantee free-market principles by law. He said an overwhelming majority of Germans want unity. West Germany will respect the decision of East Germans in any referendum on unification, he said. ``But I have no doubt what it will be.''

DOC.HEAD: Nieman-Marcus Chief Resigns to Take Over Campeau Subsidiaries
DOC.TEXT: Allen I. Questrom is stepping down as president and chief executive of the Neiman-Marcus stores to take the helm of embattled Campeau Corp.'s two U.S. retail subsidiaries. Questrom, 49, becomes chairman and chief executive officer of Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp., which own such department stores as Bloomingdale's, Jordan Marsh, Stern's, Lazarus, Abraham & Straus and Rich's. Questrom succeeds John W. Burden III and assumes the task of guiding Campeau's U.S. operations through bankruptcy reorganization. He was approved by a bankruptcy judge in Cincinnati on Thursday. Terry J. Lundgren, 38, will replace Questrom as head of the Dallas-based speciality retailer.

DOC.HEAD: Holder of Luge Record Dies
DOC.TEXT: Raymond H. Bateman Jr., a member of two U.S. Olympic teams and a four-time national luge champion, collapsed and died during a squash match. He was 34. Autopsy results were not immediately released, but Bateman, who died Thursday, had a history of heart problems. Bateman and his partner, Frank Masley, hold the U.S. luge record and in March won their fourth national luge doubles title. They were on the U.S. teams in the 1980 and 1984 Winter Olympics. Bateman also was a race car driver and competed in the Northeast for 10 years. Born in Somerville, he attended Johnson State College in Johnson, Vt., and the University of Vermont. Survivors include his wife, Robin; a son; a daughter; two sisters, and his parents. Funeral services will be Monday.

DOC.HEAD: 13-Year-Old Says He Killed Mother Because She Nagged
DOC.TEXT: A 13-year-old told police he shot and killed his mother because he couldn't stand her nagging any more. Linda Wallace, 28, was pronounced dead at Ben Taub Hospital shortly after the shooting Friday in her home in Fort Bend County, said homicide Sgt. Nancy Sovoia. The boy was placed in juvenile custody, Ms. Sovoia said. The boy's sister and three brothers, ages 6 to 12, told police they were discussing black history with their mother when the 13-year-old asked to go to the bathroom. When he did not return, his mother went to check on him, they said. The children heard a shotgun blast and their mother walked into the living room clutching her chest, Ms. Sovoia said. The boy went outside and waited for police, she said. Officers said the boy told them, ``She was nagging me, and I couldn't take it anymore.'' The boy's father, Otis Wallace, was at work when the shooting occurred. He told investigators his son was in a counseling program but didn't give details, Ms. Sovoia said.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands March to Celebrate New Freedoms
With AM-South Africa-Change, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 8th pvs, `The government...' with 1 graf to restore dropped words. Pickup 9th, `It removed...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos JOH6, CPN1
DOC.TEXT: Long-silenced activists began speaking out and thousands of blacks marched in celebration Saturday after President F.W. de Klerk scrapped stifling restrictions on anti-apartheid groups. A newspaper report, meanwhile, said jailed African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela could be freed within a week. But de Klerk's decision to legalize the African National Congress and lift a host of other restrictions brought an outpouring of activism elsewhere. Large crowds marched in the streets of Port Elizabeth, the northern Cape province desert town of Graaf-Reinet, and Alexandra, a small township next to Johannesburg. About 7,000 people protested the appearance of a visiting English cricket team in Pietermaritzburg, the Natal provincial capital. The African National Congress, meanwhile, said its guerrilla attacks would not be suspended but would have a lower profile. ``I think one can expect, in the context of the legalization of the ANC, that probably other aspects of our multipronged strategy will receive a much higher profile than in the past,'' said Pallo Jordan, the ANC's information chief at its exile headquarters in Lusaka, Zambia. Jordan was one of several ANC leaders who could not be quoted in South Africa until Saturday, when notices were published in the Government Gazette, formalizing the stunning concessions announced by de Klerk on Friday. The government repealed laws that banned 175 people, including ANC President Oliver Tambo, now recovering from a stroke in Sweden; the ANC's chief spokesman, Tom Sebina; and the leader of the South African Communist Party, Joe Slovo. It removed state-of-emergency prohibitions on travel and public speaking on another 200 people. Among those reveling in their new freedoms was 84-year-old Helen Joseph, the first white person ever placed under house arrest for anti-government activity. She had been officially ``banned,'' restricted to the Johannesburg area, placed under curfew in her home, and prohibited from meeting with more than a few people at a time or making public appearances. For the first time in 30 years, South African newspapers published her comments Saturday. ``This is a wonderful day. I am very excited about my personal freedom since I am no longer a listed person,'' said the wheelchair-bound activist, an old friend of Mandela's. ``Above all I am excited about the return of all my friends and comrades and all the exiles who will be coming back home, all my comrades who will be released from jail,'' she was quoted as saying. De Klerk, in his speech to Parliament, also said that Mandela would be freed soon. The Citizen, a pro-government newspaper, quoted an unidentified government source as saying de Klerk ``moves very fast'' and could free the 71-year-old Mandela any day. ``If there is no sudden outbreak of violence and people react in an orderly fashion, Mr. Mandela could be free by next weekend,'' the source was quoted as saying. De Klerk's announcements met most of the conditions laid down by the ANC to begin negotiations on a new constitution to bring the black majority into the nation's political life. However, many activists said the government must completely end the state of emergency, free all prisoners convicted of crimes related to political action and repeal laws that still would allow the arrest of returning exiles. Senior leaders of the ANC, most of them banned until this weekend, gathered for an executive meeting Saturday in Stockholm, Sweden. ``The ANC will discuss new strategies because of the new situation which has arisen,'' said David Kgabang, an ANC official in the Stockholm office. De Klerk announced a moratorium on executions and ended most emergency restrictions on the press, while allowing police to retain control over photography and filming of political unrest and police actions. Zwelakhe Sisulu, who had been prevented for two years from editing his newspaper, New Nation, was free to work and speak. His paper carried front-page color illustrations of the ANC and Communist Party flags in a special issue Saturday. Reaction to de Klerk's concessions in most black townships was subdued, with no celebrations in the largest black city, Soweto, home to 2.5 million people. But almost half the population of the small desert town of Graaf-Reinet, walked under ANC banners from outlying mixed-race and black townships to the town center Saturday. Mayor Joan Thornton accepted letters of complaint from leaders of the 15,000 marchers about lack of electricity and sewage systems, and a shortage of housing and water taps. She handed the leaders a white rose ``as a symbol of peace in this town,'' 560 miles north of Cape Town. The Rev. Allan Boesak, mixed-race president of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches, said the mayor's action was ``an enormous recognition of the movement and the respect with which they must behold the movement now that we can bring so many thousands of people peacefully into a town like this.'' About 8,000 people, including many elders and children, crammed into a stadium in Alexandra, a township of more than 100,000 people near Johannesburg, and chanted ``Viva ANC'' while swaying to the rhythm of liberation songs. The Alexandra rally originally had been scheduled to protest living conditions in the squalid township, and the crowd doubled as the protesters marched to the local council office and police station. In Port Elizabeth townships in the eastern Cape province, several thousand people danced in the streets, and blacks in pubs praised de Klerk as ``bold and brave,'' said a report from the South African Press Association. About 150 blacks marched and sang briefly in downtown Johannesburg. The focus of the 7,000 people gathered in Pietermaritzburg was the cricket tour, which violates an international sports boycott against South Africa. English captain Mike Gatting and Ali Bacher, general manager of the South African Cricket Union, walked through a 100-yard gantlet of chanting protesters to collect a petition from the organizers. As they returned members of the crowd threw stones and soft drink cans at them, until volunteer marshals stopped the abuse. No injuries were reported.

DOC.HEAD: Space Shuttle Countdown Rehearsal Successful
DOC.TEXT: Atlantis' five astronauts completed a countdown rehearsal inside the shuttle Saturday for their classified military mission later this month. As planned, the test ended five seconds before the clock reached zero to simulate an aborted liftoff in which the three main engines shut down after ignition. ``Everything went according to plan,'' said NASA spokeswoman Lisa Malone. Atlantis is scheduled to lift off Feb. 22. Sources close to the project said the crew will put into orbit a spy satellite that will gather information over the Soviet Union and elsewhere. The space agency said the flight could be pushed back a day or so because of a problem with a main engine turboprop, which engineers are replacing. A firm launch date will be set Feb. 10.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0528 to delete extraneous upper rail before dateline
Handicapped Students Learn in Creative Ways
DOC.TEXT: The eighth-grade history class at Stephen Decatur Middle School had taken on the competitive feel of a television game show. ``Name the King of England who wanted to move away from the Catholic church and wanted to establish his own church,'' challenged teacher Georgia Runfola. ``I know, I know,'' yelled a student, swiftly flipping through a textbook. ``Henry the Eighth.'' ``Good job,'' responded special education teacher Brenda Morris. Runfola and Morris are team teachers, participants in a program in this Prince Georges County school designated to further the ``mainstreaming'' of students with mild learning disabilities into regular classroom environments. Only the teachers know which students have learning disabilities. ``You don't make a distinction in the classroom,'' said Dawn DeTurris, another team teacher. ``Teachers put the roll in alphabetical order and then they soon forget, hopefully. They try to meet the needs of all students as they come up, whether they have a handicapping condition or not.'' The program at Stephen Decatur is one of many efforts nationwide to help children with special educational needs, a group that is drawing increased attention just a few miles away in the nation's capital. The Supreme Court recently let stand a ruling that all handicapped children, even those lacking any learning ability, are entitled to education paid for by the public schools. President Bush, who pledged during the campaign to be the ``education president,'' has promised to educate all of America's children. David Chavkin of the National Center for Clinical Infant Programs said about 4.1 million children classified as mentally or physically handicapped are being educated in federally assisted education programs. These include more than 1.5 million children with specific learning disabilities, more than 1 million with speech impairments, nearly 1 million mentally retarded, more than 300,000 with serious emotional disturbances, and more than 300,000 with orthopedic impairments, with vision or hearing impairments, and with other health impairments, or with multiple disabilities. For the current 1990 fiscal year, the Education Department's budget for special education and rehabilitative services programs is about $4 billion. Education for handicapped children cost the nation's schools $16 billion last year. An example of how that budget leaches down to the local level is in Prince Georges County. The head of the program, Robert Coombs, describes it as ``highly respected and well-known.'' In Prince Georges, 1,200 teachers, instructional aides, therapists and middle managers handle about 11,000 special education students. The county's budget for the current school year is $53 million, with only about $3 million from the federal government. Coombs said the program allows special education to move away from a ``mini, one-room schoolhouse environment.'' ``The nice part about this is if you are a multi-level student who just can't make it in math but do pretty well in everything else, we can `pull' that student for intensive work in math only and keep him mainstreamed for all the other subjects,'' said Coombs. Although the students' anonymity is broken that way, Coombs and others said the benefits of the special work are great. About 135 of the 800 students at Stephen Decatur are special education students, most of them coming from six different areas of the county. The middle school is one of three in the county with an entire wing of the building for special education students. Mildly handicapped students can receive either periodic monitoring with no direct service or up to at least 20 hours of special education service, depending on need. Students ``pulled out'' from the regular class receive separate instructions in ``intensive resource'' classes that have student-teacher ratios as low as 7-to-1. The average class size is about a dozen students. Combs explained, ``One of the things you run into in secondary schools that enroll mildly handicapped kids is they get very resistant to being labeled as different than all the other students.'' ``They don't like that and they don't like to be pulled out and have to go down the hall'' for separate classes that focus on their special needs. Students with severe learning disabilities are taught in so-called ``self-contained units'' and do not attend classes with regular students, said Coombs. ``Special education students get individualized instruction when necessary,'' said Dawn Thigpen, who oversees special education programs at several of the county's middle school. ``The teams work very hard with parents to make sure the student is placed in the least restrictive environment.'' Ms. Thigpen said that team teaching is a favorite and teachers have developed a variety of strategies. For example, the teachers try to divide up the course work according to the strengths and weaknesses, or likes and dislikes, with each taking turns to lead class work during a period. In other teams, one teacher will take over the classroom on one day and the other teacher the next day. ``What is neat is that you can meet the needs of regular education students as well as the needs of students who have handicapping conditions,'' said Joan Harris, an English and reading team teacher. Teacher Kathy Doyle added: ``With two people, you can do a lot of proactive behavior management, where you defuse a behavior problem before it starts. ... You can have one teacher take a child out of the classroom before he affects the others.'' One drawback to the approach, volunteered one eighth grader, comes ``when the teachers both talk at once. I get confused.''

DOC.HEAD: Where's the Dough for Foreign Aid?
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 18th graf pvs, bgng: Leonard H., to CORRECT editorial to op-ed
DOC.TEXT: Foreign aid, once a backwater issue that stirred relatively little interest on Capitol Hill, has become a hot topic with lawmakers asking the Bush administration: Where's the dough? Pressing domestic needs, changes in Eastern Europe, the invasion of Panama and a controversial proposal by Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., to slash funds to Israel and Egypt are spotlighting foreign aid in 1990. Noting the general unpopularity of foreign aid, Senate Budget Committee Chairman Jim Sasser, D-Tenn., said ``There's going to be some rough sledding.'' A recent Wall Street Journal-NBC News poll showed 71 percent of Americans believe the United States spends too much on foreign aid. They supported aid, but were virtually split on helping Poland and opposed aid to East Germany and the Soviet Union. Many lawmakers, including Sen. Bob Kasten, R-Wis., a member of the Senate committee that divvies up foreign aid, and Rep. David Obey, D-Wis., chairman of the House foreign operations appropriations subcommittee, view cuts in defense _ the so-called peace dividend _ as the future cash cow for foreign aid. ``We can easily cut another $10 billion to $18 billion (from defense spending) without jeopardizing security,'' says Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. ``There's a lot more to be done within the Defense Department.'' Biden is one of a handful of Democratic senators who introduced a bill last week to channel $500 million to Eastern Europe. Rep. Sam Gejdenson, D-Conn., said the defense budget should be cut in favor of foreign aid. ``There are times to buy bullets and times for other things,'' he said. Lawmakers said they've been told funds will be taken from defense programs and from other accounts. But Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Senate subcommittee that handles foreign aid, says he wants to see the money first. ``I told one administration official, `Don't travel around the world saying, `The check's in the mail,' when I have the checkbook in my pocket.'' ``I'm not going to move a bill that makes great promises without the money,'' Leahy said. While the Bush administration last week asked for $14.8 billion in foreign aid for fiscal 1991, about $1 billion over the previous year, Congress still has unfinished business for fiscal year 1990, which began last October. Secretary of State James A. Baker III has informed lawmakers the administration is planning to ask Congress for two supplemental foreign aid packages for 1990, but he hasn't told them where he wants to cut money so the budget will balance. The packages are $500 million for Panama to help the country the United States invaded on Dec. 20, and $70 million for refugees. The State Department's refugee budget has been strained by the Soviet Union's liberalized emigration policies that have allowed more people, particularly Jews, to leave. The administration wants to admit 27,000 more refugees this year. Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., says $30 million is to be siphoned off from Sudan and Somalia. But Simon, chairman of a Senate Africa subcommittee, says he's opposed to eliminating money for Africa. Leonard H. Robinson Jr., chairman of the African Development Bank, complained in an op-ed piece in The Washington Post that Africa, the world's poorest continent, has been given short-shrift. ``Where did the $900 million come from?'' he asked about the money Congress provided for Poland and Hungary late last year. ``Why did it take only days to secure? As an Africanist, I want to know _ so do the people of Africa.'' Others are sure to come forward with complaints about Congress' habit of ``earmarking'' _ setting aside _ money for specific countries. The administration opposes such earmarks, saying they eliminate flexibility. Five countries _ Israel, Egypt, Turkey, the Philippines and Pakistan _ receive more than two-thirds of the total aid. Israel and Egypt get the lion's share, with Israel leading at $3 billion. Egypt is slated to get $2.2 billion. Dole's proposal to eliminate _ as well as reduce money for Israel _ has gained little public support from his colleagues, but it has raised the sensitive issue for debate this year. Dole wants more money sent to Eastern Europe. Aid to Israel is always delicate because of its ramifications with the American Jewish community. ``I don't support Senator Dole's proposal, although I think he has performed a service by calling attention to the need for reconsideration of the allocation of our resources for foreign aid,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., said the Dole plan was a ``bad idea.'' A group of House members led by Rep. Vin Weber, R-Minn., said aid to the Middle Eastern nations is ``an investment ... not a gift.'' Sen. William Armstrong, R-Colo., predicted the Dole plan will come to the forefront in ``two to six months, but it's not something the administration wants to take the heat over right now.'' Another contentious topic is El Salvador, where some members of Congress have suggested tying U.S. aid to country's human rights record. The administration has reduced economic aid to El Salvador to $130 million in 1990, but proposes to increase that in 1991. One senator with little interest in foreign aid in Jesse Helms, R-N.C., the ranking Republican on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. ``I ain't got no dog in that fight,'' Helms said of the Dole proposal. Helms said he has opposed all foreign aid. ``What are we doing giving away money when we have such a debt problem at home?'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: On First Legal Day, ANC Reassesses Strategy
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The African National Congress held its first meeting as a legal entity Saturday and a spokesman said the group will not abandon its guerrilla campaign despite concessions made by the South African goverment. ANC leaders flew in from their headquarters in Lusaka, Zambia, to join veteran members recently released from South African prisons who were in Sweden to visit ailing ANC President Oliver Tambo. On Friday, the ANC issued a statement from Stockholm cautiously welcoming the dramatic policy changes announced Friday by South African President F.W. de Klerk in Cape Town, but said they did not go far enough. In Lusaka, ANC spokesman Pallo Jordan said the organization will not abandon the military campaign, but conceded it will take a lower profile. ``We have always said that the notion of the ANC unilaterally abandoning armed struggle is out of the question,'' Jordan told reporters. ``Any ceasing of hostilities will have to be negotiated and will arise out of a mutually binding ceasefire,'' he said. De Klerk partly rescinded the state of emergency imposed in 1986 to quell disturbances. He announced the legalization of the ANC and about 60 other opposition groups, and lifted the ban on hundreds of anti-apartheid activists, including Tambo. De Klerk also promised to unconditionally free ANC leader Nelson Mandela, but gave no date. The 71-year-old Mandela, imprisoned since 1962, is serving a life sentence for helping plan the start of the ANC's sabotage and bombing campaign against the white-led government. ANC Secretary-General Alfred Nzo and Joe Slovo, head of the South African Communist Party, flew to Stockholm late Friday to join Walter Sisulu and other ANC veterans touring Scandinavia on their first visit outside Africa since being freed in October. The meeting was an ANC executive committee session to ``discuss new strategies because of the new situation which has arisen,'' said David Kgabang, an official of the ANC's Stockholm office. Kgabang gave no indication of how the strategy might change. Jordan described the guerrilla campaign as part of the ANC's multipronged strategy to end apartheid. ``At particular times that aspect (armed struggle) has received a higher profile than others. I think one can expect, in the context of the legalization of the ANC, that probably other apsects of our multipronged strategy will receive a much higher profile than in the past,'' he said. Kgabang said he expected the ANC to reopen its offices in Johannesburg and elsewhere in South Africa. The group operated openly for 48 years until it was outlawed in 1960, and began its sabotage campaign in 1961. The arrival of Nzo and Slovo brought together in Sweden most of the ANC's top decision makers. Nzo is the group's acting president in place of Tambo, who is recuperating from a stroke in a Stockholm clinic. Slovo is a former head of the ANC's armed wing. They joined Thabo Mbeki, who is in charge of the ANC's foreign relations, Sisulu and five other recently freed leaders from the Mandela era. ``This is an opportunity to discuss developments with the leadership which has been in the cold for so many years,'' Kgabang said. Meetings were expected to last until Monday, when Sisulu and the other released veterans planned to return to South Africa while the rest head back to the ANC's headquarters in Lusaka. In its statement Friday, the ANC tempered its welcome of de Klerk's speech with concern that some emergency restrictions remained in place, including the power to detain without trial. It called for the continued international isolation of South Africa until apartheid is dismantled.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor Who Falsified AIDS Test Spared Prison
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `Dr. Monir ..., to restore Friday time element.
DOC.TEXT: A doctor who took bribes to falsify AIDS tests for two aliens wanting to stay in the United States has been sentenced to six months' house arrest and ordered to provide free medical care to AIDS patients. Dr. Monir Dawoud, 50, of Jersey City also was placed on five years' probation, ordered to donate $1,000 to an AIDS foundation and fined more than $5,000 at his sentencing Friday. The government said Dawoud took $3,000 and falsified documents so the government would not know that the two patients were carrying the AIDS virus. Most aliens who test positive for the virus are deported. Assistant U.S. Attorney Kevin McKenna refused to say whether the two people whose records were falsified have been deported. Dawoud was one of seven doctors in Hudson County authorized to examine aliens referred by the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Calls Election a Choice Between Democracy and Communism
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu is telling voters that in two weeks Japan will face a crucial choice between democracy and socialism. But as official campaigning for parliamentary elections began Saturday, voters didn't seem to share his concern. ``I need your support,'' he told an unenthusiastic crowd of several hundred people who gathered in front of a busy Tokyo train station. Most of his audience appeared to be party supporters invited to the rally. Passers-by lingered only until traffic lights changed.Nearby, more than 1,000 people gathered to hear the leader of the main opposition Socialist Party. The embattled prime minister, one of 953 candidates vying for the 512 seats in Parliament's powerful lower house, has said he will resign if his Liberal Democratic Party cannot retain a majority. And for the first time in 34 years of unbroken rule, the Liberal Democrats are facing the possibility that even that goal may prove to be too much. Kaifu said the Feb. 18 election will be ``critical,'' and warned that voters will be deciding whether they want ``freedom and democracy or socialism and communism.'' ``The world has already rendered its verdict on socialism,'' he said, referring to the ouster of hard-line Communist rulers in Eastern Europe. At the Socialist rally, party leader Takako Doi said her party planned to defeat the Liberal Democrats. ``Before the last election I said the mountain would move,'' said the 61-year-old Ms. Doi, alluding to the Liberal Democrats' loss of their majority in the upper house of Parliament in July. ``We will move the second mountain.'' Ms. Doi said the governing party lost in July because of its support for a 3 percent sales tax and because of its leaders' involvement in financial and sex scandals. ``It's been seven months, and they haven't changed a bit,'' she said. ``The only road left is for each of you to change politics with your votes.'' Ms. Doi, the only woman leader of a major party, is widely credited with increasing the Socialists' popularity. Setsuko Isobe, 60, said she also was drawn to the rally by Ms. Doi. ``Women in Japan have been looked down on in the past, but Ms. Doi shows that some of us can be very powerful.'' Two of four candidates with Ms. Doi at the rally were women. No women are running for the Liberal Democrats. Going into the election, the Socialists held 83 seats in the lower house against 295 for the Liberal Democrats. The Clean Government Party held 54 seats, the Communists 26, the Democratic Socialists 25. Twenty-nine seats were either vacant or held by independents and minor party members. The Socialists are only backing 148 candidates, and would need to form a coalition with other opposition parties to wrest the majority away from the Liberal Democrats, who are backing 325 candidates. Kaifu assumed office in August after Sousuke Uno resigned to take responsibility for the election defeat in July and amid reports that he had an extramarital affair with a geisha. Uno's predecessor, Noboru Takeshita, stepped down in June because of his ties to an influence-peddling scandal. Several other Liberal Democratic leaders resigned in the scandal, in which the information conglomerate Recruit Co. was accused of paying millions of dollars in exchange for political influence.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Militias Break Truce; Aoun Loses Crucial Port
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE casualties, details on defections, background on pvs truces; picks up 15th graf, `Aoun and ...'; SUBS grafs 20-22 pvs, `The source ...' with 1 graf with detail on shelling; picks up 23rd graf, `When Aoun ...'
DOC.TEXT: A Christian militia drove back rival forces loyal to Gen. Michel Aoun on Saturday and seized control of a vital Beirut port after some of his troops abandoned five days of fighting and began defecting. Gunboats, tanks and cannons fell silent in response to a Vatican-brokered cease-fire, but the shelling resumed after three hours. More than 37 people were killed Saturday and hundreds of thousands were trapped in shelters. Police said that overall, 164 people have been killed and 618 wounded in the clashes for control of Lebanon's Christian enclave between Aoun's 20,000 soldiers and the 6,000-strong Lebanese Forces militia. The Lebanese Forces, led by Samir Geagea, is the main Christian militia. The Lebanese Forces emerged from the fighting in control of 60 percent of the Christian enclave, with Aoun's troops entrenched only in the eastern and northern edges of east Beirut as well as the mountainous Metn province northeast of the capital. At the start of the fighting on Tuesday, each side controlled half of the Christian enclave. Civilians said the fighting in dense residential areas had caused some of the worst damage in 15 years of civil war. ``We never had a war like this,'' said Robin Haik, 24, who fled to Cyprus aboard a ferry during a lull in the fighting. ``The Lebanese Forces put all kinds of artillery between every house to try to get the army, and the army tried to hit them with all kinds of shells.'' The five-day battle has kept half a million people, or half of the enclave's population, hiding in poorly equipped basements and bomb shelters with no electricity or water. The brief cease-fire was reached after police said 1,000 members of Aoun's forces stationed at Beirut's port and along half of Beirut's three-mile dividing Green Line defected. Six hundred joined Geagea's militia and 400 went to the Lebanese army. That stripped Aoun of the Beirut port and his only docks. The loss could disrupt his supplies, but both sides are believed to have several months' worth of ammunition stockpiled. Aoun's failure to achieve a swift, clear-cut victory over Geagea's outnumbered and outgunned men has damaged his image of invincibility. Although Aoun's troops outnumber their rivals 3-to-1 and were deeply committed to the war he fought last year against the Syrians and their Moslem allies, they apparently do not have the same high morale fighting fellow Christians, many of them relatives. Geagea's troops have said they are fighting for the survival of their group. Geagea also kept some low-ranking army officers on his payroll. The cease-fire _ the sixth in the latest round of fighting _ had been called by the Vatican through Papal Nuncio Pablo Puente and Maronite Catholic Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir. Aoun and Geagea, both Maronites, accepted the cease-fire and said they had ordered their forces to honor it. The fighting resumed when artillery shells crashed into residential districts of Moslem west Beirut, which is outside the combat zone, and the city's eastern Christian sector. The barrage caught unprotected civilians who had emerged from shelters to inspect damage and flee to safer areas carrying bagloads of belongings. Many sought refuge behind sand barricades. Others rushed toward west Beirut on foot as Aoun's soldiers cocked their guns in preparation for battle. At one point, shells fell on residential districts at the rate of six per minute, said a police spokesman who cannot be named in line with regulations. The shelling set ablaze apartment buildings, warehouses, gas stations and supermarkets. Police said Aoun's gunners and Lebanese Forces militiamen were involved in the shelling, but it could not be determined who provoked the exchange. When Aoun launched his offensive against the Lebanese Forces on Tuesday, he pledged that no militias would be allowed to operate in the 310-square-mile Christian enclave north and northeast of Beirut. Geagea failed to back Aoun in his confrontation with President Elias Hrawi, elected under a peace plan adopted late last year by the Lebanese parliament. Aoun refused to cede the presidential palace to Hrawi, calling him a Syrian stooge. Syrian has the largest military presence in Lebanon and backs the Christian-Moslem government led by Hrawi. Aoun's forces wages furious battles with Syrian and Moslem forces last year in an effort to drive out the Syrians.

DOC.HEAD: Strike Called by Militants Paralyzes Kashmir
LaserPhoto KAP1
DOC.TEXT: The government on Saturday lifted curfew restrictions for 12 hours, but shops remained closed and few people ventured out because of a strike called by Moslem separatists, witnesses said. A bomb went off in the city during the relaxation, but a senior police official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said there were no casualties. No other violence was reported. The Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front spread a strike call by word of mouth on Friday night and early Saturday, local journalists said, quoting shopkeepers in downtown Srinagar and its suburbs. The front is spearheading a four-decade-old campaign for secession of Jammu-Kashmir state's predominantly Moslem Kashmir valley from Hindu-majority India. Srinagar, the state's summer capital, is the largest city in the valley. At least 76 people have been killed since the government launched a crackdown on the secessionist movement on Jan. 20 and imposed around-the-clock curfews. Most of those killed were curfew-violating Moslems shot by the security forces. The government reported no deaths between Jan. 25 and Friday, when at least four people were killed. Three of them died when paramilitary police opened fire on a mob defying curfew in the nearby city of Sopore, police officials said. The fourth was a Hindu shopkeeper who was shot by militants in Srinagar. Saturday's strike in Srinagar was to protest the Sopore deaths, Kaiser Mirza, a local journalist, quoted shopkeepers as saying. The curfew relaxation began at 5 a.m. and ended at 5 p.m. Mirza said most shops did not open in the morning when curfew was lifted, and a few shops that did open soon put down their shutters when owners learned of the strike call. It was not immediately clear if the shops were closed fearing attacks by the militants or to sympathize with the separatist cause. During earlier curfew relaxations, which began one week ago, vegetable shops and groceries were crowded and streets were filled with people and traffic. On Saturday morning, small groups of men stood at street corners but there was little traffic, Mirza said. The Moslem militancy dates to 1947 when India and Pakistan were partitioned on religious lines after gaining independence from Britain. The king of mostly Moslem Jammu-Kashmir chose union with India instead of Islamic Pakistan. Moslem militants initially began agitating for union with Pakistan but in recent months have been demanding independence instead. India has accused Pakistan of fomenting the trouble in Kashmir, a charge Pakistan denies. The two countries have fought three wars, two of them over Kashmir. The wars have left a slice of Kashmir under Pakistan's control and a U.N.-supervised cease-fire line divides the valley into Indian and Pakistani sectors. The Indian state of Jammu-Kashmir, which comprises the valley and the plains of Jammu to the south, is the country's only Moslem-majority state. At least 64 percent of its 5 million people follow Islam. Nationwide, Moslems account for 12 percent of the 880 million population.

DOC.HEAD: Latest Developments in Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: Here is a summary of developments Saturday in Eastern Europe:
DOC.HEAD: SOVIET UNION:
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will ask the Communist Party leadership to give up its guaranteed hold on power and accept the possibility of competing political parties, a Soviet news agency said. The report also said Gorbachev will propose at the Central Committee meeting this week a complete change in the party structure and tacitly endorse the concept of private ownership. In Latvia, Armenian and Azerbaijani negotiators emerging from their first talks expressed hope for a peaceful settlement of their ethnic dispute but remained far apart on thorny territorial claims. They agreed to seek the release of all hostages by March 1 and to establish permanent relations between their republics' main grass-roots political groups.
DOC.HEAD: GERMANY:
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany rejected a Soviet proposal that Americans, Canadians and Europeans vote on whether a united Germany should be allowed. Kohl spoke with reporters after a private meeting with Communist Premier Hans Modrow of East Germany in Switzerland that focused on the economic crisis caused by the exodus of East Germans to the West.
DOC.HEAD: BULGARIA:
DOC.TEXT: Parliament elected an economist to replace a hard-line Communist as premier, and the new leader promised immediate reforms to combat Bulgaria's ``social and economic crisis.'' A leader of the emerging democratic opposition described the new premier, Andrei Lukanov, as ``a good choice'' and left open the possibility that some opposition members might join a coalition government.
DOC.HEAD: YUGOSLAVIA:
DOC.TEXT: Five ethnic Albanian groups asked the government to investigate reports that police fired without warning on protesters in Kosovo province, where unrest has killed 25 people and injured 120. About 300 ethnic Albanians rallied in the town of Podujevo, and a smaller group was dispersed by riot police in the provincial capital of Pristina. The province's Albanian majority is demanding more autonomy from the Serbian republic, which said it tightened control over the province last year to protect Kosovo's Serbian minority.
DOC.HEAD: CZECHOSLOVAKIA:
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of people exercised their new freedoms by forming a 100-mile human chain to protest a hydroelectric dam project on the Danube River. About 100,000 people from Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Austria formed the chain across territory in all three nations. Meanwhile, thousands of West Germans and Czechoslovaks formed a 2.5-mile human chain across their border in a gesture of triumph over the waning divisions between East and West.

DOC.HEAD: Scowcroft Sees `More Global' Role for U.S. Forces
DOC.TEXT: U.S. National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft said Saturday that American forces in the future will be smaller but ``more global'' in their orientation. Scowcroft said the Bush administration is adapting to the massive transformations sweeping Eastern Europe but added that the United States will remain a military power in Europe. ``It is the intention of the United States to remain engaged in Europe with a substantial military and political presence,'' he said. ``We feel we are a European power with an abiding and permanent interest in Europe security.'' In a speech Saturday in Switzerland, Chancellor Helmut Kohl said future military plans would include ``a substantial security role for the United States on our continent.'' Scowcroft spoke at the annual Wehrkunde conference in Munich, which brings together security experts, lawmakers and government officials from North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries and Japan. ``America will remain engaged as a global power,'' Scowcroft said. ``Part of the adjustment in our defense posture will be toward active forces that are smaller, more global in orientation.'' President Bush already has proposed reducing superpower forces in Central Europe to 195,000 troops for each side. That would mean a reduction of about 60,000 U.S. servicemen, most of them from West Germany. Scowcroft, during his address, did not spell out how U.S. forces would be poised to be more global in orientation. The conference was held against the backdrop of vastly improved East-West relations and European integration that many predict will lead to German unification. Scowcroft repeated U.S. support for German unity and said, ``Germany's growing strength may be a most prominent feature of this new European balance.'' Another speaker, Egon Bahr of the leftist opposition Social Democratic Party, criticized Bush administration plans to develop more short-range nuclear rockets. ``The United States can build more short-range nuclear rockets, but we won't install them,'' Bahr told the American delegation. Short-range rockets stationed in West Germany are only capable of hitting East Germany and Czechoslovakia, both of which are undergoing democratic reform.

DOC.HEAD: Source: Baker Expected to Meet Egyptian, Israeli Officials in Europe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to correct cycle designator
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Baker, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Egypt expects Secretary of State James A. Baker III to meet with Egyptian and Israeli officials in Europe next week to discuss Israeli-Palestinian peace talks, a government source said Saturday. Baker leaves Monday night on a nine-day trip to Europe that includes a meeting with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and talks on the upheaval in Eastern Europe, possible German reunification and Soviet political problems. Some have suggested that Baker also may meet privately with Foreign Ministers Moshe Arens of Israel and Esmat Abdel-Meguid of Egypt. The Egyptian Foreign Ministry source said such a meeting, expected in Geneva, may depend on whether Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir wins a vote of confidence he has requested in his right-wing Likud bloc. The source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, has been closely involved with Egypt's daily diplomatic exchanges in recent months with the United States, Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization. The exchanges are aimed at getting Baker, Abdel-Meguid and Arens together to work out plans for a proposed Israeli-Palestinian dialogue in Cairo as a first step toward achieving peace in the Middle East. The ministers could discuss the composition of the Palestinian delegation in Cairo and the agenda, both of which have proved to be divisive issues. After ``intensive contacts in recent days'' between Egypt and the United States, the Egyptian source said, Baker suggested a ministerial meeting in Geneva, with Feb. 11 a possible date. ``Egypt is prepared to attend the trilateral meeting as suggested (because it) believes the Palestinian-Israeli dialogue is a vital point along the road to peace in the Middle East,'' the source said. Baker has stepped up efforts to open negotiations, talking by telephone this week with Arens and with Abdel-Meguid. But a senior U.S. official said, ``We are not at the point of saying such a meeting will be held'' next week. Both the official and diplomatic sources, speaking in Washington on condition of anonymity, said the gap between the Israeli and Egyptian positions still was too wide to be bridged at a three-way meeting involving Baker. Reports from Israel said that Arens told Washington a ministerial session would have to be held after the Likud Central Committee meeting. Shamir is pressing for a single endorsement from the 3,200 committee members for his leadership and for his plan to let Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip elect delegates for talks with Israel on autonomy. His Likud bloc critics, led by Trade Minister Ariel Sharon who chairs the Central Committee, want separate votes on the election plan's details. Shamir has threatened to resign if he fails to win the committee's support. Abdel-Meguid held three meetings with Baker in Washington last month. The Foreign Ministry source said the Egyptian minister gave Baker a working paper on the peace process then that had been closely coordinated with the PLO. The source refused to give details but said the paper outlined a position that ``was clear-cut and emphatic on safeguarding the legitimate rights of the Palestinian people.'' Egypt publicly supports PLO demands that the organization choose Palestinian delegates to the Cairo talks and that the agenda be open. The PLO also wants the delegation to include people deported from the occupied territories and from Israel-annexed East Jerusalem. Shamir insists on excluding the PLO from the process and confining the talks' agenda to his election plan. He also opposes participation of Palestinians from East Jerusalem, apparently fearing this would undermine the city's status as Israel's declared capital.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Prepares Speech on Global Warming, Aides Deny Sununu Interference
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Saturday discussed global climate change with a newly formed presidential advisory panel while White House aides denied reports that his chief of staff toned down a speech he will make Monday on global warming. Bush never intended to reveal any policy shifts in his speech to the opening session of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, and the speech was tailored to reflect the official administration position that considerable scientific uncertainty remains about the seriousness of global warming, one administration official said. Bush has been criticized for not taking a stronger world leadership role on global warming, and his speech to the IPCC, a United Nations-sponsored committee, will be closely watched by environmental and business groups. In it he will showcase his administration's proposals and steps already taken for research and protection involving global environment, said the administration official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Officials on Saturday denied reports in The Washington Post and New York Times that White House chief of staff John Sununu tried to tone down the speech because it went too far in portraying global warming as a serious problem. Sununu and Environmental Protection Agency Administrator William Reilly have been at odds over the administration's policy on global warming _ the gradual increase in the Earth's temperature due to buildup of heat-trapping gases emitted into the Earth's atmosphere by oil and coal combustion. Sununu's deputy, Andrew Card, on Saturday termed the newspaper reports ``fictitious.'' He said Sununu had ``not written any part of the speech,'' but reviewed it as he routinely would any speech. Card said finishing touches were being put on the speech Saturday. The official who spoke anonymously said Sununu's ``only point was to be careful about the tone,'' and make sure it reflected administration policy on the inconclusiveness of scientific research on global warming. Sununu, according to the reports, is not convinced of the reliability of computer models that project temperature increases of at least 4 degrees by the year 2050 and he fears the economic consequences of shifting abruptly from today's energy sources. ``We take the issue seriously, but we're not prepared to make decisions on potential changes that are not scientifically proven,'' White House spokesman Steve Hart said Saturday. ``Science does not support the theories'' that would prompt the strong countermeasures environmentalists want to see. Other officials said that despite a reluctance to endorse expensive and sweeping steps to mitigate global warming, Bush, in his speech, will point out the environmental steps he is taking, such as: _His proposal to spend $1 billion in fiscal year 1991, an increase of 57 percent, for global change research. _Sweeping Clean Air Act changes currently being negotiated with Congress. _A proposal to spend $175 million to begin a project of planting 1 billion trees. _Last year's regulatory restrictions on electric appliances. _The U.S. hosting of an international convention to work on a framework agreement on climate change next fall. ``We are using this in a comprehensive way to give credit for all the United States is doing to show leadership'' on the environment, the official said. Sununu was with Bush at the presidential retreat at Camp David, Md., where a spokesman said global warming was among the topics discussed at the first meting of the President's Council of Advisers on Science and Technology Policy, chaired by White House science adviser D. Allan Bromley. Bromley also heads the global change committee within Bush's Domestic Policy Council of advisers. Bush prepared his Monday address as a congressional report accused his administration of a ``leadership void'' without goals or comprehensive strategy on global climate change. The report by the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, praised the government for trying to develop an international consensus on global warming through the U.N. panel. But it says the administration also should develop a national policy. ``The president has not designated any individual or agency to assume overall leadership or management responsibility for global climate change,'' said the report released Friday. ``Without such a designated leadership position or focal point, no identifiable hierarchical structure for policy and decision-making on global climate change issues has emerged.'' The study was requested by House Energy and Commerce Committee Chairman John D. Dingell, D-Mich. In a letter to the White House, the Environmental Protection Agency and the departments of Energy and State, Dingell called the findings ``troubling.'' He urged ``coordinated leadership, and a wise and reasonable approach to addressing and hopefully solving these complex and controversial issues in a timely manner.'' The report notes that Bush announced last March the United States would join other industrial countries in phasing out production and consumption of chlorofluorocarbon by the year 2000. Bush made no similar commitment to control carbon dioxide emissions, another gas believed to be depleting the planet's protective ozone layer, the report said. But he has directed Energy Secretary James Watkins to develop a national energy strategy that will include proposals for reducing the global warming ``greenhouse'' gas emissions caused by energy sources.

DOC.HEAD: When it Comes to Church Organists, Money is Music
DOC.TEXT: The spirit may be willing, but the salary is weak, and church officials say that finding an organist is getting harder. ``Half the parishes either aren't able to pay or don't want to pay the musicians what they deserve, so the musicians are going elsewhere,'' said John Hubert, organist at St. Michael's Episcopal Church in Bristol. The Holy Trinity Church in Central Falls was almost left in the lurch at Christmas after its regular organist left for a better-paying job. ``I figured we'd come up with somebody, that it would just be a matter of getting in touch with one or two people,'' said the Rev. Robert M. Beirne. It took more than 15 phone calls, and in the end, the four Masses were handled by four musicians, he said. Jean Richard Dupont, placement officer for the Rhode Island chapter of the American Guild of Organists, said Saturday that Holy Trinity is not alone _ there is a nationwide shortage of organists. ``You can look at any of our magazines ... they always have ads'' for organists, he said. Fewer people are studying organ, especially sacred music. But the main reason is that women, who dominate the field, don't have the time anymore. In the past ``they could get away with it because there were a lot of women who really didn't need another income and who were willing to do it out of love,'' said Dupont. ``Those women are out working in other jobs now, and they don't want to come back to the church and work for a pittance.'' The Rhode Island chapter of the organists guild issued a book last month outlining what it considers fair recompense for church musicians. The book suggests salaries of $26,400 to $31,000 for full-time church organists holding a doctorate in music, and from $4,700 to $5,800 per year for musicians who work 10 to 14 hours a week and hold a guild certificate. Dupont said guilds in other cities have issued similar books, with wages set for each region. The Rhode Island guild has about 125 members and there are at least 175 other organists in the state, Dupont said. A 1987 survey found that of the 135 respondents, the annual pay ranged from zero to $20,000, with a median of $5,200. Taking into account time for services and rehearsals, the average hourly pay was $9.82, with the highest $33.97. Dupont, 55, who said he puts in about 10 hours of preparation for the Sunday service he plays at the First Universalist Church in Providence, said the job is more than just tickling the ivories. ``You have to have training ... experience, the ability to know what is good music and not good music, you have to be able to direct a choir and in a choir you have so many personalities ... you have to be a diplomat,'' said Dupont. The guild recommended organists should receive $50 to $75 for funerals and $75 to $100 for weddings. The 1986 guidelines by the Roman Catholic Diocese of Providence recommend $30 to $50 for weddings.

DOC.HEAD: Leftist Guerrillas Propose Truce
DOC.TEXT: Colombia's largest leftist guerrilla group on Saturday offered to call a truce until May so that the government can run congressional and presidential elections in peace. But the defense minister said he was skeptical about the proposal by the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia and noted another leftist guerrilla group has said it would disrupt balloting in the northeast. Near the cocaine trafficking center of Medellin, police found six bodies Saturday with multiple gunshot wounds and their hands and their feet tied. Police said the latest victims brought the toll to 50 in a 6-week-old gang war. The cease-fire offer, published in the Bogota newspaper La Prensa, was made in a letter to four former presidents, a Catholic Church cardinal and a leading businessman. ``The eminent recipients of this proposal will be the overseers of what could be a new process of reconciliation and peace for the Colombian family,'' the letter said. Defense Minister Oscar Botero told a news conference that leftist guerrillas, which have an estimated 5,000 fighters, had announced truces before but had failed to observe them. ``We have to see if the guerrillas fulfill their promise,'' he said. Conservative Party leader Misael Pastrana, who served as president from 1970 to 1974, said he would be willing to form a committee to oversee such a truce, La Prensa reported. The paper quoted Pastrana as saying that the government of President Virgilio Barco should take steps to ensure that the proposal leads to a permanent peace in the 30-year-old insurgency. Botero said army troops would be sent to northeastern Colombia to protect polling centers from the pro-Cuba National Liberation Army, which has promised to disrupt balloting. The congressional elections are scheduled for March 11, and presidential elections are to be held May 27. The wave of drug killings began after police shot and killed a leader of the Medellin cartel, Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, in a Dec. 15 gunfight on Colombia's northern coast. Police said some of the recent drug killings are likely the work of underlings vying for control of the criminal empire Rodriguez Gacha left behind. Another gang representing illegal gamblers and calling itself ``The Cleaning of Colombian Soccer'' said in several communiques sent to the local press that it is eliminating drug traffickers and other criminals. Most of the victims in the recent slayings had criminal records. On Friday, police found nine bodies near Bogota, all with their hands and feet tied and with several gunshots.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf in 2nd item to DELETE extraneous material.
DOC.TEXT: A troupe of women in camouflage, toting fake guns and led by a Groundhog Queen in a wheelchair, marched through the business district, passing along wishes of goodwill on Groundhog Day. ``May the shadow of the groundhog never darken your door,'' Groundhog Queen Kay Lowe and her group told Mayor Jerry Campbell and merchants Friday. ``Grr ... Grr ... Groundhog!'' Lowe started the tradition 12 years ago. This year bad luck fell on her door and she broke her foot a week before Groundhog Day. But the injury didn't stop her from singing odes to the woolly beast with six other ``Hogettes.'' Accompanied by Gus the Stuffed Groundhog, they blew into bullhorns, sounding like dying moose. ``It scares away the groundhogs because we don't want to hurt them,'' Sandi Turner said. She said the women carried the guns to protect the animals. ``A lot of people would hurt groundhogs,'' Turner said. ``We never would.'' Mayor Campbell offered each a lollipop at the start of their trek. ``I think it's a good way to come out of the winter months into the spring,'' Campbell said. ``They're promoting goodwill.''

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Demands End to Party Criticisms; 100 Palestinians Arrested
DOC.TEXT: Israeli troops arrested almost 100 Palestinians in a roundup of suspected agitators in the occupied West Bank, and soldiers shot and wounded 10 Arabs in the occupied Gaza Strip, Arab reports said. Meanwhile, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir demanded an end to a barrage of criticisms by rivals in his right-wing Likud bloc, and said that his party ``cannot live'' with the public dispute. A source in the Egyptian Foreign Ministry said Egypt expects Secretary of State James A. Baker III to invite the Israeli and Egyptian foreign minsters to a meeting in Geneva next week to prepare for Israeli-Palestinian peace talks if Shamir wins a Wednesday vote of confidence by party leaders. Rebel Likud hawks, led by Industry and Trade Minister Ariel Sharon, have been trying to undermine the foreign ministers' meeting and Shamir's efforts to implement a peace plan that calls for Palestinian elections in the occupied lands. The Likud rebels have demanded that in place of one vote of confidence at the party meeting, the 3,200 delegates vote separately on each of the plan's details. Likud's coalition partner, the left-leaning Labor Party decided Saturday to leave the government if Shamir loses the vote, Israel television reported. Shamir accused the rebels of undermining Israel's security by making the dispute public. ``To put on a display before hostile and enemy elements...is destructive,'' he said. ``This phenomenon must be dismissed from the life of the Likud.'' In the occupied West Bank on Saturday, troops imposed curfews on the towns of Ramallah, el-Bireh and the Kalandia refugee camp and detained almost 100 Palestinians as part of a security sweep, an army spokesman said. The spokesman said the Palestinians were suspected of organizing disturbances and taking part in violent anti-Israeli activities. In the occupied Gaza Strip, Palestinians closed their stores and transportation ground to a halt to observe a general strike ordered by the fundamentalist Islamic Jihad organization. Arab reports said soldiers wounded 10 Palestinians during demonstrations in the Gaza Strip. The strike was called to mark the 40th day following the death of Khalid Sheik Ali, who died after a beating by security agents in a Gaza prison cell. The secret Shin Bet security agency suspended two interrogators in December after an independent autopsy revealed that Ali, 27, died of internal injuries sustained during a beating. At least 651 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians during the almost 26 month uprising. Forty-three Israelis have died and Palestinians have killed 176 of their fellow Arabs on suspicion of cooperating with Israeli authorities.

DOC.HEAD: Ruling Council Reshuffles to Become Part of New National Unity Council
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The revolutionary government bowed to opposition pressure on Saturday and revamped the ruling council to give a minority role to 29 opposition parties. The National Salvation Front's council transformed itself into the nucleus of a new Council of National Unity, a 180-member panel that will rule until May 20 elections. The front will hold 93 of the seats. The front, unelected and serving by decree since the December revolution that ousted Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, has been under pressure to become more democratic. The front includes several former leading Communists and has been accused of plotting to restore a dictatorship. In addition, the opposition had complained that no fair elections would be possible if the front both organized and participated in the May elections. The new Council of National Unity will have 90 seats for political parties and 90 for prominent front members, including those who fought in the revolution, workers, farmers, youth and ethnic minorities. The 90 political seats will be split among the front and the 29 opposition parties, with each group getting three seats. ``Starting today, the National Salvation Front ... takes a new form,'' interim Vice President Cazimir Ionescu told repoters. He referred to the action as a ``reshuffle,'' rather than a dissolution. ``Dissolution would have meant a void in state power,'' he said, adding that a continuation of power was necessary ``to ensure stability'' and avoid a worsening of the already chaotic economic situation. Last week, the front announced it was transforming itself into a political movement with no links to its governing council in order to run in the elections, the first free vote since 1946. The front has refused to become a political party, calling itself a mass political organization instead. The 1946 elections were won by the National Peasant Party, now the largest opposition group, but were overturned by the Communists. Experts from the front and the political parties also met to discuss a draft electoral law promulgated by the front earlier this week. It provides for a two-chamber parliamentary system. Interim President Ion Iliescu said in a state radio interview that ``the temporary Council of National Unity will function as a pre-parliament'' without detailing what its structures or powers would be. ``The National Salvation Front, as a political organization with a structure and platform that is consistent ... will take part in the elections at the same level as all the other political organizations,'' Iliescu said in another interview, in Saturday's edition of the daily Adevarul. Iliescu is likely to retain his post of president until the May elections, Ionescu said. The front's political platform will be announced soon, he said. The ruling front's agreement to a Council of National Unity came at a meeting Thursday with the 29 opposition parties. Three historic opposition parties had originally demanded that the self-appointed ruling council of the front step down altogether, claiming it had no legitimacy. But in recent days, the opposition parties have resigned themselves to power-sharing with the front holding the dominant position. Their leaders said that at least until the elections, this arrangement was the only viable alternative to being totally locked out of power. ``What was announced today was in step with the decisions ... to build a provisional council of national unity,'' said Iftene Pop, vice president of the National Peasant Party. ``The new council better mirrors the real balance of political forces existing in Romania and ends the front's monopoly on power.'' ``More precisely, it bars the way to dictatorship and a new one-party system,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Report Highly Critical of China Rights Abuses
DOC.TEXT: A Bush administration report to Congress complains in unmistakable terms about human rights abuses in China following last year's crackdown on the pro-democracy movement there, according to sources who have seen the document. The State Department's annual assessment of repressive practices around the globe ``doesn't pull any punches'' when it comes to China, one source said. Another said it ``describes every human rights crime you can think of'' regarding the Beijing government. The unambiguity of the section on China surprised some congressional figures, particularly those who have charged the president himself with soft-peddling the issue and catering too much to the communist government.
