The report is not scheduled for public release until Feb. 21, when Robert Schifter, assistant secretary for human rights, is scheduled to testify on it before the House Foreign Affairs Committee. ``Murders, disappearances, executions, suppression of labor rights, religious persecution of Catholics and Buddhists, slave labor camps in western China _ you name it, it's in there,'' said one source who discussed contents of the report on condition he not be identified. Another source, who also declined identification, said ``We expected ... they might go somewhat easy on the Chinese,'' in light of the recent missions to Beijing by national security adviser Brent Scowcroft. ``But they didn't,'' he said. ``The report doesn't pull any punches.'' A State Department spokeswoman, Sondra McCarty, declined comment Saturday on the new human rights report, saying it would be premature to do so before Schifter's testimony to the House panel. Some members of Congress have complained that Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III were far too muted in their criticism of the Chinese regime after last summer's bloody suppression of student demonstrators in Tiananmen Square. And most Democrats, and even many Republicans, were particularly upset when Bush last month vetoed a bill protecting an estimated 40,000 Chinese students in the United States from deportation. The president argued he had accomplished the same objectives through administrative action. The students, meanwhile, expressed fear that he might revoke his executive order in some future bargain with Beijing. Referring to the president's veto, sustained in the Senate a week ago, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., declared ``It was wrong for the Bush administration to yield to pressure from a communist dictatorship in Beijing . ... One lesson of the past 45 years is that no Congress and no president should be timid in the defense of freedom.'' Bush, at a news conference following the Senate vote, repeated his pledge that ``No chinese student who is in this country is going to be sent back against his or her will.'' He added that ``we will continue to urge the People's Republic of China to recognize the human rights of its citizens.'' At the same time, Bush pronounced himself ``very pleased'' that Beijing had lifted martial law, had stopped harassing the U.S. Embassy and had released 573 people from prison. ``I've very pleased they've lightened up on the areas where I think we can really move things forward,'' including Peace Corps and Fulbright scholarship exchanges, he said. NBC News, which reported first on the still-unreleased human rights report, quoted this passage from it: ``As of year's end, there were continuing reliable reports of beatings of political detainees in the Beijing area by security forces ... prisoners, both criminal and political, are subjected to severe psychological pressure to confess.'' Earlier this week, Baker went before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee with a prepared text which named Cuba and China as countries who ``try to shut out democratic values,'' but he omitted the reference to China in his spoken testimony.

DOC.HEAD: Taped Confession Helps Deaf-Mute Killer Get Life
DOC.TEXT: A deaf-mute spared himself from a possible death sentence with a sign-language confession to murdering a 14-year-old boy after what he said was a video arcade fight over a dollar. ``I pushed him into the car, and I started choking him,'' Brian Hodge said in the confession. ``I kept choking and choking him. He went back and grabbed me in the crotch, and it really hurt, so I choked him harder. ``He was pushing me in the face and saying, `Stop, stop.' It was too late. He should have paid me back before,'' he said through a sign-language interpreter. The videotaped confession was made as part of a bargain with prosecutors in which Hodge pleaded guilty Friday to murder and attempted rape in the July slaying of Karl Phillip Heiland. In exchange, he was spared the possibility of the death penalty and will receive life in prison plus 15 years. The defense had intended to argue that the 25-year-old electrical worker committed second-degree murder because he never meant to kill the boy. But prosecutors said they would have tried to prove that Hodge killed Karl while trying to rape him, not by accident in a fight over the dollar. Michael Benito, an assistant state attorney, said he would have put on evidence that Hodge followed a different boy the day before he killed Karl. On the videotape, Hodge distanced himself from the sexual attacks. ``I didn't do it, the devil did it,'' he said. ``That's when the devil was calling me to have sex.'' Six weeks after the slaying, Karl's mother, Cathy Lee Heiland, committed suicide near his grave by running a hose from her exhaust pipe to the inside of her car. Police found her next to photographs of Karl.

DOC.HEAD: Jackson to de Klerk: Learn from Lincoln, Kennedy
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson Saturday appealed to President F.W. de Klerk to follow the example of Abraham Lincoln and John F. Kennedy and press ahead with his reforms, regardless of any threatened backlash from white conservatives. The U.S. black civil rights leader expressed ``hope and caution'' about South Africa as he prepared to revisit the nation after being refused entry for a decade. Jackson said he hoped that in giving him a visa for the first time since 1979, South Africa was sending ``yet another signal of a commitment to openness.'' Jackson visited with black cultural groups in London Saturday, and he was to attend two public meetings Sunday. On Monday he is to meet with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. He flies to Zambia later on Monday and to South Africa on Wednesday, and he said he hoped to meet de Klerk as well as jailed black leader Nelson Mandela, in or out of prison. De Klerk on Friday legalized the African National Congress, the main guerrilla group fighting white rule, and lifted restrictions on 60 opposition groups and 374 individuals. He also promised Mandela's imminent release. Jackson mentioned President Lincoln's emancipation of the slaves and President Kennedy's desegregation drive in the southern United States. ``And so Mr. de Klerk must be encouraged to move. ... Most people in the world are pulling for him to go farther and don't stop now.'' Jackson said de Klerk must not be deterred by any threatened backlash. ``Great leadership does not follow opinion polls. It molds opinion,'' he told reporters. ``Mr. de Klerk is now in a position to mold opinion and make things happen, and should not let this moment pass. ... He must seize this moment to do the right thing.'' He should free Mandela and abolish the remaining pillars of apartheid like the Group Areas Act, which segregates residential rights by race, Jackson said. Jackson, hitherto a fervent supporter of economic sanctions against South Africa, was noncommittal about whether the West should continue to apply them. ``Sanctions is not the central issue,'' he said, noting that de Klerk had not made their removal a condition for reform and that President Bush had said it was premature to talk of lifting sanctions. ``Sanctions should be part of the negotiating process therefore, not a precondition,'' Jackson said. ``And to put the focus on sanctions rather than apartheid is to shift the focus away from the need to encourage Mr. de Klerk to continue. And what we heard yesterday was reason for hope and caution.'' But he said South African blacks now saw economic sanctions the same way the West sees NATO now that Eastern Europe is free of Soviet domination: ``NATO is both a deterrent on one hand and a stimulus to democracy on the other.''

DOC.HEAD: Nesting Eagles Threaten Beltway Construction
DOC.TEXT: A family of bald eagles has moved into the path of the planned Orlando beltway, and developers are seeking an exception to a ban on building near the threatened birds' nest. The mother eagle and her two eaglets have settled on a flat-top pine just 50 feet west of where cars will zoom onto the beltway where it crosses over Lake Jesup in Seminole County. Usually, state and federal agencies do not allow development within 750 feet of a nest of the threatened species. But the expressway authority is seeking a first-time-ever exception to their policy, which wildlife officials fear could set an unwelcome precedent. ``Once we do it, then everybody will want to do this,'' said Don Wood, endangered species coordinator for the Florida Game and Fresh Water Fish Commission. Bald eagles are an endangered species in most states but are classified only as threatened in Florida, which has one of the largest groups of the birds in the nation. Florida prohibits any disturbance, molestation, harm, or harassment to the eagles. Violators can be fined up to $50,000 and sentenced to three years in jail. Wood acknowledged that the uniqueness of the situation should make it virtually impossible to duplicate. First, the nest appears to have been built in the past month, long after the Seminole County Expressway Authority plotted where its beltway section would run through the county. Second, the eagles appear to be plentiful around Lake Jesup. In fact, the expressway route across the lake was selected specifically to bypass two other eagle nests. And eagle expert Doris Mager has plotted at least 11 active nests around the lake. ``We're going to consider there are a lot of eagles in the area,'' Wood said. ``The loss of one nest would not be as significant because of that.'' Moving the toll road farther east would place it in the environmentally sensitive Black Hammock. To the west, the route would pose further engineering problems, said beltway environmental consultant W. Michael Dennis. State and federal officials are asking the expressway authority for certain safeguards before it could allow the road to be built so close to the nest. The authority would be required to prove the nest was new, leave a belt of trees between the nest and the road, halt construction during the Oct. 1 through May 15 nesting season, ensure that lights do not hit the nest and monitor the birds' reaction to the construction. Gerald Brinton, executive director of the expressway authority, said meeting those constraints would likely raise the cost of the $158 million project.

DOC.HEAD: Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu Makes Surprise Visit to Boston
DOC.TEXT: Jubilation over the pending release of South Africa's imprisoned black leader Nelson Mandela must be tempered with the realization that apartheid is far from ended, Archbishop Desmond Tutu said Saturday. Tutu, visiting to confer with other opposition leaders and U.S. officials, said the fight for equality is not over and urged continued political and economic pressure on the South African government to dismantle apartheid. ``We have not yet the complete dismantling of apartheid and this is the pinpoint of the sanction program. We want apartheid totally dismantled,'' said Tutu, the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize laureate. The Anglican archbishop said his initial joy over the lifting of some political restrictions against blacks Friday was tempered later by the realization that apartheid still is far from over. He said his change of heart came after ``having pinched myself and convinced myself it wasn't a dream and it was real. ... Of course you see apartheid is still in place.'' Tutu said he is looking forward to relinquishing his position as South Africa's pre-eminent opponent of apartheid now that Mandela is to be released from prison. ``I said long ago I was just an interim leader until he (Mandela) comes out,'' he said. ``He's been making us work too hard.'' Tutu was accompanied by Patrick Lekota, publicity secretary for the United Democratic Front. They were met at Logan International Airport by Themba Vilakazi, head of the Boston-based Fund for a Free South Africa, just returned from Zambia where the African National Congress is based. The group was met by Zenani Mandela Dlamini, 30, eldest daughter of Nelson and Winnie Mandela and a political science student at Boston University. Their arrival came less than 24 hours after South African President F.W. de Klerk announced in a speech to Parliament that Mandela would be released unconditionally, although he set no date. De Klerk also lifted bans on more than 30 opposition groups after three decades of underground activity against white rule, including the African National Congress, outlawed in 1960. The announcements appeared to clear the way for talks on a new constitution that would end the black majority's exclusion from national politics. Tutu, a member of Harvard University's Board of Overseers, was here to attend a meeting at the school. Lekota said he planned to attend a meeting of the Albert Einstein Institute, a Cambridge think tank that advocates the use of non-violent sanctions to solve political unrest. Mandela's daughter, greeted fondly by Tutu, told reporters she was skeptical of the recent changes in South Africa, despite the news her father would be released. ``This has been going on for 300 years,'' she said. ``What happened Friday, I'm not overly excited about it. Release some political prisoners, to me, that's nothing. We want total majority voting in South Africa. Until that happens, I will not be satisfied.'' Her husband, Thumbumuzi Dlamini, 39, is a prince from Swaziland, one of the sons of the late king Sobhuza II. His brother is now the king of Swaziland, an independent country almost completely surrounded by South Africa. They live in the Boston area with their three children. Lekota, who was recently released from prison, was more positive about the changes. He predicted members of the white minority in South Africa who resist change will eventually be forced to accept the idea of equality with blacks. ``They cannot stop us,' he said. ``We are unstoppable now.'' Lekota said he also planned to meet with Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., and State Department officials to give the South African black perspective on the recent turn of events.

DOC.HEAD: Moderate Elected Premier, New Government On Thursday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 7th graf `He later...' to UPDATE with head of government radio and TV resigning. Pickup 8th graf pvs, `Lukanov and...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto SOF2
DOC.TEXT: Parliament on Saturday elected an economist to replace a hard-line Communist as premier, and the new leader promised immediate reforms to combat Bulgaria's ``social and economic crisis.'' A leader of the emerging democratic opposition described the new premier, Andrei Lukanov, as ``a good choice'' and left open the possibility that some opposition members might join a coalition government. The election, the latest development in a wave of changes, came one day after the Communist Party expelled many of the old orthodox Communists and picked another advocate of change as party chief. Lukanov's government is to hold power until free elections are held in May. The National Assembly unanimously chose Lukanov as premier after accepting the resignation of former Premier Georgi Atanassov and his 22-member Cabinet. Lukanov, a 51-year-old economist with years of experience in government and party politics, said he was accepting the post at a time of ``moral and economic crisis.'' He later told reporters that his new government would liberalize the news media. He asked for ``constructive criticism by the press'' and ``complete objectivity.'' Apparently to underline the new leadership's more open media policy, Filip Bokov announced his resignation as head of state Radio and Television, a position he has held for less than three months. The official news agency BTA said the reason for his resignation was his appointment to the new Communist Party presidium, apparently to avoid a conflict of interest. Lukanov and his reform-minded colleagues _ new party chief Alexander Lilov and President Petar Mladenov _ face public skepticism about their commitment to reform, as well as their ability to handle a flagging economy hobbled by unprecedented labor unrest. ``We have to make fundamental economic reforms, and we have to do it immediately,'' he said. ``The social and economic crisis is now the most important thing, and it is the most important task to come out of the crisis.'' He said he would detail his recovery plan in a speech to the National Assembly on Thursday, when lawmakers will swear in the new government. It was not clear if Lukanov, Lilov or Mladenov would have the most substantive power in the new government. Mladenov on Nov. 10 replaced hard-line leader Todor Zhivkov after 35 years in power, and he promised free elections and oversaw the end to guaranteed Communist supremacy in Bulgaria. Lukanov has been the main negotiator for the party at broad talks with the opposition and is perceived by many Bulgarians as the most trustworthy Communist leader. Lukanov said the government must be rejuvenated and said he would move beyond career technocrats to choose a Cabinet with ``clever professionals and well-trained people.'' He said he was hopeful that opposition groups would support an interim coalition government. Petar Beron, a leader of the opposition Union of Democratic Forces, said earlier Saturday that his group would not take part, but later indicated that some coalition members might do so on their own. He said Lukanov was ``a good choice.'' He said the Communists have not said how much power they will share, and he predicted little chance of a real opposition role as long as the National Assembly is controlled by the Communists. The opposition's participation would be ``like a Muppet show,'' Beron said. Whatever its composition, the new government ``could not be worse than it has been up to now,'' Beron said. Blagovest Sendov, president of the Academy of Sciences, said only private initiative could pull Bulgaria out of its economic crisis. Lukanov did not reject private ownership outright but said this was one of various approaches to be considered in reforming the economy.

DOC.HEAD: Lab Loses Certification to Test Federal Workers For Drugs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf, `Ms. Pizzo ..., with 3 grafs to UPDATE with comment from company president.
DOC.TEXT: The company hired by the city of New Orleans to screen its employees for drugs has lost its certification to test federal workers. Laboratory Specialists Inc. is the first such lab in the nation to lose federal approval, according to the National Institute on Drug Abuse in Bethesda, Md. Since Jan. 24, the Belle Chasse company has been forbidden to test federal workers or those on federal contracts. The company is still allowed to test city employees and pursue other drug-testing contracts. Officials at the federal National Institute on Drug Abuse won't say why they rescinded LSI's certification other than that the lab failed to maintain standards to conduct urine drug testing for federal agencies. City personnel director Michael Doyle said it's not clear what effect the decertification would have on the city's new drug testing program. New Orleans police, firefighters and other employees have been subject to random drug testing since Jan. 1, but the results of testing _ or any resulting disciplinary or rehabilitation measures _ have not been announced. Twenty police officers per day have been selected randomly by computer for the past week and given about an hour's notice, police union members said. ``When you are dealing with someone's livelihood, I think you should go with the ultimate accreditation, and that's the federal government,'' said Michael Conn, treasurer of the Police Association of New Orleans. He did not say whether the union would challenge the testing program because of the decertification. LSI was chosen in December, partly because it was the only lab in the state with federal approval, Doyle said. A spokeswoman at NIDA said LSI was the first of 42 laboratories nationwide to lose federal certification. ``We are working with them to have it reinstated,'' NIDA spokeswoman Mona Brown said. The federal agency, which charges $17,000 a year for certification, inspects the labs twice a year and tests quality control every other month. LSI has been in the drug testing business for 11 years. The company has 500 to 600 customers nationwide, lab director Pat Pizzo said in November. ``I want to make it clear this is a suspension, not a revocation,'' said LSI President Arthur R. Peterson. He said he did not know what caused the suspension of the lab's federal certification, but that his company has been continuing talks with the federal agency to obtain reinstatement. Peterson said he had heard from some LSI clients, but had not discussed the matter with the city of New Orleans.

DOC.NOTE: For Release at 12:30 a.m. EST Sunday
DOC.HEAD: Senate Minority Leader Demands Removal of Foreign Forces From Lebanon
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs grafs 9-12, ``President Bush xxx to update with embassy changing hands in Washington
DOC.TEXT: Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole on Saturday lamented Lebanon's ``long night of death and destruction,'' saying all foreign forces should leave the war-torn country. ``For too many in Washington, Lebanon has fallen off the screen. The only `issues list' that it tops is the list of those issues to avoid in the future,'' the Kansas senator said. Dole said that factional strife among Christians in East Beirut, together with the continued presence of Syrian forces in the Middle Eastern country, does not point toward a peaceful resolution. ``Lebanon's long night of death and destruction continues,'' he said. In a speech prepared for a dinner sponsored by the American Task Force on Lebanon, an organization of some 100 prominent Americans of Lebanese descent, he called on Christians ``to end their bloody test of might and will.'' A copy of Dole's Los Angeles speech was released by his Washington office. As violence escalated last year, the United States withdrew Ambassador John McCarthy and other Americans on the U.S. Embassy staff. Only Lebanese remain at the embassy. Dole urged appointment of a special American envoy _ ``someone who will devote full time and attention to Lebanon, someone who will make it clear that the United States is serious about Lebanon.'' President Bush has deplored the increasing incidences of violence in Lebanon, and the administration went into federal court to win the ouster of Lebanese Gen. Michael Aoun's ambassador in Washington, Abdallah Bouhabib. The State Department argued that his continued occupation of the building was ``causing increasingly serious adverse consequences for the nation's foreign relations.'' The State Department sought Bouhabib's ouster at the request of Lebanon's new government led by President Elias Hrawi, who was elected in November with the backing of the 22-nation Arab League. The United States recognized the Hrawi government last November and had been conducting its business with a Hrawi-appointed ambassador rather than with Bouhabib even before before the embassy was turned over to Hrawi representatives Friday under a federal court order. Aoun, who controls Lebanon's Christian sector with about 1 million residents, refuses to recognize the Hrawi government and continues to hold out with 20,000 troops at the presidential palace in Beirut. The State Department has called for Aoun to step down. Dole said the United States should put pressure on Syrian President Hafez Assad to remove forces from Lebanon and said the Arab League should press Assad for a troop withdrawal timetable. He also said that Secretary of State James A. Baker, in talks with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze in Moscow this week, should say that ``as long as Moscow gives Assad the green light for aggression in Lebanon, the United States will keep out the yellow caution light on the path of U.S.-Soviet relations.'' ``I do believe it is my responsibility, as someone who cares deeply about Lebanon, to plead with every faction and every Lebanese leader (to) ... end the senseless killing,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Stormy Weather Pushes Eastward: Rain in South, Snow, Sleet Farther North
DOC.TEXT: A wide band of stormy weather socked the nation's midsection Saturday, bringing heavy rain to sections of the South and a mixture of snow, sleet and freezing rain to the north and east. Snow fell in the lower Great Lakes region and was spreading toward the Northeast, prompting winter storm watches or advisories for snow, rain and everything in between across most of the Middle Atlantic States and southern New England through the weekend. In the south-central United States, showers and thunderstorms extended from eastern Texas and the lower Mississippi Valley to the Ohio Valley. Strong thunderstorms developed along the central Gulf Coast. Parts of Tennessee, Kentucky, Arkansas and Louisiana got 2 to 3 inches of rain or more from Friday night to midday Saturday, and flash flood watches were posted in much of the area. Heavier rainfall totals for the six-hour period ending at 1 p.m. EST included 1.79 inches at Jackson, Ky.; 1.46 inches at Muscle Shoals, Ala.; 1.36 inches at Jackson, Tenn., 1.07 inch at Memphis, Tenn.; and 0.99 inch at Pine Bluff, Ark. On the Plains, a mixture of freezing rain, sleet and snow fell in parts of Kansas, Oklahoma, Missouri and Arkansas early in the afternoon. Wichita, Kan., got 2 inches of snow Saturday morning. Farther north, light snow extended from eastern Iowa to Upper Michigan. High winds in Maine dropped wind chills to 30 below. In the South, record high temperatures for the date were set. Birmingham, Ala., had a reading of 79 degrees by early afternoon, one degree higher than the 1932 record; Jacksonville, Fla., 86, two degrees higher than the 1989 record; and Merdian, Miss., 83, three degrees higher than the 1957 record. Baton Rouge, La., and Wilmington, N.C., both hit 82 degrees, tying records for the date. In the Pacific Northwest, a cold front spread rain and snow into Washington, Oregon and California, and winter storm warnings and advisories were posted in mountain regions. Winds gusting to 56 mph downed trees around Walla Walla, Wash. The low for the nation Saturday morning in the Lower 48 was 13 degrees below zero at Caribou, Maine, and Craig, Colo. Saturday's rain came a day after thunderstorms produced hail, strong winds and a couple of reported tornadoes across the lower Mississippi Valley. Tornadoes near Brewton Mill, La., and in Grenada County, Miss., damaged some homes but caused no injuries.

DOC.HEAD: Foes of Salvadoran Aid Protest Cristiani Visit
DOC.TEXT: Opponents of U.S. military aid to El Salvador staged a protest Saturday afternoon as President Alfredo Cristiani, in Boston for a ``private visit,'' left his hotel. About 25 protestors from the Boston-based Central American Solidarity Association shouted at Cristiani as he left the hotel garage at 1:15 p.m. in a limousine followed by a small caravan of security personnel. David Voisin, a spokesman for CASA, said the demonstrators were also protesting the slaying of six Jesuit priests in El Salvador last November. Voisin said Cristiani planned to meet with Cardinal Bernard Law in an effort to ease tensions between his government and the Roman Catholic Church, but spokesmen for the cardinal said no meeting was planned, A State Department spokesman would only say that Cristiani was in Boston for a ``private visit,'' The Boston Herald reported Saturday. Cristiani was in Washington earlier this week lobbying Capitol Hill to continue the $1.4 million-a-day El Salvador receives in U.S. aid.

DOC.HEAD: West Germans, Czechoslovaks Link Arms Across Border
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with tens of thousands crossing through Czechoslovak-West German border during the day, environmentalists reading letter to Czechoslovak President Havel. ADDS background. Pickup 9th graf pvs, `Referring to...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PRA5
DOC.TEXT:
Tens of thousands of people exercised their new freedom Saturday by forming a 100-mile human chain to protest a hydroelectric dam project on the Danube River, the government news agency said. The CTK news agency said 100,000 people from Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Austria formed the chain across territory in all three nations. Meanwhile, thousands of West Germans and Czechoslovak citizens formed a 2.5-mile human chain across their common border in a gesture of triumph over the waning divisions between East and West, CTK said. Tens of thousands of them passed through the border crossing where the chain was formed, drawing attention to the ``absurdity of the Iron Curtain,'' CTK said. Hard-line Communist regimes have been replaced by reformist governments in Czechoslovakia and Hungary in the past two years that have opened their borders with the West. While much of Eastern Europe's ``Iron Curtain'' has been torn down, the continent remains divided by the NATO and Warsaw Pact military alliances. Among those taking part was Czechoslovakia's foreign minister, former dissident Jiri Dienstbier. He was quoted as saying that a joint commmission to discuss the opening of new border crossings between the two countries would meet next week. In the hydroelectric dam protest, CTK said that up to 100,000 people helped form a human chain along the Danube over a span of about 100 miles from the town of Hainburg in Austria, across to Bratislava in Czechoslovakia and to Komarom in Hungary. Hungary's Parliament already voted to scrap its part of the joint dam project with Czechoslovakia, and the new Prague leadership has said it will review the environmental consequences of its part of the power plant at Gabcikovo. Activists read aloud a letter addressed to Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel, requesting his support for the demands that the project be stopped, MTI reported. Participants also called for Austria, Hungary and Czechoslovakia to create a nature reserve along the Danube, MTI said. In the Hungarian town of Visegrad, Andras Szekfue of the Hungarian Green Party told about 100 people that since the Hungarian part of the project at Nagymaros had been scrapped, they must help the Czechoslovaks stop the dam at Gabcikovo, a participant told The Associated Press.
Referring to the democratic revolutions that have swept the East bloc, Szekfue added: ``The good thing is that we no longer need to work in secret but can pursue our aims with democratic means.'' In the Hungarian city of Esztergom, activist Csaba Paska noted, ``the Danube links the people (of the three countries), and this dam which divides us was the work of politicians.'' Among placards and banners carried by protesters was one reading, ``Build bridges, not dams.'' Austrian and Hungarian environmentalists had long opposed the mammoth project, maintaining it would destroy unique wildlife and have other irreparable consequences for the Danube. The project was agreed on by the Communist governments in Prague and Budapest in the 1970s. Austria had agreed to finance part of the Hungarian project in exchange for electricity. The chain across the West German-Czechoslovak border was formed between the Czechoslovak town of Zlezna Ruda and the West German border town of Bayrisch Eisenstein, about 100 miles northeast of Munich.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Bradley's Political Mentor Got Thousands Through City
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Tom Bradley's political mentor received $336,000 in federal funds through the city to renovate a building he owned through a non-existent corporation, The Los Angeles Times reported Saturday. The City Council granted loans to Bishop H. Hartford Brookins between 1982 and 1985, apparently in violation of city bidding procedure and despite Brookins' refusal to provide financial information on some occasions, the Times reported, citing city officials and government records. In addition, an aide to Bradley repeatedly asked two city administrators to grant special help to the bishop, the officials said. A spokesman for Brookins referred questions about the matter to attorney J. Stanley Sanders, who said he did not know enough about it to comment. Bradley declined to be interviewed about Brookins, but the mayor's spokesman, Bill Chandler, said Bradley never spoke about the Brookins loan and said it ``never came to his attention'' until after it was repaid in 1988. The money came in the form of federally funded contracts, administered by the city's Community Development Department, to renovate a three-story building Brookins owns in southwest Los Angeles. Loan records indicate the building today is worth about $1 million. Brookins used some of the money to pay off $30,000 in ``personal obligations,'' according to district attorney investigative reports cited by the Times. In July, the district attorney's office dropped a two-year investigation into the loans because the statute of limitations for fraud and embezzlement had elapsed. Last month, the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development referred the Brookins case to its regional Office of Inspector General for possible investigation of misuse of government funds, HUD spokesman Scott Reed said. Brookins was the regional bishop of the African Methodist Episcopal Church from 1976 to 1984. He engineered Bradley's first campaign for City Council in 1963 and has been chairman or co-chairman of every campaign since. ``I mean literally, if I may, I almost hand-carried Bradley up his whole political career,'' Brookins said in a 1985 interview. Brookins currently is AME Church bishop for Maryland, Virginia and Washington, D.C. The building was owned by the Southern California African Methodist Episcopal Church Inc., of which Brookins is listed as sole corporate director. But the secretary of state's office said the firm was never incorporated in California. In 1982, the City Council instructed the Community Development Department to loan $238,000 to the company to renovate the building. No competing projects were considered, said Douglas S. Ford, the CDD's former general manager. ``The reality was that (Brookins) was politically connected and the contract came down through those channels, and we were in a position where we had to implement it,'' CDD analyst Arnold C. Garcia said. Brookins received more money from the City Council when the project ran out of funds in 1985, bringing the total to $336,000, records show. CDD analyst Richard Gallegos said supervisors ordered him to release the additional funds, even though Brookins had failed to provide property deeds, loan papers and other required documents for the contract. ``I was told pressure was coming from the mayor's office and we got to get this contract out,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Storm Kills 18 in France; Floods in Western England
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with 18 dead, hole in Chartes cathedral; pickup 9th graf pvs, `A 75-year-old...'
DOC.TEXT: A violent windstorm gusting up to 104 mph battered northern France on Saturday, tearing off roofs, cutting rail service in several areas and leaving more than 2 million people without electricity. At least 18 were killed. Among the buildings damaged was the 12th century cathedral at Chartres, one of the world's most magnificent Gothic structures. The wind peeled copper plates from the roof, leaving a 540-square-foot hole over the nave between the two bell towers of the church, 50 miles southwest of the capital. In western England, the rain-swollen Severn river rose 14 feet above normal and flooded towns and farmland along its banks. The riverside city of Worcester, 100 miles northwest of London, had its worst flooding in 25 years. Winds tore across Brittany, Normandy and the Paris regions, damaging roofs, blowing trees and electric lines across railways and roads, and disrupting air traffic. The St. Lazare railroad station in Paris, France's busiest, was closed about 2 p.m. and all rail service to Normandy cut off because of downed trees on tracks. Service also was cut between Paris and Rennes, capital of Brittany. As many as 5,000 passengers had to be transported in buses. Service was severely disrupted both at Charles de Gaulle and Orly airports in Paris, with only occasional takeoffs during the afternoon. The national Civil Defense office said at least 18 people died as a result of the storm, although the circumstances of all the deaths were not immediately known. A 75-year-old woman died in Rosny-sous-Bois when a bar from a shutter blew across a room and hit her in the head, fire department headquarters said. In Alfortville, a young man was killed by a fence post that hit him on the head. A motorcyclist was killed in the city of Moulins when he was hit in the head by a flying tree branch, and a truck driver died when a gust turned over his vehicle in the Ille-et-Vilaine region. The windstorm even delayed races at Vincennes Racetrack and forced closure of the Vincennes Zoo, where keepers put the animals indoors. The Paris Fire Department also said the wind caused the glass covering of a swimming pool at Villeneuve-Saint-Georges to explode, injuring about 15 children with flying glass.

DOC.HEAD: March Commemorating Stroessner Coup Anniversary Blocked
DOC.TEXT: Police blocked a march by the largest opposition party Saturday, the first anniversary of the military coup that toppled dictator Alfredo Stroessner. ``On the day that commemorates the end of an oppressive dictatorship ... they prohibit us from freely walking in the streets,'' said Domingo Laino, who was jailed and exiled by Gen. Stroessner but won a seat in Congress in national elections last May. The government did not say why they banned the peaceful demonstration by several hundred members of the Authentic Radical Liberal Party. ``The march is prohibited by the Ministry of the Interior, and I have precise orders to act to bar it,'' said police Gen. Francisco Sanchez. No clashes or injuries were reported. The police action was at odds with the generally improved climate of civil liberties since Stroessner was overthrown by his top general, Andres Rodriguez, on Feb. 3, 1989. Three months later, Rodriguez overwhelmingly was elected president. In interviews last week, political, labor and human rights leaders said the Rodriguez government was upholding civil rights and democratic liberties although it was clear Stroessner's Colorado Party and the armed forces still dominate government and commerce. ``We enjoy freedom of thought and expression,'' said Eduardo Escobar, a leader of the Pro Demos human rights group. ``That is an important achievement and an essential element in the process toward democracy.'' ``People are exercising their liberties _ calling radio stations about abuses, complaining about increased bus fares. This didn't happen before,'' said Benjamin Arditti, a political analyst. ``My concern is that political leaders aren't moving as fast as the desire for change.'' Rodriguez, 66, began the coup the night of Feb. 2, 1989. Stroessner surrendered before dawn the next day, after he was pinned down by tanks at the presidential escort battalion and several hundred soldiers defending him had been killed. On Friday, Rodriguez urged Paraguayans to bury any bitterness they may have for the past. In brief comments to reporters, Rodriguez said the anniversary ``is a day for reflection. ... I would like people to raise a prayer for the fallen.'' ``I hope we may forget rancors, hatreds, jealousy, selfishness and passions in order to live in peace and harmony,'' he said. ``May our prayers serve as a just remembrance for those who offered their lives for the liberty and democracy'' Paraguayans now enjoy.

DOC.HEAD: Vultures' Attraction For Vinyl Seats Vexes Boat Owners
DOC.TEXT: The unexplained attraction vultures have for vinyl seat covers has led a group of wealthy homeowners to seek expert help to chase away the bothersome buzzards. Len and Sandy Wilkerson moved to Kissimmee's exclusive Regal Bay neighborhood because they love wildlife: Osprey, white ibis and great blue herons stop on a small island in the neighborhood's manmade lake. Flocks of ugly vultures also are drawn to the area, spoiling the natural serenity of the $500,000 homes, said Sandy Wilkerson, ``They're always on my back porch,'' she said. ``The other day they were sitting up on the railing, staring at the cats. It was like the movie `The Birds.''' Besides their unsightliness, the flying freeloaders cause between $50 and $500 in property damage each month. For reasons unexplainable even to bird experts, vultures seem to be attracted to the smell of vinyl that cover most of the boat seats. ``They're vicious,'' said resident Judy Foster. ``They pick at the screens, the shingles, and the boat seats. ... They rip apart the boat seats.'' The Regal Bay Homeowners Association, determined to avoid Walt Disney World's environmental blunder with vultures last year, went straight to the experts. In January Disney paid $95,000 to settle 16 animal cruelty charges against five of its employees after the company was charged last summer with shooting, starving, dehydrating, harassing and beating vultures to death. In Regal Bay's case, a federal nuisance control officer _ sort of a vulture vigilante _ arrived Tuesday and bombed the tiny island with fireworks for two nights to scare the vultures away. Soon after the noise died down, the Florida Game and Fresh Water Fish Commission showed up. It seems two neighbors, members of the same homeowners group, called the state agency to complain that the action against the vultures was scaring off the other birds sharing the island. Bob Sauls, a state wildlife officer, said after a quick survey of the situation Thursday, ``I can see right off the bat, there are going to be problems.''

DOC.HEAD: Financial Deals Cost AMA Thousands
DOC.TEXT: The chief executive of the American Medical Association was one of four top staff members of the organization who benefited from a decade of money-losing financial deals, according to a published report. The Chicago Sun-Times reported in early Sunday editions that the AMA lost $45,000 when it purchased the suburban Inverness home of Dr. James H. Sammons. The association paid $280,000 for the home in 1984 and sold it the next year for $235,000. Sammons, the association's chief executive officer, later moved into a Chicago high-rise condominium owned by the AMA, where he paid below-market rent, the newspaper reported, citing unidentified sources. The AMA lost $23,000 after purchasing the Wheaton home of Joe D. Miller for $170,000 in 1980 and selling it later for $147,000. Miller retired at the end of 1982. Relocation experts said corporations expect to lose 5 percent to 6 percent buying and reselling a house, but the AMA lost 16 percent on Sammons' home and 13.5 percent on Miller's home, the newspaper said. The AMA's board of trustees released a statement Friday that said the purchases of Miller's and Sammons' residences ``were authorized by the board of trustees, at prices arrived at by independent outside appraisals, and they were for the convenience and benefit of the association.'' The newspaper quoted unidentified AMA trustees who served in 1980 and 1984 saying they did not recall being told the group was buying the homes of Sammons and Miller. Sammons has been under fire in recent months following the disclosures of various financial decisions. In December, the AMA board of directors curtailed Sammons' broad financial discretion and announced that he would retire in 1991. In a 1987 deal, the AMA reimbursed its chief operating officer, Whalen M. Strobhar, $353,000 to cover stock market loses to his pension-fund investments. Strobhar resigned and later repaid the amount with interest. The doctors' group lost $65,000 in 1989 when it foreclosed on a loan to Assistant Vice President Richard Noffke. He was loaned about $267,000 to buy a Chicago condo. Sammons did not inform the board of the stock-loss bailout and foreclosure settlement he had authorized. The Chicago-based AMA's 280,000 members account for about half the doctors in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Seizes 4,719 Pounds of Cocaine in Orange County Raid
DOC.TEXT: Police and federal agents Saturday displayed more than two tons of cocaine seized in a raid on an Orange County warehouse, but there were no arrests made, authorities said. The estimated wholesale value of the 4,719 pounds of cocaine was nearly $36.5 million, said FBI spokesman Jim Neilson. The drug, neatly wrapped in banded boxes on pallets in a truck and secured with shrink-wrap plastic, was seized late Friday from an unoccupied warehouse that was apparently a distribution center, Neilson said. Orange County sheriff's investigators and police from Gardena and Santa Ana took part in the raid, the latest in a series of ton-load cocaine seizures in Southern California. In December, 2{ tons of the drug were seized in raids in Los Angeles and San Bernardino counties. In September, a world-record 20 tons was seized at a warehouse in the Sylmar section of Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Spreading Rapidly Among Drug Users In Europe, WHO Says
DOC.TEXT: AIDS is spreading nearly twice as fast among intravenous drug users in Europe than among the continent's homosexual men, the World Health Organization said. More than 11,500 new cases of the deadly disease were reported worldwide in January, bringing the total to 215,144, the agency reported Friday in its weekly bulletin. The United States had the biggest share of new cases, 4,500. Brazil and Tanzania recorded about 1,500 each, and Italy reported 644 new cases. In Europe, total reported cases rose to 29,727 by the end of January. A special World Health Organization survey of the continent found a sharp rise in acquired immune deficiency syndrome among intravenous drug users in the year ending last September. Reported cases in that group grew by 103 percent, compared to a 55 percent rise among homosexual and bisexual men. The report did not specify the countries where the increases occurred. But it noted that AIDS spread especially rapidly over the one-year period in Spain and Italy, where about two-thirds of all reported victims are intravenous drug users. According to the survey, the biggest number of cases per week were recorded in France, followed by Spain and Italy. AIDS destroys the body's immune system, leaving it vulnerable to other disease. There is no known cure. Despite the shifting trends, homosexuals and bisexuals still account for 49 percent of all European cases reported over the years until Sept. 30, the World Health Organization said. Drug users were 30 percent of the total. Switzerland continued to report the continent's highest number of cases per capita, 158.5 per million inhabitants. France, Spain and Denmark were next hardest-hit. European women who contracted AIDS were younger than men, the survey said. The percentage of European heterosexuals, both men and women, with the disease has grown from 6.6 percent in 1986 to 8.8 percent last year, the health agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Members of Presidential Science Advisory Committee Listed
With AM-Global Warming
DOC.TEXT: President Bush met Saturday with members of the President's Council of Advisers On Science and Technology, whom he appointed Friday. The committee is to advise him on a wide range of issues concerning science and technology, including research and development and increasing U.S. competition on the world scene. The chairman of the panel is Bush's national science adviser, D. Allan Bromley of Connecticut. He has the title of assistant to the president in his post as director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy. The other members are: _ Norman Borlaug, a Nobel laureate from Texas who is leader of the Sasakawa-Global-2000 agricultural program in sub-Saharan Africa. He is a professor of international agriculture at Texas A&M University. _ Solomon J. Buchsbaum, of New Jersey, senior vice president for technology at AT&T Bell Laboratories, who won the President's National Medal of science in 1986. _ Charles L. Drake, of Vermont, professor of earth sciences and geology at Dartmouth. _ Ralph E. Gomory, of New York, who is president of the Sloan Foundation and recently retired as senior vice president for science and technology for IBM Corp. _ Bernadine Healy, of Ohio, chairman of the Research Institute of the Cleveland Clinic Foundation, and a staff member of the clinic's cardiology department. She is immediate past president of the American Heart Association and former president of the American Federation for Clinical Research. _ Peter W. Likins of Pennsylvania, president of Lehigh University, and former engineering professor at UCLA and Colombia University. _ Thomas E. Lovejoy, of Virginia, assistant secretary for external affairs at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington and president of the Society for Conservation Biology. _ Walter E. Massey, of Illinois, vice president of the University of Chicago and professor of physics. He is president-elect of the American Physical Society and past president and chairman of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. _ John P. McTague, of Michigan, vice president for research at Ford Motor Company. _ Daniel Nathans, a 1978 Nobel laureate from Maryland, who is professor of molecular biology and genetics at the Johns Hopkins University Medical School and senior investigator of the Howard Hughes Medical Institute. _ David Packard, of California, chairman of the board of Hewlett-Packard Co. He won the President's National Medal of Technology and the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 1988. _ Harold T. Shapiro, of New Jersey, president of Princeton University.

DOC.HEAD: Students March to Demand Reforms
DOC.TEXT: More than 40,000 high school and university students marched through Rome on Saturday to demand reform in the Italian educational system. ``We want to study, we want jobs, so the schools must change,'' the students shouted. The peaceful demonstration was organized by a group of Naples high school students angered by the decision of the national Education Ministry not to include many students in a convention on the Italian school system. Many of the Naples students belonged to the youth group of the Communist Party, Italy's biggest opposition party, newspapers reported. The students demanded that studies be updated to reflect changes in society and that the government not reduce its commitment to schools under a new plan granting them more autonomy. The plan would allow businesses to become more involved in higher education, and the protesters say private industry utlimately would have too much influence at state-run universities.

DOC.HEAD: IRA at Issue as Political Supporters Meet
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To ADD details on proposed party platform, INSERT 3 grafs after 9th graf pvs; pickup 10th graf pvs, `Party officials...'
DOC.TEXT: The Irish Republican Army's political wing on Saturday discussed how to broaden its voter appeal, while demonstrators outside brought a coffin and signs saying ``The IRA Kills Democracy.'' The annual convention of the Sinn Fein party came a week after an IRA bomb accidentally killed a 16-year-old boy in Londonderry, Northern Ireland. Although Sinn Fein President Gerry Adams said a year ago that such ``mistakes'' were retarding the cause of a united Ireland, there was no repeat this year of his call for the IRA to be ``careful and careful again.'' Instead, Adams asserted that the mainly Catholic IRA was winning in its 21-year-old battle to end British rule in Protestant-dominated Northern Ireland and unite it with the Republic of Ireland. He called on the British government to open unconditional negotiations. Peter Brooke, Britain's top official in Northern Ireland, a British province, said recently that talks could be considered only after the IRA campaign ended. Outside the Mansion House, where Ireland's first legislature met in 1919, the armed campaign was denounced by members of the Irish Peace Council and New Consensus, a group that was formed to protest IRA bombings of the Dublin-Belfast railway line. ``One percent is no consent,'' said one placard, referring to Sinn Fein's share _ actually 1.2 percent _ in last summer's elections in the Republic of Ireland. Within Northern Ireland, Sinn Fein's share of the vote has slipped from 13.4 percent in 1983 to 11.3 percent in 1989. It consisently runs behind the Social Democratic and Labor Party in competition for votes from the province's Roman Catholic minority. ``We need to consider why we are not as strong as we could be,'' Adams told the convention. ``We have not done and are not doing sufficient political work.'' The party was midway through a three-day debate on a political report that proposed a more active publicity effort ``to defeat black propaganda about republicanism'' and to emphasize to Protestants that they would not be excluded from a united Ireland. It proposed to support divorce, which is outlawed in the Republic and is a sore point between Protestants and Catholics. The report said the underlying cause of poverty, unemployment and emigration is ``British imperialism and partition of our country.'' Party officials say they have been hurt by being banned from appearing on British TV and radio _ they are also banned in Ireland _ but they admit that IRA killings of innocent civilians have hurt. Since Adams' appeal last year, the IRA's victims have included a 20-year-old woman killed when a bomb exploded prematurely, a 52-year-old Belfast man mistaken for someone else, a 26-year-old German wife of a British soldier and a 6-month-old baby shot to death in the arms of her soldier father in West Germany. A week ago, 16-year-old Charles Love was fatally injured by a piece of stone dislodged by a bomb 500 yards away on the city wall of Londonderry. He was attending a march commemorating 13 people shot to death by the British Army in 1972 during a civil rights march.

DOC.HEAD: Two Palestinian Guerrillas Killed In Clash With Israeli Troops
DOC.TEXT: A radical Palestinian group said Israeli troops killed two of its guerrillas during a clash Saturday in Israel's self-proclaimed buffer zone in southern Lebanon. The Palestinian Liberation Front claimed killing ``several'' Israeli soldiers in the fight, but an Israeli army spokesman denied any army casualties. The group, led by terrorist mastermind Mohammed Abbas, better known as Abul Abbas, said in a communique that one of its guerrilla squads clashed with an Israeli patrol in Ein Ebl on the northern edge of the zone. It said the three-man squad was heading out on an anti-Israeli ``combat mission'' inside the Israeli-occupied Palestinian territories when they were confronted by the patrol. ``Our heroes engaged the enemy in a pitched battle that left several enemy soldiers killed or wounded and destroyed a half-track armor vehicle,'' the communique said. The communique, issued in Beirut, said two of the guerrillas were killed and that the third was wounded but managed to return to base. Israel maintains about 1,000 troops, with armor and artillery, in the six- to 10-mile buffer zone carved out when the Israelis withdrew the bulk of their army in 1985, three years after it invaded.

DOC.HEAD: Ports Paralyzed As Dockworkers Renew Strike
DOC.TEXT: The nation's 2,800 dockworkers went on strike Saturday, paralyzing Greece's ports. The dockworkers are demanding an extra $50 a day for handling hazardous loads, as well as improved pension and health insurance plans. The Union of Port Employees of Greece says it expects the strike to last at least a week. The dockworkers have staged repeated strikes and slowdowns in recent weeks. Some freighters have been redirected to other European ports while others languish at Greek docks. In an interview with the Greek daily newspaper Ethnos, Spiros Marinakis, president of the International Shipping Union _ a group representing firms in Athens _ said the strikes are causing serious long-term damage to Greek shipping. Greece has been plagued by labor unrest since last month, when the government announced austerity measures to battle an annual inflation rate of nearly 15 percent and a $1.6 billion budget deficit. Bus drivers, electricians and television and bank employees have called slowdowns for this week, and the national confederation of labor unions has threatened to hold its second general strike of the year in mid-February.

DOC.HEAD: Bandits Bind, Gag Custodians, Rob Treasures at Herculaneum
DOC.TEXT: Masked gunmen bound and gagged unarmed guards early Saturday at Herculaneum, a Roman city destroyed when Mount Vesuvius erupted in 79 A.D., and stole hundreds of treasures, news reports said. Baldassare Conticello, the superintendent of the archaeological areas of Herculaneum and nearby Pompeii, said the inventory of the stolen goods was still incomplete, the Italian news agency AGI reported. The missing items included about 200 gold bracelets and earrings, a first century bronze vase in the form of a woman's head and a 32-inch silver-and-copper inlaid bronze statue of Bacchus, he said. At least four bandits wearing ski masks surprised four night watchmen at their station, AGI quoted investigators as saying. The custodians were forced at gunpoint to turn over the keys to a building that houses hundreds of artifacts, the news agency said. It said the custodians were tied up and their mouths taped with bandages. After a few hours, one of the guards was able to free himself and sounded an alarm. Conticello said sale of the stolen goods would be difficult since they were cataloged. But he said it was possible someone had commissioned the holdup to enrich a personal collection. Walter Mazzitti, the head of Archeoclub of Italy, an organization of people interested in archaeology, decried what he called a lack of adequate security at major ruins in the Naples area and syggested that guards there should be armed. Herculaneum, along the Bay of Naples and with the volcano at its back, included the villas of wealthy ancient Romans. Its ruins, discovered in 1709, are considered better preserved than those at the more extensive complex at Pompeii, which was also destroyed by Mount Vesuvius' eruption.

DOC.HEAD: Topeka School Board to Appeal Desegregation Decision
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Supreme Court will be asked to review this city's progress in desegregating its schools after the landmark 1954 Brown vs. Board of Education decision declaring segregated schools unconstitutional, it was announced Saturday. Board of Education members told a news conference they will appeal a lower court ruling that held Topeka schools were not sufficiently integrated. The board decided to appeal because it felt the district was integrated and wanted to maintain local control of the school system, said Superintendent Gary Livingston. ``Children want the right to go to school where they live,'' Livingston said. Plaintiffs' attorney Richard Jones said he was disappointed by the decision. The Supreme Court ruled in 1954 that segregated schools deprived black children of equal educational opportunities and reinforced the concept that blacks were inferior. A black railroad worker, Oliver Brown, had sued the school district because his daughter was not allowed to attend an all-white school near their home. The case was reopened in 1979 by the parents of 17 black schoolchildren, who alleged the district had not desegregated schools. U.S. District Judge Richard Rogers ruled against the plaintiffs in 1987, but was overruled by the 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. The school board said it feared a court would order busing in the district if the appeals court ruling was not appealed. ``I think that's a possibility,'' said Joe Zima, attorney for the board. ``We're not there yet, but if we don't appeal it, we'll be there.''

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Perform First `Lung Assist' Implant in Human
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15th graf, `The developer ...,' to CORRECT that centers in Europe and Japan have applied, sted been approved, for testing the device.
DOC.HEAD: LaserGraphic NY11
DOC.TEXT: A teen-age girl was in critical condition Saturday after becoming the world's first recipient of an implant consisting of a slender bundle of fibers that works like a lung in supplying oxygen to the body. The 20-inch device _ designed to give damaged lungs a chance to rest and recover before it is removed _ was implanted in a two-hour operation Friday at LDS Hospital, one of four U.S. centers approved for testing of the IntraVascular Oxygenator. ``This patient could live and the device could be useless,'' Dr. Alan Morris, the hospital's director of pulmonary research, said at an afternoon news conference. ``She could pass away and it could be a perfectly useful device.'' Morris emphasized that it was far too early to evaluate the devices's performance. ``There is a grave risk of misrepresentation,'' he said, if the mechanism is seen as anything more than an experiment. The IVOX is not an artificial lung but could lead to development of such a device, said its developer, Dr. J.D. Mortensen. The family insisted that no details about the patient be made public, but sources confirmed the recipient was a teen-age girl with acute respiratory failure. The Salt Lake Tribune reported she is 16. Morris described the patient as ``a suffering individual whose privacy must be protected at all costs'' for research protocol and ethical reasons. Hospital spokesman Richard Nash said only that the patient was in critical condition. The device was implanted by Dr. Roger C. Millar. Although he assisted in the surgery, Mortensen would not discuss particulars of the implant, which involved insertion of the device via the neck or groin into the inferior vena cava, the large vein that brings blood to the heart. Two tubes the diameter of a soda straw are attached to the bundle and leave the body; one delivers oyxgen to the body from a hospital oxygen system or tank, the other removes carbon dioxide, a waste product of breathing. Mortensen said the initial experiments will involve only patients with acute lung disease, such as pneumonia or smoke inhalation, not long-term, chronic disorders such as cystic fibrosis or emphysema. The only alternative for people with acute lung failure is an extracorporeal oxygenator, a large machine that requires pumping the blood outside the body. Guidelines approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration in September limit the implants to seven days in people with acute respiratory failure who have little other chance of survival. ``In patients with acute lung failure, the natural lungs can recover in four to five days if given a chance to rest,'' Mortensen said. If they do not recover by then, ``they probably aren't going to. ... You have dead lungs.'' The developer of the IVOX, CardioPulmonics Inc. of Salt Lake City, announced Jan. 11 the device would be tested in 10 patients at LDS Hospital, Penn State's Hershey Medical Center, the University of Michigan Medical Center in Ann Arbor, and the Los Angeles County-University of Southern California Medical Center. Several centers in Europe and Japan have applied to test the device. Mortensen said about eight of the 10 initial human recipients were expected to die from their illnesses. Mortensen said the IVOX acts much like the natural membranes in the air sacs of the lungs. The device is an inch-wide bundle of 900 to 1,200 hollow fibers each about the thickness of a human hair. The polypropylene fibers have porous walls. The bundle is covered with a super-thin plastic membrane. As the IVOX floats in the blood flowing through the vena cava, oxygen passes through the fiber walls into the oxygen-poor blood. Meanwhile, carbon dioxide passes from the blood through the fiber wall into the hollow fiber. Mortensen said the initial human experiments are to determine IVOX's safety, not effectiveness. ``These are extremely sick patients that have advanced lung disease, whose lungs are unable to support life, and are in the process of dying from their lung disease,'' he said. ``We're trying to see if the device will cause further complications for the patient. ``If it does not, then the FDA will release it for testing on healthier patients.'' The IVOX was made possible by membrane technology that allows much higher concentrations of oxygen through the tiny polypropylene tubes. In animal tests lasting up to 19 days, the IVOX did not damage the blood or organs of 150 sheep and dogs. LDS Hospital, once named Latter-day Saints Hospital when it was owned by the Mormon Church, is a few miles from the University of Utah Health Sciences Center, where doctors in 1982 implanted the world's first permanent artificial heart in a human.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Empaneled Quickly, To Be Sworn Monday
DOC.TEXT: Jury selection went faster than expected for the trial of Joseph Hazelwood, the ex-captain of the Exxon Valdez blamed for the nation's worst oil spill, clearing the way for opening arguments Monday. The 12 jurors and three alternates are to be sworn in Monday for the criminal trial of Hazelwood, who was in command of the tanker when it struck a Prince William Sound reef last March and spilled nearly 11 million gallons of oil. Attorneys for Hazelwood and the state had expected jury selection would take two weeks because of publicity about the accident that polluted pristine waters, tarred shorelines, killed wildlife and disrupted fishing. But by lunchtime Friday, the fourth day of jury screening, the court had a panel of 12 members from among 52 candidates questioned in Hazelwood's criminal trial. He faces a felony charge of criminal mischief and misdemeanor charges of reckless endangerment, negligent discharge of oil and operating a vessel while intoxicated. Conviction on all charges could produce a maximum penalty of seven years, three months in prison and $61,000 in fines. Some prospective jurors were excused immediately after they said they held opinions about Hazelwood. Others were eliminated after questioning which determined they could not set aside their conclusions about the case. Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone said toward the end of the selection process that the number of candidates whose acceptability went unchallenged by attorneys was high. Of 44 people questioned, 27 were in that category, he said. Although everyone questioned knew of the oil spill, most said they had little or no opinion about it. Johnstone said he found that hard to believe, but added that such statements made under oath had to be accepted as the truth. The judge granted attorneys for both sides extra peremptory challenges that allowed them to rule out candidates without saying why. Hazelwood attorney Dick Madson said he needed additional challenges in part because two of the potential jurors were so familiar with the case they practically qualified as witnesses. In granting the state an extra challenge, Johnstone said he detected ``an undercurrent of feeling by jurors that perhaps there are others who are responsible for this (Exxon Valdez) incident, including the state.'' District Attorney Brent Cole had not used his extra challenge by the time the jury was chosen. Madson said the jury represents a good cross-section of the Anchorage-area population. Occupations of jurors include mail carrier, cook, homemaker, business executive, engineer, grocer, real estate agent and child-care worker. The trial that began with preliminary matters last Monday and then moved into jury selection could last six weeks or more. It originally was scheduled for October in Valdez, the port from which the tanker sailed just hours before the crash. The trial was moved to Anchorage in the interest of obtaining a fair proceeding, although Madson proposed Fairbanks or Palmer as better locations. In deciding the venue, Johnstone said that if Oliver North could get a fair trial despite the vast publicity his case received, then Hazelwood could get a fair proceeding in Anchorage. Lawyers for Hazelwood, who was absent from the tanker's bridge when the vessel ran aground, are expected to argue that he left adequate instructions for crew members and cannot be held criminally responsible for their actions. The state's attorneys refused to discuss the case and Cole has not revealed his plans.

DOC.HEAD: Third Teen-ager in a Week is Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `Saturday's march ...,' to ADD number of demonstrators.
DOC.TEXT: A boy who authorities said tried to rob a grocery store customer with an unloaded gun became the third teen-ager in a week shot to death by police. In Brooklyn, where police fatally shot two unarmed teen-agers on Jan. 27 and Wednesday, residents held a largely peaceful march Saturday that ended with a demonstration at a stationhouse. The latest shooting came Friday night in Harlem when 13-year-old Robert Cole was shot after he refused to drop a .32-caliber handgun after trying to rob a man in a grocery, said Sgt. Nick Vreeland, a police spokesman. Cole, who was carrying 35 vials of what appeared to be crack, was struck in the chest by a bullet fired by Officer Larry Walton, 31, Vreeland said. He was pronounced dead at a hospital. Cole was the eighth person fatally shot by police in the first five weeks of this year. In 1989, 30 people were killed by police; in 1988, 25 died and in 1987, 14. Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown, who took office just last month, said Friday he wants officers to spend more time in the communities they protect to gain a better understanding of residents. Saturday's march concluded with a rally outside a Brooklyn stationhouse, where about 300 demonstrators called for the suspension without pay of Officer Frank Albergo, who fatally shot 14-year-old Jose Lebron on Wednesday. Lebron, suspected in a $10 robbery, was killed when Albergo thought he saw the unarmed teen-ager reaching into his coat and feared he was going for a gun, police said. Four days earlier and five blocks away, 17-year-old Louis Liranso was shot in the back and killed by an officer after the unarmed Liranso allegedly lowered his hands and turned toward the officer. In Friday's slaying, police said Cole and an accomplice tried to rob a 42-year-old grocery store customer, but the man got Cole's gun away from him. Cole fled, got another gun and began chasing the man. The customer escaped by flagging down an ambulance, but the boy continued after it, police said. When the ambulance arrived at its destination, an accident scene about three blocks from the grocery store, the customer told officers there what had happened. The boy arrived, officers ordered him at least twice to drop his gun, but the boy kept advancing and raised the gun, Vreeland said. It turned out that the gun used in the attempted robbery and the gun Cole had later were unloaded, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Shoemaker's Last Ride Finishes Out of the Money
LaserPhoto LA909
DOC.TEXT: For the 31,517th and final time, Bill Shoemaker failed to win a horse race, but the 58-year-old jockey still entered his retirement Saturday as the world's winningest rider. Shoemaker rode a horse named Patchy Groundfog to a fourth-place finish in a one-time-only stakes race at Santa Anita called the Legend's Last Ride. The $7,500 pot for fourth place in the 11-horse field boosted Shoemaker's career earnings to $123,375,524 on a record of 8,833 victories, 6,136 seconds and 4,987 thirds in 40,350 starts. It looked briefly as if Shoemaker would post win No. 8,834 when he put Patchy Groundfog into the lead at the top of the stretch of the one-mile stakes on the grass. The crowd roared, but just as quickly as Patchy Groundfog got the lead, he lost it. In the stretch run, Shoemaker got Patchy Groundfog into the lead as the race caller shouted, ``Come on, Shoe.'' But it was not to be. Exemplary Leader surged past on the inside and won over Happy Toss. Oraibi edged Patchy Groundfog by a head for third. Shoemaker was honored at a ceremony before the race, and then to warm applause and chants of ``Shoe, Shoe, Shoe.'' Patchy Groundfog carried the Shoe onto the racetrack for the final time at 2:32 p.m. At the pre-race ceremony, Shoemaker said, ``One more race to go. I want to thank all you fans who supported me all these years.'' Shoemaker will turn to training horses. He passed his trainer's license test Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Bishop Claiming To Be New Patriarch Barricades Self in Monastery
DOC.TEXT: A bishop claiming to be the new Armenian patriarch of Jerusalem barricaded himself in a monastery with submachine gun-toting bodyguards and officials protested to police Saturday, a church spokesman said. Bishop Shahe Ajemian entered the St. James convent and monastery Friday, a day after the death of Patriarch Yeghishe Derderian and reportedly declared himself successor. The Armenian patriarch is the spiritual leader of 8,000 Armenian Christians in Israel, the occupied West Bank and Jordan. He is also one of the custodians of Jerusalem's holy places, along with the Greek Orthodox and Latin patriarchs. A church spokesman said on condition of anonymity that Ajemian was surrounded by eight Israeli bodyguards carrying Uzi submachine guns. He said the Israelis worked for a private security company and had no connection to the government. The spokesman said the church issued a formal complaint to Police Minister Chaim Bar Lev concerning the violation of church grounds. Ajemian was expelled from the brotherhood of the monastery in 1982 after a series of scandals and is ineligible for the role of patriarch. ``This man was dismissed from the brotherhood, but he keeps trying to enter by wicked means,'' said Albert Alghazarian, a prominent member of the Armenian community. ``He can do or say whatever he wants, but he can not even legitimately enter the room where the voting will take place.'' The 60 members of the worldwide Brotherhood of St. James are expected to elect a new patriarch within 40 days of the death of Derderian. The 80-year-old patriarch died of a heart attack after being ill with influenza for two days, officials said. Bishop Guregh Kapikian has been named acting patriarch. The Armenian Church is an eastern rite church organized along ethnic lines and does not accept the authority of the pope. There are about 7.5 million Armenians worldwide, including 1 million in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Costa Ricans Ready For Quadrennial Civic Fiesta
DOC.TEXT: Flag-waving crowds vied good-naturedly in the streets of this capital as Costa Ricans got worked up for Sunday's presidential election _ a civic fiesta. ``It is very satisfying to return to Costa Rica, especially as an election observer,'' said Joao Baena Soares, secretary general of the Organization of American States. Baena Soares arrived Friday from neighboring Nicaragua, where the bitter and controversial election campaign sharply contrasts with Costa Rica's friendly democratic tradition. Rafael Angel Calderon of the Social Christian party was considered a slight favorite over Carlos Manuel Castillo of the incumbent National Liberation party. The winner will take office on May 8. Five minor candidates together are expected to garner less than 5 percent of the vote. Voters will also elect 57 National Assembly delegates and 525 mayors. More than 80 percent of the nation's 1.6 million registered voters are expected to cast ballots. Luis Fishman, a top Calderon aide, said Saturday that the latest party poll indicated a substantial victory for his candidate, while Castillo said he would win by a slim 25,000 votes. By another of the many gentlemen's agreements that rule Costa Rican politics, no independent poll has been conducted since Dec. 10, when Calderon had a 5 percent lead with 20 percent undecided. The candidates were clearly reluctant to speak ill of each other during the campaign, although Calderon brought up embarrassing ties to drug traffickers and Castillo mentioned that Calderon was born in Nicaragua. In the narcotics case, a former National Liberation president admitted accepting more than $100,000 from an indicted drug trafficker. The case was thought to have hurt Castillo, but Fishman said Calderon's main advantage is simply that National Liberation has won the last two elections. ``No party has won three presidential elections in a row since 1948,'' noted Fishman. ``Costa Ricans don't like to leave one party in power too long.'' Castillo partisans counter that the country has experienced eight years of good government under presidents Luis Alberto Monge and Oscar Arias, including a recovery from economic doldrums in the early 1980. Both major candidates support Arias' efforts to promote peace in Central America, efforts that won him the Nobel Peace Prize. He cannot run again, however. The Social Christian party appeared to be better organized and funded for get-out-the-vote efforts. A national computer center was prepared to tell uncertain voters where their precincts were located. Also planned was a national youth poll, in which children vote at local schools and go through exactly the same process as their elders in an exercise to reinforce their understanding of and commitment to democracy. On Saturday, cars swept through the city bearing partisans of the major parties, with the green-and-white flags of National Liberation or the red-and-blue of the Social Christians waving from windows. Every evening for the last week crowds have gathered on the streets to wave flags, chant, cheer and jeer, with the weekend festivities lasting into the early morning hours. The 1990 vote will mark the 10th consecutive peaceful national election for Costa Rica, a mark unmatched in Central America.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Protesters Arrested Outside Three Clinics
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested and carried away 143 abortion protesters Saturday after they locked the entrances to two downtown abortion clinics with bicycle locks in an ``all-women's rescue.'' In an unrelated abortion protest, 35 men and one woman were arrested Saturday morning outside a clinic in northeast Philadelphia. Police Sgt. David Brown said the protesters were taken to the Police Academy, where they were issued citations for trespassing. Abortion-rights supporters held counterdemonstrations at all three sites, but Brown said there were no reports of violence. Jean Hunt, executive director of the Elizabeth Blackwell Health Center For Women, one of the downtown clinics, said the protesters harassed patients and closed the clinic's back doors with bicycle locks that had to be cut off by the Fire Department. The protesters caused a ``massive disruption'' but did not deter any of the 25 or so women with appointments Saturday from entering the clinic, Hunt said. ``They can do this until the cows come home, we're still going to be open for business,'' she said. Brown said about 120 women protested at the Planned Parenthood clinic and 30 or 40 blocked the entrance to the Elizabeth Blackwell clinic. Police arrested 143 protesters at the Elizabeth Blackwell clinic. The day's protests began at the Northeast Women's Center, where mostly male protesters began arriving at 6:45 a.m., Brown said. None of the counterdemonstrators was arrested, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Government Claims Mavinga Recaptured from UNITA Rebels
DOC.TEXT: The Angolan army Saturday claimed its forces recaptured a strategic airstrip from U.S.-backed rebels after bitter fighting in southeastern Angola, the Portuguese news agency Lusa reported. Lusa quoted an Angolan army statement and said it was the first official admission of any military action near the Mavinga airstrip. The communique said the Marxist government's troops were ``continuing punitive actions'' to the south of the town, Lusa reported.
