In a dispatch from the Angolan capital, Luanda, Lusa quoted the statement as saying government forces ``dislodged the bands of UNITA from Mavinga'' Friday evening. The acronym stands for National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, the rebel group. Mavinga's airstrip is considered vital for control of the southeastern region and the key for any government attack on rebel headquarters at Jamba, more than 120 miles farther south toward the Namibian border. Rebel leader Jonas Savimbi denied in a statement released in Lisbon Saturday that Mavinga had fallen. ``The situation is difficult, but Mavinga has not fallen into the hands of the MPLA (government forces), and UNITA cannot, at any price, allow (them) to occupy Mavinga,'' Savimbi said in the statement. MPLA, or the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola, is the party of President Jose Eduardo dos Santos. Norberto de Castro, the rebels' spokesman in Lisbon, said Savimbi was directing operations in Mavinga under heavy air bombardment. Savimbi cut short a five-nation European tour on Tuesday to lead the fighting. An estimated 10,000 government soldiers began the drive on Mavinga late in December. Washington has urged dos Santos' government to halt the attack, and some U.S. congressmen have proposed an increase in military aid to the rebels, who reportedly already receive $50 million a year. Diplomats in Luanda and Lisbon say the government would likely use Mavinga to pressure the rebels in a new round of direct peace talks, rather than push the military offensive toward Jamba. A first round of negotiations, that began after dos Santos and Savimbi agreed to a truce in June, collapsed within weeks amid renewed fighting. The rebels have been fighting for a power-sharing agreement since Angola gained independence from Portugal in 1975. They are demanding free elections, but Dos Santos' government is offering amnesty and integration of the rebels into a single-party state.

DOC.HEAD: Greek Consul Ordered Expelled In Retaliation For Greek Expulsion Of Turk
DOC.TEXT: The government Saturday declared the Greek consul general in Istanbul ``persona non grata'' and asked him to leave the country within a week in retaliation for Athens' expulsion of a Turkish consul. The Turkish consul ordered to leave was in Komotini, a town in the Greek region of Western Thrace troubled by ethnic unrest by the 120,000-strong Moslem minority there. Both sides gave a week for the departure of the Turkish consul, Kemal Gur, and the Greek diplomat, Elias Klis. ``The reprisal for Komotini is Istanbul,'' Turkish Foreign Minister Mesut Yilmaz was quoted as saying Saturday. Greece said Friday that the Turkish consul was ``persona non grata'' for referring to the Moslem minority as ``fellow countrymen.'' Turkey had said earlier that Gur's phrase was misunderstood because of a translation difficulty. A Foreign Ministry announcement on the issue said Greece's decision to expel Gur was ``unjust and without any sound basis and impossible to find reasonable.'' ``The entire responsibility rests with Greece for our decision, which we took reluctantly and with regret,'' it said. ``Racist attacks against the Turkish minority in Komotini will not be forgotten,'' it added. Turkey insists the minority in Western Thrace is Moslem and of Turkish origin. Greece recognizes them only as a religious minority under the 1923 Lausanne treaty ending a four-year Turkish-Greek war. The recent troubles began when a Komotini court sentenced two local Moslem politicians, Ahmet Sadik and Ibrahim Sherif, to 18 months in prison each for using the forbidden Turkish reference in their latest election campaign. Moslems protesting the sentences clashed with Christians in Komotini Monday and scores of shops belonging to Moslems were damaged. Two years ago Greece and Turkey, long-feuding neighbors, started a period of rapprochement when former premiers Turgut Ozal and Andreas Papandreou agreed to try to negotiate their disputes, which center on deciding the future of the Mediterranean island Cyprus. The island is divided into Greek and Turkish sectors. Turkish papers claimed Saturday that the reconciliation had died after the recent developments.

DOC.HEAD: Nation of Islam Leader Tells Crowd: ``Stop the Killing'
DOC.TEXT: Nation of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan exhorted a crowd of more than 16,000 to ``stop the killing'' as he spoke in the wake of a clash between local Black Muslims and authorities that left a man dead. Farrakhan called for creation of a civilian review board to investigate incidents like the Jan. 23 one between sheriff's deputies and Muslims in which Oliver Beasley was shot to death. Sheriff's officials said Beasley, 27, was killed during a struggle for a deputy's gun, but Farrakhan said Beasley was executed. ``I have talked to eyewitnesses. They've told me that Oliver Beasley was lying on the ground, he was bleeding, and the sheriff's deputy looked down on him and blew his brains out,'' Farrakhan said Friday night at the Los Angeles Sports Arena. ``Our subject is stop the killing. Stop the killing,'' said the national Muslim leader from Chicago. ``There's so much disrespect for the single gift of life that it is sad in 1990 that someone has to come along and ask us to stop those who have delighted in killing us.'' Farrakhan, who entered the arena to a standing ovation, called on blacks to stop killing one another in violent street-gang battles. ``Why can we take the trigger and pull it at each other?'' he asked. ``We are killing ourselves. In the name of life, we are worshipers of death.'' Earlier Friday, the Los Angeles County coroner's office released an autopsy report on Beasley saying he died of a gunshot would to the head fired at point-blank range. Sheriff's Lt. Frank Merriman said that supported investigators' contentions that Beasley was killed as he tried to take a deputy's gun away. The incident following a routine traffic stop was the latest in a series of confrontations that has strained relations between the South Side's black communities and law enforcement officials. A 15-foot-high picture of Beasley hung behind the dias during Farrakhan's speech, and Beasley's family sat on stage. In suggesting a police review board, he recommended it include black, white, Hispanic and American Indian representatives. ``If you do this, you'll save the city from eruption,'' Farrakhan said. ``If you do not, people will say enough is enough ... If we reach a point where we can tolerate this abuse no longer, we will rise up against your authority _ and we would rather die than live like dogs under your roof.'' Security was tight. More than 50 police officers were on hand, and those entering the arena had to pass through metal detectors and submit to pat-down searches by Nation of Islam members.

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Cutter That Chased Ship To Mexico Returns Home
LaserPhoto XMB1
DOC.TEXT: A Coast Guard cutter that chased and fired on a Cuban-operated freighter returned to port Saturday, and the skipper said he was too cautious in failing to stop the ship for a drug inspection. The Chincoteague tailed the 250-foot Hermann for 335 miles beginning early Tuesday, when the cutter spotted the ship about 120 miles north of Merida on Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula. The chase ended 26 hours later with the Hermann escaping into Mexican waters near Tampico after being hit about 50 times with a volley of machine-gun fire from the U.S. ship. Cuban dictator Fidel Castro last week called the incident a ``grave provocation,'' but the Chincoteague's captain said he should have done more to stop the freighter. ``I was probably too cautious. I took too long,'' said Lt. Todd Gentile, commander of the 110-foot cutter. Gentile said Coast Guard intelligence had told him the Hermann was carrying more than six tons of cocaine. Cuban officials have said the Hermann, operated by the Guamar Shipping Co. of Cuba but registered in Panama, carried 10 tons of chromium. Mexican officials who searched the freighter at the request of U.S. officials said they found no drugs. Secretary of State James A. Baker III called the U.S. ship's actions a ``legal law enforcement activity.'' Gentile said the intent was not to hurt any of the 12 crew members aboard the Hermann, but to stop the ship for a drug search. No one aboard the Hermann was injured. At the news conference, the Coast Guard released a videotape of the chase. ``I will be firing across the bow of your vessel,'' Gentile is heard saying over a bullhorn. ``It is not my intention to harm you. You must stop your vessel immediately.'' The videotape shows the Chincoteague opening fire on the Hermann, with shots pelting the ship's rudder and propeller area. The videotape also shows crew members using large hoses to shoot water at the Hermann in an attempt to flood its engine. Capt. Larry Hyde, commander of the Chincoteague's Mobile-based group, said an initial review showed the cutter's 16-man crew acted properly. Jack O'Dell, a Coast Guard spokesman in Washington, previously said officials from the State Department, Defense Department and National Security Council held three meetings before giving permission to open fire. Gentile said he was told he could fire on the freighter until it was 15 miles off the coast of Mexico. ``We could have stopped the vessel if we'd wanted to, if we didn't have to worry about the saving of lives,'' Hyde said.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Pentagon Has $30 Billion In Unneeded Equipment
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon has stockpiled at least $30 billion worth of excess, unneeded equipment, spare parts and uniforms _ including a 13,000-year supply of a machine tool, The New York Times reported. The Pentagon has orders for another $1.8 billion in supplies it doesn't need, the Times reported in Sunday editions. The information is contained in a Senate Budget Committee report delivered to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney on Friday, the newspaper said. The report was prepared by staff members of the Democrat-controlled panel, and committee Democrats plan to question Cheney about the stockpile on Monday, the Times said. ``This report has confirmed some of my worst fears,'' said Sen. Jim Sasser, D-Tenn, and chairman of the committee. ``It appears to me that we haven't made much progress from the days of the $400 hammers.'' Pentagon officials disputed some of the report's specifics, the Times said. The officials acknowledged a chronic, serious problem with excess inventory, but said it is already being worked on. The report attributed the problem to inefficient management, including a Pentagon unwillingness to throw away anything, inadequate inventory control and a reluctance to cancel unneeded orders, the Times said. Some examples cited in the study: _ In the past year, the Army was forced to buy 80,000 camouflage helmet covers because officials couldn't locate ones they had already bought _ until after the new order was delivered. _ The Navy has a 13,000-year supply of a machine tool used to make circuits for the F-14 fighter jet. _ The Army has more than $3 million worth of women's long-sleeve dress shirts sitting in a warehouse, while a new one of a heavier material is being designed. _ Defense Logistics Agency warehouses store 150,000 pairs of Korean War-vintage cold-weather pants.

DOC.HEAD: Azerbaijani and Armenian Negotiators Hope For Peaceful Settlement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf after 9th graf `At least...' with background on truces. Pickup 10th graf pvs, `Both parties...'; INSERTS 3 grafs after 16th graf `In a...' to ADD details of communique. Pickup 17th graf pvs, `Both sides...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Armenian and Azerbaijani negotiators emerging from their first talks Saturday expressed hope for a peaceful settlement of their ethnic dispute but remained far apart on thorny territorial claims. The representatives agreed to seek the release of all hostages by March 1 and to establish permanent relations between the Azerbaijani Popular Front and the Armenian National Movement. ``We have made the right first step,'' Sabit Bagirov, one of the two Azerbaijani negotiators, said after the talks in the Latvian capital of Riga. ``There is a certain success. We know each other better,'' said Ashot Manucharian, one of the three Armenian negotiators. The negotiators met for more than nine hours on Friday and early Saturday with mediators from the Baltic Council, which groups leaders of the three people's front movements in the western republics of Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania. The Azerbaijani and Armenian teams later convened for their first face-to-face talks without the Baltic mediators in the Writer's Union building in Riga. The talks continued into Saturday evening, Rihard Stankovs of the Information Center of the Latvian People's Front said by telephone from Riga. He said he did not know what the two sides had discussed. The talks, held without the participation of the Soviet government, were called after about 17,000 Soviet troops were sent to the Azerbaijani capital of Baku to quell ethnic violence that erupted on Jan. 13. At least 214 people have been killed in clashes in the past month and thousands of ethnic Armenians were chased from their homes in Azerbaijan. Ethnic violence over the past two years has created nearly 500,000 refugees in both southern republics. Both sides agreed late last month to truces along the border between Armenia and Nakhichevan _ an Azerbaijani territory bounded by Armenia, Iran and Turkey _ and along a tense battlefront on the Armenia-Azerbaijan border, Soviet media reported. Warring nationalists began pulling back from the borders last week, the reports said. Both parties agreed before the peace talks not to raise the issue of Nagorno-Karabakh, the mostly Armenian district located inside Azerbaijan. Armenia wants to control the enclave; Azerbaijan refuses to surrender it. But the issue dominated the first session of the talks, which had been expected to focus on the presence of Soviet troops in the two republics, refugees and humanitarian issues. Despite efforts of the Baltic mediators to bring the Azerbaijanis and Armenians closer together on territorial issues, the two sides failed to reach any agreement on Nagorno-Karabakh. The Armenians said that they wanted representatives of the Armenian and Azerbaijani communities in Nagorno-Karabakh to join the talks. The Azerbaijanis have refused to negotiate with Armenians from the region. ``It was not easy,'' Latvian Popular Front leader Dainis Ivans, one of the mediators, told a news conference after the first session of talks. ``Sometimes we felt we were in the mountains.'' Baltic mediators are concerned about the precedent set by military intervention in the southern republics and fear more violence in the Caucuses could threaten their own peaceful march toward independence and democracy. In a joint communique issued after the first round of talks, the Azerbaijanis and the Armenians agreed to exert all possible effort to settle the conflict in the Caucuses in a peaceful manner. The Azerbaijanis and the Armenians agreed to use their authority and influence to secure the release of hostages held by each side by March 1 and agreed to establish permanent relations between the Azerbaijani Popular Front and the Armenian National Movement. By Feb. 15, they agreed to try to determine the number of hostages held by each side. Both sides also agreed that the communique would be submitted for consideration to the leadership of their respective movements and would take effect only if approved by those bodies. Life remains difficult in both republics as a result of the conflict. Azerbaijani Communist Party Chief Ayaz Mutalibov appealed to the population to put the tragedy behind and return to work in a speech to collective workers in Baku on Saturday, the Tass news agency reported. ``No matter how deeply we grieve over what has happened, we should work increasingly actively to return life into its normal channel and get involved in work,'' Mutalibov said. The official Soviet news agency Tass said that 152 of 255 factories in Baku were working on Friday. Police and army authorities continued confiscating weapons from the population, especially since six children were seriously wounded when a bottle with a flammable mixture they had found exploded, Tass said. Two men were sentenced to nine and 10 years in a labor camp for resisting arrest when police found them in possession of firearms and explosives. Strikes continued in other major cities in Azerbaijan, the agency reported.

DOC.HEAD: Rushdie's Year in Hiding Damaging
DOC.TEXT: Author Salman Rushdie said nearly a year in hiding has been lonely, with his only company ``people with guns'' _ his protectors. Rushdie went into hiding last Feb. 14 after the late Ayatolluh Khomeini of Iran condemned him to death for his book, ``The Satanic Verses,'' which many Moslems believe blasphemes Islam. In a telephone interview with Newsweek magazine, he said he originally didn't expect his seclusion to last more than a couple of weeks. ``It was only gradually that I began to feel that the damage that had been done was so huge that it was going to take an awful lot of undoing,'' Rushdie said. ``I think one of the problems of unleashing this quantity of hatred is that it's very difficult to put it back in the box.'' The interview is to appear in Newsweek's Feb. 12 issue, available on newsstands Monday. Rushdie, living under the protection of Scotland Yard, said he fled with just the clothes on his back, though he has since received books and personal belongings. After initial weeks glued to a television set, Rushdie returned to writing book reviews but says that for three months he wrote little else except for some poems and a journal. He then began writing a previously planned fable for children. Rushdie said he's lucky to be accustomed to spending long periods alone. His days are spent mostly working. He said he misses things like grocery shopping and going to movies. ``I find myself watching a lot of bad television and videos,'' he said. ``And that's about it, except that instead of being entirely by myself, I've got a number of guests around. People with guns.'' He's learned to ``become chatty on the telephone,'' noting that he can choose whom he calls _ though the chosen often need to be convinced it's really him. Rushdie said his wife, American novelist Marianne Wiggins, who left their hiding place to return to public life in July, ``has actually taken more of the weight of this than any other human being, and in many ways still is.'' Rushdie said he feels a paperback edition of ``The Satanic Verses'' should be issued. ``I see this as an innocent book, wrongly accused and much persecuted,'' he said. He also said he has no intention of trying to change his identity. ``I simply will not accept that this is going to be the rest of my life _ I have to remain an optimist in the sense of believing that solutions are possible.''

DOC.HEAD: Jazz Drummer Mel Lewis Dead at 60
DOC.TEXT: Jazz drummer and orchestra leader Mel Lewis has died of cancer at age 60. Lewis, who died of melanoma Friday at a hospice, in 1965 with trumpeter Thad Jones formed the Thad Jones-Mel Lewis Big Band, which played for 23 years. Lewis, whose real name was Melvin Sokoloff, started his career working with dance bands in his hometown of Buffalo when he was 14. By 1948, he had played with some well-known jazz bands including the Boyd Raeburn Orchestra and the bands of Alvino Ray, Tex Beneke and Ray Anthony. Lewis joined the Stan Kenton Orchestra in 1954. In 1957 he moved to Los Angeles and worked with big band leaders Terry Gibbs and Gerald Wilson, along with pianist Hampton Hawes. Lewis, who played until three weeks before his death, said he loved any kind of music. ``When I play, I'm ecstatic. There isn't a better feeling in the world than swinging or playing a good arrangement,'' he told an interviewer last year. Lewis is survived by his wife, Doris Sokoloff; two daughters, three sisters, a brother and two grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Off-Duty Officer Shot at Graduation Party
DOC.TEXT: A bouncer shot an off-duty police officer outside a bar early Saturday when a graduation party for eight rookie officers ended in a street fight, a police official said. Officer John Hanley, 21, was in serious but stable condition after surgery at Bellevue Hospital, said Chief of Detectives Joseph Borrelli. Hanley was shot in the stomach and the arm; another man involved in the fight was shot once in the hand. The cause of the fight was apparently a woman who left the bar in a limousine, Borrelli said. The brawl began outside the Manhattan bar around 4:20 a.m., with as many as 10 people involved, Borrelli said. Two officers were punched in the face, including one who was knocked unconscious, before Hanley moved in and arrested Mark Tarazhi, 21. Hanley, his gun on Tarazhi, tried to take the man into the bar. But bouncer Eugene DiSilvio, an ex-police officer, pulled a handgun and ordered Hanley to drop his weapon. When Hanley refused and kept walking, DiSilvio fired two shots at the officer, Borrelli said. DiSilvio, who was not charged in the shooting, told police that Hanley never identified himself as an officer, and Borrelli said Hanley's police ID was still in his pocket. Tarazhi fled after the shooting, but was arrested when he arrived at New York University Medical Center for treatment of a gunshot wound to his hand, Borrelli said. Tarazhi was charged with assault. Three of the eight officers at the bar were not involved in the fight, the chief of detectives said.

DOC.HEAD: Hurricane Ofa Knocks out Power, Causing Minor Damage in U.S. Territory
DOC.TEXT: Hurricane Ofa, packing winds up to 104 mph, knocked out electrical power and caused minor flooding and damage Saturday as it passed 230 miles to the west of this U.S. territory, authorities said. There were no reports of injuries, according to Territorial Emergency Management Committee coordinator Maiava Hunkin. Disrupted communications Friday and Saturday caused a blackout of information from Western Samoa, which is about 40 miles west of here. At 7 p.m. EST, Ofa was at 14.6 degrees south latitude and 173.5 degrees west longitude and moving to the south-southeast at 8 mph, the National Weather Service office in Honolulu said, quoting weather officials in Fiji. If the hurricane kept on course, its center would pass to the west of Western Samoa, a country of about 160,000 people. High winds knocked out electrical power to about 90 percent of Tutuila, American Samoa's main island, where most of the territory's 38,000 resident live.

DOC.HEAD: Teens Accused in Dog Death Blame Heavy Metal Music
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: Teen-agers who claimed they were ``driven to kill something'' after listening to hours of heavy metal rock music have been charged in a dog killing, police said. Four male teens were arrested Friday night, said police Sgt. Ric Storbeck. He said the oldest, Timothy Todd Bloemers, 18, of Caledonia, was being held at the Racine County Jail Saturday for lack of $5,000 bail on charges of taking the dog and causing its death. Three 17-year-olds who were released to their parents will have their cases reviewed by juvenile court officials, Storbeck said. He said the incident occurred Jan. 5 after three of the youths listened to various heavy metal groups, then went to a neighborhood yard and stole the dog, a 1{-year-old German shepherd-and-husky mix. ``They said that they were driven to kill something after listening to the heavy metal music,'' Storbeck said. The teens took the animal to a wooded area in this community about 10 miles south of Milwaukee, beat it and one youth knelt on the animal's neck, he said. The three left the animal for dead, later told a friend about the killing, then returned to find the dog still alive, Storbeck said. The officer said they then beat it until it died. Police Investigator Tom Simons said the dog's owner reported the dog missing. Police received information from informers and questioned those believed to have been involved, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Signs of Corrosion in Trans-Alaska Pipeline Worries Officials
DOC.TEXT: Massive corrosion has weakened the 800-mile Trans-Alaska pipeline, prompting federal officials to investigate possible safety violations by the pipeline's operators, the Los Angeles Times reported. Alyeska Pipeline Service Co., the oil industry consortium that operates the pipeline, has begun making repairs to the crude-oil pipeline, the Times reported in Sunday's editions. If left unchecked, corrosion could eventually weaken the half-inch-thick steel wall of the pipe, which is pressurized and could rupture, conceivably spawning an oil spill requiring a costly pipeline shutdown. But Alyeska officials maintain that the corrosion poses no immediate danger to its operations or to the environment. The pipeline carries crude oil from Alaska's North Slope to Valdez, where the crude is transferred to tankers for shipment to refineries. ``We have sufficient early warning in this case,'' said Bill Howitt, Alyeska's manager for engineering. ``We don't have pipeline integrity problems.'' Officials at the federal Office of Pipeline Safety aren't so sure. ``The extent of it we don't know, but it's big enough that it could affect the integrity of the pipeline,'' said Jack Overly, the agency's Western regional division chief. Alyeska may have violated federal safety regulations by failing to adequately maintain portions of its systems designed to retard corrosion, according to agency staff reports. The Office of Pipeline Safety, part of the Department of Transportation, could decide by spring whether to cite Alyeska for violating federal guidelines, the newspaper said. Pipeline inspection reports show that safeguards against corrosion often were incomplete or faulty to begin with, the Times reported. Most of the corrosion was caused by the failure of a protective coating and tape wraps, which many critics earlier had warned were flawed, the newspaper said. Before pipeline operations began in 1977, preparations for laboratory tests of corrosion were set up at the National Bureau of Standards. But those tests were never conducted, the Times said. Alyeska has said that repairs on weakened portions of the line can be completed without disrupting oil flow for more than 2{ days over the next 18 months. Until repairs can be completed, pressure in the line has been reduced by 20 percent in key locations. The pipeline rehabilitation plan could cost operators $1.5 billion over the next five years, and under a complex formula used to determine royalties paid to Alaska, the state could lose $22 million this year alone, said Alaska Attorney General Douglas B. Baily.

DOC.HEAD: Two Small Planes Collide at Airport
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with details of crash, identity of one pilot, quotes; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Two small planes collided Saturday while trying to land at the municipal airport Saturday, killing one pilot and critically injuring the other, authorities said. Both pilots were alone when their planes collided about 300 to 400 feet in the air just before 11 a.m. No injuries were reported on the ground, but one plane nearly missed a house, said Lou Rosskamp, a spokeswoman for the Indian River County sheriff's office. Authorities said the dead man was a licensed pilot and a student at the Florida Institute of Technology's School of Aeronautics, but declined to release his name before notifying his family. Roger Cooper, 62, of Sebastian, a coastal town about 70 miles north of West Palm Beach, was in critical condition in the intensive care unit at Humana Hospital with multiple injuries to his face, arms and legs, said a nursing supervisor. Witnesses told investigator Carrol Smith that Cooper's Grumman Cheetah struck the student's Piper Warrior II from behind as the Piper made its final approach to the airstrip about a mile away, according to National Transportation Safety Board spokesman Jorge Prellezo in Miami. ``We're not faulting anybody at this time,'' Prellezo said. ``It's possible the one that struck the Piper never saw the traffic. ... We're looking at the angles and everything else.'' The student's plane crashed nose-first into the backyard of a house, about 20 feet from a swimming pool, said Annabelle Stevens, the home's owner. ``Thank the Lord it didn't hit the house,'' Mrs. Stevens said as rescue workers foamed down the area to prevent a fire. ``Five more minutes and I would have been outside hanging clothes.'' Cooper, a retired Air Force colonel and a former member of the airport's advisory board, was thrown from his plane when it crashed across the street. Investigators from the Federal Aviation Administration in Miami also headed to the scene Saturday, said FAA spokesman Roger Myers in Atlanta. Myers said the planes were not being guided by air traffic controllers at the time of the crash. The airport has no control tower. ``Apparently both of these aircraft were operating under visual flight rules, which means see and be seen,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Radical Faction: Soviets Won't Direct Flights Of Jewish Emigrants To Israel
DOC.TEXT: The head of a PLO faction on Saturday said a ranking Soviet official has assured the Palestine Liberation Organization that Jews leaving the Soviet Union will no longer be flown directly to Israel. ``The Soviets assured us they would stop all direct flights between Moscow and Tel Aviv,'' said Nayef Hawatmeh, secretary-general of the Marxist-oriented Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine, after PLO discussions with Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Gennady Tarassov. Hawatmeh, who spoke to reporters after a three-day meeting of the PLO's Executive Committee at its headquarters in Tunis, said direct flights are ``a method that leaves no other choice of destination for Soviet Jewish emigration candidates.'' A stop in Vienna, Austria, he said by way of example, would allow immigrants a freedom of choice to pick other countries in which to settle. There was no immediate confirmation from Tarassov, who met in recent days with PLO officials in the Tunisian capital. Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir indicated last month that Israel needed to keep the occupied lands to settle an expected wave of immigrants, which Israel says may total 300,000 in the next three years. Moscow broke diplomatic ties with Israel over its occupation of Arab territory in the 1967 Middle East war. In late January the head of a Soviet diplomatic delegation visiting Israel, Georgi Martirosov, blamed Shamir for the delay in approving an agreement between Aeroflot and Israel's El Al airlines for regularly scheduled direct flights between the nations, including transport of immigrants. Israel in October announced a preliminary agreement; some such flights have occurred since then but were not regularly scheduled and only one carried immigrants. Last Thursday, Azzam al-Ahmed, the Palestinian ambassador to Iraq, said the PLO will send a delegation to Moscow soon to ask that Jewish emigration to Israeli-occupied territories be restricted. The 22-nation Arab League expressed concern at a meeting Friday that Soviet-Jewish immigration to Israel will spill over to augment the ``illegal'' settlements in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Hawatmeh also said the PLO will not use guns in its strategy in the 2-year-old uprising against Israeli authority in the occupied lands. He said protesters will continue to use rocks and firebombs. The organization ``remains committed to its engagement not to use firearms in the occupied Gaza Strip or the West Bank,'' Hawatmeh said. ``Our arm is the intefadeh (uprising) of the Palestinian people who are following it in a peaceful way, throwing stones and Molotov cocktails,'' he said. Hawatmeh said the Executive Committee had decided to call a meeting of the Central Council soon to examine the development of the Mideast situation since the last Central Council meeting in October in Baghdad, Iraq. He did not disclose a date or a site for the meeting. The 150-member Central Council is the representative body between the Executive Committee and the Palestine National Council, the PLO's parliament-in-exile.

DOC.HEAD: Cap Cities' Newswriters Union Accepts Tentative Pact
DOC.TEXT: East coast radio and television newswriters will get two 5 percent pay increases under a three-year contract tentatively agreed to Friday by the Writers Guild of America, East and Capital Cities-ABC. ``We are very pleased with this contract,'' said Jeffrey Ruthizer, Cap Cities vice president for labor relations. ``The union was sensitive to the company's need for increased flexibility and we were able to respond to its concerns with wage increases and protections important to them.'' The union's 160 writers, editors, desk assistants, researchers, production assistants, promotion writers and graphic artists are employed at ABC's local and network stations in Washington and New York. The old three-year contract expired at midnight. Negotiators worked through the night and the union accepted Capital Cities' final proposal about 7 a.m.. ``We believe that the agreement provides for a fair and equitable contract for our members,'' said Mona Mangan, chief negotiator for the guild. In 1987, the guild was involved in a bitter seven-week strike. The first 5 percent increase is immediate and the second comes in 18 months. Union spokesman Martin Waldman said the increases would hike the average newswriters' salary from $863 to $949. Waldman said the guild also kept intact some union-covered duties ABC tried to eliminate at ``Good Morning America'' and ``News One,'' Capital Cities' television news service for affiliates. The proposal also includes new fees for radio newswriters at the network level who take on additional technical jobs and more vacation time for employees with more than 15 years experience. Julie Hoover, a spokeswoman for Cap Cities-ABC, said the flexibility Ruthizer spoke of in the new contract ``allows management and others outside the bargaining unit to perform duties previously performed by people in the bargaining unit.'' Those jobs include writing, said Hoover. Union members vote on the proposed pact on Monday. On Tuesday, the guild is to begin negotiations for its members at CBS television and radio. Their contract, which covers employees at the network and local levels, expires March 1.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Protest Nicaragua Purchase
DOC.TEXT: American funds bought made-in-India ``general purpose utility vehicles'' for the opposition political party in Nicaragua, according to statements Friday by angry lawmakers from auto industry districts. ``The workers of our country whose taxes finance this assistance surely deserve more consideration,'' said Reps. Marcy Kaptur, D-Ohio, and Jim Jontz, D-Ind., in a letter of protest to the organizations that handled part of the money appropriated for helping Nicaragua hold fair elections. Kaptur represents Toledo, where Chrysler Corp. makes Jeeps, and Jontz represents Kokomo, Ind., where Chrysler makes transmissions. The entire aid package was $9 million. Of that, $1.8 million went to the United Nicaraguan Opposition opposing Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega. About $743,000 was spent on cars, trucks and four-wheel-drive vehicles, said Ken Wollack, executive vice president of the National Democratic Institute for International Affairs. A total of 93 vehicles was purchased, including 50 Indian-made utility vehicles. Wollack said his organization, which is affiliated with the Democratic Party, would have preferred to buy American-made Jeeps for Nicaragua's opposition, but with the election scheduled for Feb. 25 and grant agreements uncertain until last December, there was no time to move U.S.-exported vehicles through all the required clearances. The vehicles purchased were already in Nicaragua, waiting to clear customs, Wollack said. ``Because of the (U.S. trade) embargo there were no American vehicles to be bought in Nicaragua,'' he said. ``The only way to purchase the equipment and get it to Nicaragua in time ... was to buy equipment already in Nicaragua.'' Further complicating the politics of the utility vehicle purchase, the U.S. trade representative has cited India for unfair trading practices. Jontz said India requires 98 percent local content for autos to qualify as Indian-made. Imported cars bear a 140 percent tariff and imported trucks are taxed at 190 percent. ``It is ironic under these circumstances that American tax dollars are being used to purchase vehicles from India,'' said the protest letter. The lawmakers, both of whom voted against the $9 million Nicaraguan aid package, wrote, ``Regardless of how one feels about the aid to begin with, certainly this particular use of funds ... is most objectionable.''

DOC.HEAD: Southeast Asians Decry Torture, Killings in Laos, Seek U.S. Help
DOC.TEXT: More than 1,000 Southeast Asians marched in a downtown park Friday to protest government attacks on villages opposed to communist domination in Laos and pressure the United States to intervene. Bundled in heavy coats and scarves, Hmong originally from the northern foothills of Laos walked through 3 inches of fresh snow at Ziedler Park chanting ``U.S., we need your help. Laos needs democracy.'' They said many Hmong in Laos have been killed by bombs and chemical weapons in assaults launched recently by communist forces in Vietnam and Laos. ``Their animals have been killed. Their food has been destroyed. They are without shelter. They have no shovels to bury those that are killed and no medicine to treat those that are wounded,'' demonstrator Nao Shoua Xiong said. He said Hmong are the target of a brutal offensive which began after Free Lao, a resistance movement, declared a provisional government Dec. 5. Free Lao is dedicated to freeing Laos from Vietnamese domination and establishing a democracy in the country, Xiong said. Xiong, 42, like many Hmong, was recruited to help the U.S. military during the Vietnam war. He served as an interpreter, then fled the country 15 years ago, first on foot through Thailand. ``The Vietnamese don't like us. They want to exterminate all the people who fought against them in Vietnam. The Lao government does what the Vietnamese government tells them. The Vietnamese should withdraw from Laos completely and let the Laotians determine their future,'' he said. More than 16,000 Hmong who fled Laos to escape communist persecution now reside in Wisconsin, officials said. An additional 14,000 live in neighboring Minnesota and 50,000 in California. Less than a quarter of Laos' 3.8 million people are Hmong. Xiong said hundreds of Hmong villagers have been killed and many hundreds more poisoned and maimed in the northern and central provinces of Laos. The protesters called for international condemnation of the attacks and urged the United States to withhold funds from the Laotian government designated for anti-drug work and searches for U.S. soldiers missing in action. ``If the U.S. government doesn't support us, we have no where else to turn,'' said 18-year-old Chee Vang Moua, from Milwaukee. ``We have heard that a lot of people have died. I don't think they should send the drug money until this is resolved,'' said Mai Yong Vang, 22, a Milwaukee nurse. The demonstration was one of several planned for Friday and Saturday in many U.S. cities, including one outside the Laotian Embassy in Washington. According to a report issued Wednesday by the Republican Task Force on Terrorism and Unconventional Warfare, fighting in Laos during January was aimed at destroying the civilian population in the mountainous northern region. The report said the bombings by the Vietnamese were endorsed by the Laotian government and that the results of some attacks pointed to the use of chemical weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Say Bush's Budget Would Cut Drug Fight On Border
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's proposed budget could gut efforts to fight illegal drug trafficking along the U.S.-Mexico border, contrary to adminstration promises to step up law enforcement on the front lines, area Democrats contended Friday. The Southwest border's four Democratic senators said Bush's budget seeks personnel reductions in three federal law enforcement agencies that could seriously affect their operations along the border. Bush released his budget Monday, four days after declaring the Southwest border, Houston, Los Angeles, Miami and New York City were ``high intensity drug trafficking areas'' eligible for hundreds of additional law enforcement agents and millions of dollars in additional federal aid. But Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, said the benefit of being targeted for more help has been undercut by the president's budget, which seeks reductions for the Immigration and Naturalization Service, the Customs Service, and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. According to Bentsen and fellow Sens. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., and Jeff Bingaman, D-N.M., a total of 636 positions would be cut from Customs, 423 from the INS, and 185 from the ATF, the lead agency on the border for gang enforcement and firearms investigations. The senators, in a letter Friday to William J. Bennett, director of the office of national drug control policy, ask his help in restoring these law enforcement positions to federal agencies ``which are this nation's front line forces in the war on drugs. ``We believe cuts of this magnitude will have a serious adverse impact on each of these agencies' operations in the Southwest,'' the senators said. The president's new drug control strategy, however, recommends an additional 174 Border Patrol agents and 175 Customs inspectors for the Southwest border, which the adminstration described as the principal corridor for moving drugs, especially marijuana, cocaine and heroin, into the country.

DOC.HEAD: Cattle and Cow Inventory Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial circuits
DOC.TEXT: The Jan. 1 inventory of cattle and calves on the nation's farms and ranches edged up from a year ago to 99.3 million, but was still below the 99.6 million of 1988, the Agriculture Department said Friday. ``This reversed the recent downward trend in cattle inventories and shows the first Jan. 1 yearly increase since 1982,'' said the National Agricultural Statistics Service. The 1989 inventory was 99.2 million head, a 28-year low. Officials said the 1990 calf crop is expected to be 43.9 million head, up fractionally from 43.7 million last year and up 1 percent from 1988. ``This was the second consecutive increase in all cows and heifers that have calved following six consecutive years of decline,'' the statistics service said. The breakdown: _Beef cows, 33.7 million, up 1 percent from Jan. 1, 1989 and 2 percent above Jan. 1, 1988. _Milk cows, 10.1 million, down 1 percent from last year and 2 percent below two years ago. _All heifers, 500 pounds and over, 17.9 million, up 3 percent from last year and up 4 percent from two years ago. _Beef replacement heifers, 5.47 million, down slightly from last year but up 4 percent from two years ago. _Milk replacement heifers, 4.29 million, up 2 percent from last year and up 4 percent from two years ago. _Other heifers, 8.09 million, up 5 percent from a year ago and up 3 percent from two years ago. _Steers weighing 500 pounds and over, 16.1 million, up 2 percent from both of the last two years. _Bulls weighing 500 pounds and over, 2.21 million, down fractionally from last year but up 2 percent from two years ago. _Calves under 500 pounds, 19.3 million, down fractionally 4 percent from last year and down 8 percent from two years ago. _ All cattle and calves on feed for slaughter, 11.6 million, up 2 percent from last year, but down 2 percent from two years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Costly Aircraft Bomb-Sniffing Devices Aren't Good Enough, Panelists Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with comments from detector developer, airport operators, inserting 3 grafs after 11th graf, The TNA, and adding 2 grafs at end
DOC.TEXT: A new device designed to detect plastic explosives in airplane luggage is deficient and probably could not have discovered the bomb which destroyed Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, members of a presidential terrorism commission said Friday. Panelists at a hearing of the Presidential Commission on Terrorism Aviation Security and Terrorism sharply questioned plans by the Federal Aviation Administration to require the airline industry to buy hundreds of the bomb detecting devices, complaining that they have not been adequately tested. But Monte Belger, the FAA's associate administrator for aviation standards, said he believes the sophisticated detection device is the best of its kind in the world, has been adequately tested and should be deployed. In a three-hour hearing, the commission also was told that the device _ which employs a technique called thermal neutron analysis, or TNA _ will cost far more than original estimates of between $700,000 to $1 million each. Belger said the first five TNA machines actually will cost a total $15 million or about $2.5 million each because of the rush nature of the order. A TNA system _ an 18-foot high, 20,000-ton machine _ is at work inspecting baggage at Kennedy International Airport in New York. A second system was installed at Miami International Airport last week and is being calibrated. A third TNA machine is to be installed at Gatwick Airport near London next month, and site planning is under way to place one at Washington Dulles International Airport. ``I think there is a lot of flim flam going on,'' said Sen. Alphonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., a commission member. ``The TNA looks good but it does not do what it is supposed to do. Congress has been sold a bill of goods. ... ``There is a reduced ability to detect plastic explosives at the levels believed to have been used at Lockerbie,'' the senator said. Investigators believe the Lockerbie crash on Dec. 21, 1988, was caused by less than a pound of plastic explosives secreted inside a portable tape player. The crash killed 259 people aboard the Boeing 747 aircraft and 11 people on the ground. Science magazine, which first reported in August that the TNA machines would not be able to detect a Lockerbie-sized bomb, said the devices are being set at a sensitivity that will detect about 2.5 pounds of explosives. The TNA machines use neutrons _ a type of subatomic particle _ to probe luggage for the presence of nitrogen, a major component of explosives. A problem with the TNA system is that some types of fabric, leather and such things as plastic ski boots can have nitrogen densities as high as explosives. Hadi Bozorgmanesh, vice president of Science Applications International Corp., also defended the device his company developed and said it has established a high success rate of detecting all sizes and designs of bombs. He said an accusation that the TNA machine cannot detect a bomb as small as two pounds is ``absolutely false.'' ``We would like to get closer to 100 percent and to detect smaller amounts of explosives with better accuracy,'' he said and added: ``I totally agree that the system is not perfect, but it's far better than anything else that can be demonstrated.'' He said the company is working to make the device ``smaller, faster, cheaper and more accurate.'' D'Amato said calibrating the TNA device to detect a Lockerbie-sized bomb would set off so many false alarms ``that you would have a system which is inoperative.'' Belger said: ``I am convinced the TNA machine has been tested sufficiently for the U.S. government to want to deploy it. It is not perfect and we know it.'' A vigorous drive is under way to identify and develop other technologies which will more efficiently detect bombs in luggage, and breakthroughs are expected soon, Belger said. In the meantime, he said the safety of the traveling public demands that the TNA machines be widely deployed. Commission member Thomas C. Richards, a retired Air Force general, told Belger: ``It is your responsibility to prove the technology before you go to industry and tell them to buy a pig in a poke.'' Belger replied: ``It would be a mistake not to continue to deploy it. It is wrong to wait for the perfect machine.'' Representatives of airport operators also expressed objections to the TNA device. Siegbert B. Poritsky, vice president of the Airport Operators Council International said the FAA's requirement that explosive detection systems be installed at major airports is causing `'more confusion than security.'' ``As a result the only approved equipment to date, TNA, is too slow and large to accommodate in a manner which will do the most good, too heavy for most airport terminal floors, and has a substantial false alarm rate which causes long delays in baggage screening and causes personnel to be complacent in responding to alarms,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Commercial Jet Lands Safely After Flames Seen on Engine
DOC.TEXT: Flames shooting from an engine forced a Northwest Airlines DC-10 to return to Los Angeles Airport early Friday, but the 99 passengers and nine-member crew were uninjured. Northwest spokesman Bob Gibbons said the flames in the left engine were caused by a compressor stall, a problem that can occur when the even flow of air to the engine turbine blades is interrupted, causing too much jet fuel to accumulate. A DC-10 has three engines, but can safely land on two, said Rich Tornquist, Federal Aviation Administration regional duty officer. Northwest spokesman Kevin Whalen said Flight 84 arrived in Los Angeles from Honolulu. Mechanics examined the engine and repaired the problem, he said. The Minneapolis-bound passengers went to a nearby hotel to rest after the landing at 2:20 a.m. and then boarded a later flight, Gibbons said.

DOC.HEAD: Airliner with Hydraulic Problems Lands Safely in Chicago
DOC.TEXT: An American Airlines 727-200 jet with 63 people aboard landed safely Friday at O'Hare International Airport after reporting hydraulic problems, officials said. No injuries were reported. The pilot of Flight 1125, en route to Chicago from Omaha, Neb., reported the plane had problems with its main hydraulic system, which controls steering, said Tom Stack, a spokesman for American Airlines. The pilot switched to a back-up system, he said. The plane was carrying 56 passengers and seven crew members. The pilot considered landing in Minneapolis because of the threat of bad weather at O'Hare, but decided to to try the Chicago landing, Stack said. The plane landed safely at O'Hare at 5:10 p.m. CST as emergency crews stood by, said Mort Edelstein, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration in Chicago. The plane was then towed to the terminal where the passengers disembarked without incident, Edelstein said.

DOC.HEAD: Hungarians Report Progress After First Round Of Withdrawal Talks
DOC.TEXT: Hungary said the Soviet Union agreed to continue work on a timetable for removing all 50,000 Soviet troops from the country during an initial two-day session that ended Friday. ``In the course of the talks, the sides set forth their position and agreed that the withdrawal of Soviet troops will be carried out on the basis of an inter-governmental agreement to be concluded within the shortest possible time,'' the Foreign Ministry said in a communique. The communique, carried by the official MTI news agency, said no date was set for a second round of talks, but that two sides had agreed to continue efforts ``at working out the timetable for the pullout.'' There was no immediate Soviet comment. The talks were the second of their kind in Eastern Europe since a wave of democratization last year started loosening the Soviet grip over its Warsaw Pact allies. The first, held in Prague on withdrawing troops from Czechoslovakia, ended inconclusively early this month. A second round is set for next week. The head of the Hungarian delegation and secretary of state in the Foreign Ministry, Ferenc Somogyi, said Thursday night that his country is seeking a withdrawal by the end of the year or early 1991. The Hungarian communique said the talks with the Soviet delegation, led by Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Ivan Aboimov, were held in an ``objective, constructive atmosphere.'' The estimated 50,000 Soviet troops in Hungary and 70,000 in Czechoslovakia are stationed on the basis of ``temporary'' agreements the Kremlin reached with the two countries after quashing a revolt against Stalinism in 1956 in Hungary and reforms in Czechoslovakia in 1968. The new leaderships of the East bloc have echoed calls for troop withdrawals. In Poland, Solidarity leader Lech Walesa made the appeal to the Soviet ambassador, although the non-communist-led government has not started negotiations. Moscow began reducing its troop presence in Hungary last April as part of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's program of cutting 50,000 soldiers from the Red Army in Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Archbishop of Canterbury Starts First Visit to Pakistan
DOC.TEXT: The spiritual leader of Anglicans worldwide arrived Friday on his first visit to this predominantly Moslem country to promote understanding and goodwill. The Archbishop of Canterbury Robert Runcie bowed low to receive almost a dozen traditional heart-shaped garlands during a red-carpet welcoming ceremony at Islamabad International Airport. ``It's the first time I've nearly been strangled by kindness,'' Runcie said during a brief arrival address to representatives of Pakistan's minority Christian community. Runcie's host, the Church of Pakistan headed by Bishop Alexander Malik, is an interdenominational church representing 700,000 Anglicans, Lutherans, Presbyterians and Methodists. There are about 3 million Christians among Pakistan 107 million people. Runcie said he wanted his visit to emphasize the need for dialogue between varying religions. ``We should be talking to each other, building bonds of friendship together, working together for human betterment,'' he said. Runcie is to meet Saturday with Pakistan President Ghulam Ishaq Khan. The archbishop will also spend a day in Pakistan's rugged Northwest Frontier Province bordering war-weary Afghanistan. He will later tour the ancient Punjab capital of Lahore and the ethnically troubled port of Karachi. Runcie visits Bangladesh after Pakistan.

DOC.HEAD: Banana Farmers Protest Gov't Takeover of Association
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of banana farmers marched on this Caribbean capital Friday to protest declining banana prices and the government's recent takeover of their association. There were no arrests in the demonstration led by banana farmer Rupert Gajadhar and opposition Labor Party leader Julian Hunte, but there were several scuffles with armed police when protesters broke through a police cordon. Prime Minister John Compton fired the board of directors of the Banana Growers Association in October and accused Gajadhar, the ex-chairman, of engaging in ``confrontation politics.'' A government-appointed interim board assumed control. ``We are protesting against the withdrawal of our democratic right to elect our own people to represent us and run our business,'' Gajadhar told reporters. ``We are protesting against the low prices that we have got (for bananas) for years.'' Banana exports, mostly to Britain, are the main earner of hard currency for this island-nation of 140,000 people.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Checking for Tampering By Suspended State Official
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 4th graf pvs, ``From now...accompany her,' to UPDATE with inspectors confiscating documents, typewriter; DELETES first reference to Moore in 10th graf pvs. Pick up 11th graf: `Resha unsuccessfully...
DOC.TEXT: Authorities on Friday began checking whether the state's suspended revenue director altered or destroyed any documents related to an investigation against her. Florida Department of Law Enforcement inspectors interviewed Department of Revenue employees Friday about a scrap of paper found on the desk of director Katie Tucker and visits she made to her office, two at night. The night visits prompted Brian Ballard, director of operations for Gov. Bob Martinez, to have the locks changed on department doors Thursday. ``From now on, whenever she goes over there she's going to have an escort,'' Ballard said. Either officials from a Cabinet agency or the Florida Department of Law Enforcement will accompany her. Inspectors confiscated 10 to 20 documents and a typewriter from Tucker's office, said Jere Moore, spokesman for the Department of Revenue. ``They took the files they thought were appropriate for their inquiry,'' Moore said. The latest investigation came after Sam Alexander, the assistant director of the department, was shown a scrap of paper bearing his initials that had apparently been cut up. Alexander said Friday that another employee found the scrap on Ms. Tucker's desk and brought it to him. Ms. Tucker is serving a 10-day suspension with pay ordered by Martinez and the Cabinet because of a 1988 tax investigation of Tallahassee businesman Donald G. Resha, a political rival of Ms. Tucker's husband. Martinez has called for her resignation from the appointed position. There was no answer at Ms. Tucker's home on Friday, but when contacted by the St. Petersburg Times on Thursday, she said, ``This is crazy.'' It is a third-degree felony to alter public documents under Florida law. Ms. Tucker has visited the office several times to look through documents to back up her contention that the tax probe was part of a sweep of video stores like those owned by Resha, said Moore, the Revenue Department spokesman. Resha unsuccessully ran against her husband, Daniel Miller, for state AFL-CIO presidency in 1985. Alexander took the paper to Cabinet officials Thursday. He said he was concerned the paper could be used to superimpose his name on possibly forged documents using a copy machine. ``That's one of the things the FDLE is looking into, whether there were documents destroyed or altered,'' said Alexander, who was interviewed by investigators Thursday. He said Ms. Tucker told aides Thursday she had found a document expressing her concern that the probe was centered on Resha. Such a document would back her claims that she never intended Resha to be the sole target. Previous FDLE reports have found nothing to indicate such a sweep was conducted, saying Resha alone was targeted for the tax investigation on Ms. Tucker's orders. She has said she will decide by Monday whether to step down or face the governor and Cabinet at its meeting Tuesday. She also faces a $4 million defamation lawsuit filed Thursday by Resha in Leon Circuit Court.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Demands Vote of Confidence from Likud Bloc
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said Friday he will demand a vote of confidence from his right-wing Likud bloc because of a barrage of criticism by hawkish party rivals who oppose his peace moves. The Likud power struggle, which has halted Middle East peace efforts, has increased in intensity daily, with Shamir and his allies trading barbs and trying to outmaneuver each other before next week's Central Committee party meeting. ``For too long I have been insulted by slanderous and attacking voices from within my own movement,'' Shamir said on Israel television. ``This is not a normal phenomenon.'' ``Because of this, I believe that the central committee must adopt a decision on confidence in the prime minister and the head of the movement.'' The showdown will take place next week when Shamir hopes to get a single vote of confidence from the 3,200 committee members for his leadership and for his plan calling for elections in the occupied territories as a first step toward peace. The party rebels, led by Central Committee Chairman and Trade Minister Ariel Sharon, demand that Likud members instead vote on separate motions on the plan's details, such as barring Palestinians from Arab east Jerusalem from voting in the elections. Shamir aides said they fear Sharon's voting procedure would place unnecessary constraints on Shamir in his peace negotiations with the United States and Egypt that are expected to lead to the elections. ``Shamir wants a vote of confidence. He wants to prove that the majority stands behind him and wants to be able to maneuver freely in the diplomatic arena,'' said the Likud official, speaking on condition of anonymity. Shamir has threatened to resign if he does not win the support of the Central Committee. ``If the central committee does not accept my ways and does not accept my recommendations and does not give me its full faith, I will have to draw conclusions,'' Shamir said. Sharon aides could not be reached for comment Friday, but the trade minister and his allies have daily heaped insults on the prime minister. He has been called ``a rotten apple,'' ``a complete failure'' and ``a con-man.'' In one instance, Sharon accused Foreign Minister Moshe Arens, a Shamir ally, of avoiding battle during Israel's 1948 War of Independence. Arens denied the allegations. When asked to respond to Sharon's insults in Friday's television interview Shamir said: ``He talks too much.'' The inner-party battle has been waged for two weeks, halting any movement in the peace process because Washington has become convinced there is no point in pushing ahead until Shamir has re-established his leadership. The confrontation further escalated Thursday when Shamir sent out invitations for the Feb. 7 Central Committee meeting that contradict the agenda previously set by Sharon. Shamir's agenda calls for a speech outlining the peace plan and a yes-or-no vote, while Sharon wants votes on separate motions. Shamir and his aides accused Sharon of using the platform of the Central Committee meeting to wage a struggle for succession to the party leadership. ``There are people who because of personal problems are driving the whole country crazy, and are blocking all achievements. We have to stop this,'' Israel radio quoted Shamir as saying. In fact, there are few ideological difference between the hard-line Shamir and his rivals, who include Housing Minister David Levy and Economics Minister Yitzhak Modai. For example, all are opposed to the participation of east Jerusalem Arabs and Palestinian deportees in a Palestinian delegation that would hold preliminary peace talks with Israel in Cairo. The two proposals are part of a compromise package that has been accepted by the PLO, Egypt, the United States and Israel's left-of-center Labor Party that governs in coalition with Likud.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor Says Interrogation Imperils Honecker's Life
With AM-East Germany
DOC.TEXT: Erich Honecker's doctor and lawyer both contended Friday that criminal interrogation of the ousted East German Communist leader was endangering his life. The once-powerful 77-year-old Honecker was judged this week to be too ill to withstand imprisonment and was freed from an East Berlin jail after about 36 hours detention. Honecker is to be tried next month on a charge of high treason, national prosecutor Hans-Juergen Joseph has announced. In a statement carried by the official ADN news agency, attorney Wolfgang Vogel and Dr. Friedrich Wolff protested the interrogation of their client. Vogel said criminal investigators questioned Honecker Friday morning in preparation for the trial against him. ``This unannounced investigation session and the previous imprisonment contrary to doctors' advice has led to a worsening of his health condition, in the view of Dr. Peter Althaus,'' ADN quoted Vogel and Wolff as saying in their written statement. Althaus was the surgeon who operated on Honecker Jan. 8 to remove a malignant kidney tumor. Vogel and Wolff said investigators were aware of the influence their questioning was having on Honecker. ``Dr. Peter Althaus believes that police interrogation at this time could endanger the patient's life,'' they stated. Lutheran Church officials have taken in Honecker and his wife Margot, as the Honeckers were stripped of their former residences and are in effect homeless. Honecker was released from East Berlin's Charite hospital on Monday and was immediately arrested. He was released Tuesday night after Joseph failed to obtain a detention warrant. The East Berlin court heeded doctors' advice that Honecker was in no condition to be imprisoned.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Considering Membership in U.N. Agricultural Body
By FRANCES D'EMILIO
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet delegation is seeking to determine if joining the U.N. Food and Agricultural Organization could benefit the Soviet Union's economic reforms, especially in farming. Eight Soviets arrived in Rome on Thursday for meetings with FAO officials through next week. The Rome-based FAO is attractive because it deals ``not just (with) resolutions ... but with concrete economic activity,'' delegation leader Konstantin P. Ovchinnikov told reporters Friday. ``Our goal is to raise the economic sufficiency of our country.'' Ovchinnikov, deputy director of the Foreign Ministry's department of international economic organizations, said membership in FAO would mean access to the agency's technical assistance as well as scientific know-how.. Ovchinnikov, an economist, said the FAO could profit from Soviet expertise and the Soviets could benefit from membership in the agency. He said FAO's statistical and other scientific methods could prove valuable in reforming the Soviet economy. Other benefits could come in biotechnology, lifestock and botany, he said. Ovchinnikov said any actual FAO aid projects in the Soviet Union would be ``very modest.'' Moscow is ``not seeking to divert financial resources from FAO,'' he said. As a founder of FAO in 1945, the Soviet Union does not have to seek formal approval of member status. FAO Director-General Edouard Saouma has welcomed the prospect of Soviet membership. The Soviet Union currently has observer status. Ovchinnikov said checking into possible FAO membership comes in the context of Soviet interest in other international bodies, such as the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development and GATT, the tariffs organization.

DOC.HEAD: Swiss Company Agrees to Buy 60 Percent of Biotech Firm
DOC.TEXT: A Swiss company agreed Friday to buy 60 percent of Genentech Inc., one of this country's leading biotechnology companies. Roche Holding Ltd., a large Swiss pharmaceutical company, said it had agreed to invest $492 million in Genentech and buy half its outstanding stock for $36 a share, 65 percent higher than Thursday's closing stock price. Other features of the transaction, which has a total value of $2.1 billion, would give Roche 60 percent of Genentech's stock. The Swiss company would have the option to buy the rest of Genentech's stock, for higher prices, over the next five years. The deal was approved by the Genentech board Friday and will be submitted to the shareholders for approval in April, the companies said. Genentech, founded in the mid-1970s as one of the first commercial ventures to make use new biological technology, gets most of its revenue from two products: A genetically engineered heart drug called Activase and a human growth hormon sold as Protrofin. Analysts suggested Roche was seeking a bigger foothold in the U.S. market, and that the infusion of cash would enable Genentech to expand its efforts. Jacqueline Siegel, an analyst with the high-technology consulting company Hambrecht & Quist in San Francisco, said Roche ``clearly bought the most aggressive product development company in the industry.'' Denise Gilbert, an analyst who follows the company for Montgomery Securities in San Francisco, said Genentech likely would get the money and market influence to begin trying to buy the rights to develop or market drugs developed by other biotechnology companies. ``Genentech now is in a very good market position and many of the other biotech companies _ including Roche itself _ which found they had niches to themselves may find Genentech as a competitor,'' Gilbert said. Fritz Gerber, chairman and chief executive officer of Roche, released a statement saying, ``Roche's $2.1 billion total investment will be best served if Genentech continues to operate in the manner that led to its impressive success in such a short time.'' The deal would require all the company's common shareholders to sell half their stock for $36 a share. The remaining shares would be converted to a new class of redeemable common stock, and Roche would have the option to buy all that stock until June 1995. Two weeks ago, Genentech reported a turnaround in fourth-quarter earnings, posting a $15 million profit after losing the same amount in the fourth quarter of 1988. For all of 1989, Genentech posted a profit of $44 million. The company, based in South San Francisco, said fourth-quarter sales of Activase jumped 63 percent. Roche, based in Basle, Switzerland, has worldwide sales of $6.5 billion, and facilities in 52 countries.

DOC.HEAD: Cult Members Describe Shootings in Videotapes
DOC.TEXT: A family found buried under a barn ate with the man charged with their murders on the night of the slayings and had no idea they were to be shot, a newspaper reported Friday. Citing videotaped statements two members of a religious splinter group gave federal authorities, The (Cleveland) Plain Dealer said Dennis Avery, his wife, Cheryl, and their three daughters were brought one by one to a nearby barn after dinner April 17 at the farmhouse of Jeffrey Lundgren, the group's leader. According to the statements, each of the Averys was gagged, tied and fatally shot. Their bodies were covered with lime, stone, and trash, and buried in a mass grave, the newspaper said. Lundgren, a defrocked lay minister of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, is charged with five counts of aggravated murder and five counts of kidnapping. Twelve other cult members also face charges, including conspiracy and aggravated murder. The bodies of Avery, 49; his 42-year-old wife; and their daughters Trina, 15; Rebecca, 13; and Karen, 7, were found on Jan. 3 and 4. Shortly after the discovery, Lake County Prosecutor Steven C. LaTourette said the slayings may have been designed to spiritually cleanse the group's members before a trip to the wilderness. County Common Pleas Judge Martin Parks has issued a gag order in the case. The newspaper said the videotaped statements were shown to defense lawyers Wednesday. Lawyers for the various defendants either declined to comment or could not be reached for comment. There was no answer Friday at the office of Lundgren's attorney, R. Paul LaPlante. In the taped statements, Lundgren's wife, Alice; Susan Luff; Tonya J. Patrick and her husband, Dennis S. Patrick, said they feared for their lives and dared not defy Lundgren, the newspaper reported. They said they lied to family and friends about their lives with Lundgren, whom they called ``prophet'' and ``father.'' The four denied participating in the slayings and said learned about them later. The Plain Dealer said group members Ronald B. Luff and Richard E. Brand described the killings in statements to officers of the U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms in Kansas City, Mo. The day after the shootings occurred, FBI agents and local authorities who had been monitoring the cult went to the Kirtland farm, 30 miles east of Cleveland, to question the members, who said they were not being held against their will. The cult members left the area on April 18 and lived at a camp in West Virginia before heading to Missouri and scattering.

DOC.HEAD: GE, Former Employees Guilty Of Defrauding Government
DOC.TEXT: General Electric Co. and two employees were convicted Friday on several charges of bilking the government of $10 million for a battlefield computer system. A U.S. District Court jury returned the verdict against GE, James Badolato and Gerald A. Leo, both former employees of Management and Technical Services Co., a GE subsidiary. GE faces a fine of about $50 million, plus court costs, Assistant U.S. Attorney David Howard told reporters after the verdict. If GE had been convicted on all charges, it would have faced up to $71.9 million in fines. The defendants were found innocent on several charges in the 321-count indictment, which was announced in November 1988. The trial began last Nov. 14. GE and Leo were found guilty of four counts of mail fraud while Badolato was convicted on one count of obstructing justice and one count of trying to cover up the fraud scheme. Leo also was convicted of the cover-up. GE was convicted of 282 counts of making false claims and acquitted of 30 others. The company and Leo were acquitted on one fraud count and Badolato was acquitted of all five counts of mail fraud. Leo and Badolato were acquitted of one count each of racketeering. Leo could be sentenced to up to 25 years in prison and fined $1 million, while Badolato could be imprisoned 10 years and fined $500,000. The government also has filed a civil lawsuit seeking $23 million in overcharges and damages in the $234 million project from 1983 to 1986. GE could be suspended from Pentagon contracts because of the verdict, said Assistant U.S. Attorney Nicholas Harbist. That decision rests with the Secretary of the Army, he said. The subsidiary, Management and Technical Services, was suspended from government contracts after the indictment, Harbist said. Action on GE was withheld, pending resolution of the case, he said. GE receives approximately $6 billion annually for defense contracts ranging from jet engines and electronic warfare equipment to highly classified strategic work. This was GE's second defense-related fraud case in four years. In May 1985, the company pleaded guilty to illegally claiming $800,000 in cost overruns on Minuteman intercontinental ballistic missiles and paid a $1.04 million fine. Under the $250 million no-bid contract in the current case, the King of Prussia-based Management and Technical Services subsidiary was to provide 233 mobile computer units in five production years beginning in 1984. The government alleged that GE padded its costs and failed to notify the Pentagon of savings negotiated with subcontractors. Badolato, 43, of Springfield, and Leo, 52, of King of Prussia, are now working in other GE departments. The company pleaded innocent, although GE acknowledged an internal investigation uncovered discrepancies totaling $3.69 million, which the company refunded in 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Disney World Raises Prices At Its Three Theme Parks
DOC.TEXT: Walt Disney World has raised the admission price almost 5 percent for its three theme parks to help pay for several new attractions, the company announced Friday. The new prices take effect Feb. 11. Disney World last raised its prices at May 1, 1989. Customers will have to pay $100 ($80 per child) for a four-day pass to all parks and $117 ($95 per child) for five days. A single-day admission will cost $31 ($25 per child). The current price is $29 ($23 per child) for a single day, $97 ($77 per child) for a four-day pass and $112 ($90 per child) for five days. Disney, in announcing the price increases, noted recent additions to their theme parks. The company recently opened ``Star Tours'' and the ``Indiana Jones Stunt Spectacular'' at the Disney-MGM Studios Theme Park; ``Wonders of Life'' at Epcot Center and ``Dreamflight'' in the Magic Kingdom.

DOC.HEAD: Three Students Wounded in High School Shooting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Three students were wounded Friday in a gang shooting outside a high school during lunch break, police said. Police arrested one 17-year-old about a half-mile from Austin High School and a 16-year-old student originally brought for questioning as a witness, said Lt. Paul Saucedo. ``They literally got out of the car walked up the stairs and found their targets and shot'' with a handgun, Saucedo said. He said the gunmen seeking revenge for the non-fatal drive-by shooting of a youth two weeks ago. The dispute involved two rival gangs that have been troublesome in the past, Saucedo said. Alex Martinez, 16, was in critical but stable condition at William Beaumont Medical Center with a gunshot wound to the abdomen and hip. Less seriously injured were David Munoz, 16, and Ramon Rodarte, 17. Austin High School principal John Doran expressed shock and asked students who witnessed the shooting to come forward. ``I'm very upset about it. It frightens me when I think about what could have happened to other students, besides the ones who were wounded today,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Washington State Asks Whether It Can Kill Troublesome Sea Lions
DOC.TEXT: Washington state is seeking clarification from the federal government on whether the state can kill some sea lions that annually devastate a run of seagoing trout, officials said Friday. While the state waits for an answer, it plans to truck the worst offenders to their California breeding grounds and harass the remainder with firecrackers and rubber-tipped arrows, among other devices. As many as 40 sea lions have gathered annually near the Ballard Locks for the last eight years to dine on the wild steelhead that must negotiate a fish ladder there on their spawning migration from Puget Sound to inland streams. The sea lions weren't considered a problem until 1985, when they caught 30 percent of the wild fish run. Last year they ate an estimated 65 percent of the run, allowing just 687 fish out of a run of 1,973 to pass the fish ladder. At that rate, the run would be extinct within a decade, Curt Smitch, director of the state Department of Wildlife, said Friday. This year, officials hope 816 of 2,093 fish will survive to spawn. The sea lions are protected under the federal Marine Mammal Protection Act. The steelhead are protected under state _ not federal _ law. Within a month, federal authorities will begin gathering public comment on whether the Marine Mammal Act allows killing protected animals in cases where they are destroying other wildlife, Rolland Schmitten, Northwest regional director of the National Marine Fisheries Service, said Friday. Washington state had asked the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, which enforces the act, for the ruling last fall. The public comment period should last between 60 and 90 days and a federal ruling on the question should be made by year's end, in time for next year's steelhead run, Schmitten said.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Probing Crash Survivor's Connection to Medellin Cartel
DOC.TEXT: The FBI said Friday it is investigating a report that a survivor of the Avianca jet crash who was found to have swallowed packets of cocaine may be a hit man for the Medellin drug cartel. FBI spokeswoman Lorraine Johnson said the Colombian government had informed the bureau that Antonio Zuluage, a 46-year-old Colombian national, may be a hired killer for the notorious drug-trafficking organization. She said federal agents are working with Colombian authorities to determine if Zuluage is the same man known as a killer in Colombia. The investigation should take several days, she said. Zuluage is being held on drug possession charges in the Nassau County Medical Center's prison ward, where he is listed in satisfactory condition with back and arm injuries sustained in the plane crash. Seventy-three people died in that accident. Assistant District Attorney Pamela Kelly-Pincus said Zuluage was arraigned at his bedside on Tuesday on charges of criminal possession of a controlled substance, a charge punishable by up to 25 years to life in prison.
